questions.text: You find a parking spot on a busy street, but a fire hydrant is 12 feet away. What should you do?
choices: Find another spot — you must park at least 15 feet from a hydrant
Park there since 12 feet provides enough clearance
Park there but leave your hazard lights on
Park there only if you'll be gone less than 5 minutes
questions.explanation: Texas law requires at least 15 feet of clearance from fire hydrants. At 12 feet, you are in violation. This buffer ensures fire crews can quickly connect hoses without moving parked vehicles, potentially saving critical minutes in an emergency.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.302; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: You want to park near an intersection. How close to a crosswalk are you legally allowed to park?
choices: No closer than 20 feet
No closer than 15 feet
No closer than 10 feet
As close as you want if the crosswalk is unmarked
questions.explanation: Texas law prohibits parking within 20 feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. This distance keeps parked vehicles from blocking drivers' view of pedestrians entering the crosswalk, reducing the risk of a pedestrian being struck by a turning vehicle.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.302; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: While searching for parking downtown, you notice a curb painted blue. A car without any visible placard or special plate is parked there. What can you conclude?
choices: The parked car is likely in violation — blue curbs are reserved for disabled parking permit holders
Blue curbs allow anyone to park for a limited time
Blue curbs indicate a commercial loading zone
The driver may have a temporary permit not displayed on the dash
questions.explanation: Blue curbs designate disabled parking spaces. Vehicles must display a valid disabled placard on the rearview mirror or have disabled license plates to legally park there. A vehicle without any visible permit is likely in violation. Texas law requires the placard or plate to be displayed at all times while parked.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §681.011; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: You're running a quick errand and the only nearby spot requires parking partially on the sidewalk. Is this legal in Texas?
choices: No — parking on a sidewalk is always illegal regardless of the duration
Yes, if you leave at least 4 feet of sidewalk clear for pedestrians
Yes, for stops under 10 minutes
Yes, in residential areas if no pedestrians are present
questions.explanation: Parking on sidewalks is always illegal in Texas because it forces pedestrians — including those using wheelchairs, strollers, or mobility aids — into the street. No duration, time of day, or lack of pedestrian traffic makes it permissible.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.302; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: How far must you park from a stop sign or traffic signal?
choices: 30 feet
15 feet
20 feet
50 feet
questions.explanation: You must park at least 30 feet from any stop sign, traffic signal, or flashing beacon to ensure the sign remains visible to approaching drivers.

questions.text: What does a red painted curb mean?
choices: No stopping or parking at any time
Fire lane - emergency vehicles only
Loading zone during business hours
No parking during rush hour
questions.explanation: Red curbs prohibit all stopping and parking at any time. This is the most restrictive curb marking and violations can result in tickets or towing.

questions.text: Can you park in front of a private driveway?
choices: No, it blocks property access
Yes, if the property owner agrees
Yes, for less than 5 minutes
Yes, if no car is in the driveway
questions.explanation: Parking in front of any driveway, including private driveways, is illegal because it blocks property owners from entering or exiting their property.

questions.text: How far from a railroad crossing must you avoid parking?
choices: 50 feet
30 feet
20 feet
100 feet
questions.explanation: Texas law prohibits parking within 50 feet of a railroad crossing to maintain clear sightlines and ensure vehicles can safely cross the tracks without obstruction.

questions.text: You pull up to a block where every curb space is taken, and a delivery truck is parked alongside one of those vehicles, blocking the lane. What is this situation called?
choices: Double parking
Parallel parking overflow
Lane sharing
Temporary standing
questions.explanation: Double parking means stopping or parking alongside a vehicle already occupying a curb space, which blocks the travel lane. It is illegal because it forces other drivers to swerve into oncoming traffic or wait, creating congestion and crash risk.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.302; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: What does a yellow painted curb typically indicate?
choices: Loading zone for commercial vehicles
Caution area - park carefully
School zone parking
Temporary parking only
questions.explanation: Yellow curbs designate loading zones, usually for commercial vehicles to load or unload goods. Time limits and restrictions are typically posted on nearby signs.

questions.text: Is it legal to park within an intersection?
choices: No, intersections must remain clear
Yes, if the intersection is small
Yes, if no other cars are approaching
Yes, during off-peak hours
questions.explanation: Parking within any intersection is always illegal. Intersections must remain clear for turning vehicles and to maintain traffic flow and safety.

questions.text: How far must you park from a fire station driveway on the same side of the street?
choices: 20 feet
15 feet
30 feet
50 feet
questions.explanation: You must park at least 20 feet from a fire station driveway entrance when parking on the same side of the street to allow emergency vehicles quick access.

questions.text: How far must you park from a fire station driveway on the opposite side of the street?
choices: 75 feet
50 feet
100 feet
20 feet
questions.explanation: When parking across from a fire station driveway, you must stay at least 75 feet away to provide adequate maneuvering space for large emergency vehicles.

questions.text: Can you park in a designated bike lane?
choices: No, bike lanes must remain clear
Yes, if no cyclists are present
Yes, for brief stops only
Yes, during non-peak hours
questions.explanation: Parking in bike lanes is illegal as it forces cyclists into traffic and creates dangerous conditions. Bike lanes must remain clear at all times.

questions.text: You see a white painted curb in front of a hotel entrance. What does this curb color mean for you?
choices: You may stop briefly to load or unload passengers only
Parking is prohibited at all times
You may park for up to 30 minutes
The space is reserved for hotel guests
questions.explanation: White curbs designate passenger loading and unloading zones with strict time limits. You may stop to drop off or pick up passengers but may not leave your vehicle unattended or park for extended periods. Check posted signs for specific time limits.

questions.text: What does a green painted curb typically indicate?
choices: Limited time parking, usually 15-30 minutes
Parking for hybrid vehicles
Free parking all day
Visitor parking only
questions.explanation: Green curbs indicate short-term parking with time limits, commonly 15 to 30 minutes. Check posted signs for specific time restrictions in that area.

questions.text: Is it legal to park between a safety zone and the adjacent curb?
choices: No, this area must remain clear
Yes, if the safety zone is empty
Yes, during off-peak hours
Yes, for emergency stops
questions.explanation: Parking between a safety zone and the curb is prohibited to maintain pedestrian safety areas and ensure clear access for people entering or exiting transit vehicles.

questions.text: You see a sign that says 'NO PARKING ANYTIME' with a red circle and slash. What does this mean?
choices: Parking is never permitted in this location
Parking is allowed only during emergencies
Parking is allowed with a permit
Parking is restricted during business hours
questions.explanation: A 'NO PARKING ANYTIME' sign with prohibitory markings means parking is absolutely forbidden at all times, day or night, regardless of circumstances.

questions.text: Can you park directly on a crosswalk?
choices: No, crosswalks must remain clear
Yes, if no pedestrians are crossing
Yes, if the signal is red
Yes, partially if necessary
questions.explanation: Parking on crosswalks is illegal as it blocks pedestrian right-of-way and creates safety hazards, especially for people with visual impairments or mobility devices.

questions.text: What should you always check before parking in a location with posted signs?
choices: Time restrictions and permit requirements
The color of nearby vehicles
The weather forecast
The street name
questions.explanation: Always read parking signs carefully for time limits, permit requirements, street cleaning schedules, and restricted hours to avoid tickets or towing.

questions.text: You're about to parallel park between two vehicles. What should your first action be?
choices: Signal, then pull forward until you are alongside the vehicle ahead of the space
Turn your steering wheel hard toward the curb and begin backing in
Back up slowly until your rear bumper is even with the car behind the space
Check your rearview mirror and begin reversing immediately
questions.explanation: The first step in parallel parking is to signal your intent and pull alongside the vehicle in front of the open space, positioning your car about 2–3 feet away and roughly even with that vehicle. This starting position sets the correct angle for the backing maneuver that follows.

questions.text: How far should you position your car from the vehicle ahead when beginning parallel parking?
choices: 2-3 feet
1 foot
4-5 feet
6 inches
questions.explanation: Position your vehicle 2-3 feet away from the car ahead. This distance provides adequate room to maneuver while backing into the parking space.

questions.text: After pulling alongside the car ahead, which way should you turn your wheels as you begin backing?
choices: Sharply toward the curb
Sharply away from the curb
Keep wheels straight
Slightly to the left
questions.explanation: Turn your wheels sharply toward the curb as you begin backing. This angles your vehicle into the parking space and positions it correctly.

questions.text: When your car reaches about a 45-degree angle during parallel parking, what should you do with your wheels?
choices: Straighten them
Turn them more toward the curb
Turn them away from the curb
Keep them in the same position
questions.explanation: At approximately 45 degrees, straighten your wheels and continue backing. This prevents your front end from swinging too far into the street.

questions.text: What is the maximum distance from the curb your vehicle should be when parallel parked in Texas?
choices: 18 inches
12 inches
24 inches
6 inches
questions.explanation: Texas law requires that parallel parked vehicles be within 18 inches of the curb. Parking farther out obstructs traffic flow and is a violation.

questions.text: Approximately how large should a parallel parking space be for safe parking?
choices: About 1.5 times your vehicle length
Exactly the same as your vehicle length
Twice your vehicle length
Three times your vehicle length
questions.explanation: A safe parallel parking space should be about 1.5 times the length of your vehicle, providing enough room to maneuver in and out without hitting other cars.

questions.text: You are ready to leave a parallel parking space on a busy street. What is the safest sequence of actions?
choices: Check mirrors and blind spots, signal, then merge when a gap appears
Turn on your hazard lights and pull out slowly
Honk your horn to alert other drivers, then pull out
Accelerate quickly to match traffic speed while merging
questions.explanation: Before leaving a parallel parking space, check all mirrors and your blind spot for vehicles, cyclists, and pedestrians. Signal your intent to give other drivers time to react. Then merge only when there is a safe gap in traffic. Rushing into traffic without checking creates a serious collision risk.

questions.text: When parallel parking, how should you control your speed?
choices: Back slowly with gentle brake pressure
Back quickly to minimize time
Use cruise control
Accelerate while turning
questions.explanation: Back into the space slowly, maintaining control with gentle brake pressure. Slow speed allows you to make adjustments and prevents collisions.

questions.text: After backing until nearly parallel to the curb, which way should you turn your wheels to straighten the vehicle?
choices: Away from the curb
Toward the curb
Keep wheels straight
Alternate left and right
questions.explanation: Once nearly parallel, turn wheels away from the curb while continuing to back slowly. This straightens your vehicle and centers it in the space.

questions.text: Can you parallel park within 15 feet of a fire hydrant?
choices: No, you must stay at least 15 feet away
Yes, if you leave your keys in the car
Yes, if you stay in the vehicle
Yes, for less than 5 minutes
questions.explanation: You cannot parallel park or stop within 15 feet of a fire hydrant under any circumstances, as this blocks emergency access to water supplies.

questions.text: When parking uphill with a curb, which way should you turn your wheels?
choices: Away from the curb (left)
Toward the curb (right)
Straight ahead
Either direction is acceptable
questions.explanation: When parking uphill with a curb, turn wheels away from (left of) the curb. If the car rolls backward, the back of the tire will hit the curb and prevent the car from rolling into traffic.

questions.text: When parking downhill with a curb, which way should you turn your wheels?
choices: Toward the curb (right)
Away from the curb (left)
Straight ahead
Either direction is acceptable
questions.explanation: When parking downhill with a curb, turn wheels toward (right to) the curb. If the car rolls forward, the front tire will hit the curb and stop the vehicle.

questions.text: When parking uphill without a curb, which way should you turn your wheels?
choices: Right, toward the road shoulder
Left, away from the road shoulder
Straight ahead
It doesn't matter without a curb
questions.explanation: Without a curb, turn wheels right toward the shoulder. If the car rolls backward, it will go off the road away from traffic rather than into the traffic lane.

questions.text: When parking downhill without a curb, which way should you turn your wheels?
choices: Right, toward the road shoulder
Left, away from the road shoulder
Straight ahead
It doesn't matter without a curb
questions.explanation: Without a curb on a downhill, turn wheels right toward the shoulder. If the car rolls forward, it will move off the road rather than into traffic.

questions.text: What should you always engage when parking on a hill?
choices: The parking brake
The turn signal
The hazard lights
The air conditioning
questions.explanation: Always set your parking brake when parking on any hill to provide an additional safety mechanism that prevents your vehicle from rolling.

questions.text: When parking on a hill with an automatic transmission, what gear should you use?
choices: Park
Drive
Neutral
Reverse
questions.explanation: Put an automatic transmission in Park when parking on a hill. Combined with the parking brake and properly turned wheels, this secures your vehicle.

questions.text: When parking uphill with a manual transmission, which gear provides the best safety?
choices: First gear (lowest gear)
Reverse
Neutral
Third gear
questions.explanation: Use first gear (lowest gear) when parking uphill with a manual transmission. This provides maximum resistance against backward rolling if the brake fails.

questions.text: When parking downhill with a manual transmission, which gear should you use?
choices: Reverse
First gear
Neutral
Second gear
questions.explanation: When parking downhill with a manual transmission, use reverse gear to provide resistance against forward rolling if other parking mechanisms fail.

questions.text: Why is it important to turn your wheels properly when parking on a hill?
choices: To prevent the car from rolling into traffic if brakes fail
To make it easier to drive away
To reduce tire wear
To improve fuel economy
questions.explanation: Properly turned wheels ensure that if your parking brake fails, the vehicle will roll into the curb or off the road, not into traffic, preventing accidents.

questions.text: What is the purpose of turning wheels toward the curb when parked downhill?
choices: The front tire hits the curb if the car rolls forward
It makes backing out easier
It prevents tire theft
It improves the vehicle's appearance
questions.explanation: Turning wheels toward the curb when parked downhill means the front tire will contact the curb if the vehicle rolls forward, stopping it before entering traffic.

questions.text: You need to drop off a package and the closest spot is a disabled parking space with a blue sign. You don't have a disabled placard. Can you use it for a quick stop?
choices: No — only vehicles displaying a valid disabled placard or plate may use these spaces
Yes, if you stay in the vehicle with the engine running
Yes, for stops under 3 minutes
Yes, if no disabled drivers are waiting for the space
questions.explanation: Disabled parking spaces are reserved exclusively for vehicles displaying a valid disabled placard or license plate. No exceptions exist for brief stops, staying in the vehicle, or the space appearing unused. Fines for unauthorized use can range from $500 to $1,250 in Texas.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §681.011; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: What is the minimum fine for illegally parking in a disabled parking space in Texas?
choices: $500 or more
questions.explanation: Texas imposes fines of $500 or more for unauthorized use of disabled parking spaces, reflecting the serious nature of this violation and its impact on people with disabilities.

questions.text: What color is a permanent disabled parking placard?
choices: Blue
Red
Green
Yellow
questions.explanation: Permanent disabled parking placards are blue in color and are issued to individuals with long-term mobility impairments that qualify them for disabled parking privileges.

questions.text: What color is a temporary disabled parking placard?
choices: Red
Blue
Yellow
Orange
questions.explanation: Temporary disabled parking placards are red and are issued for short-term disabilities, typically with an expiration date of six months or less.

questions.text: Can you park in the diagonal striped area next to a disabled parking space?
choices: No, these access aisles must remain clear
Yes, if the disabled space is empty
Yes, for motorcycles only
Yes, for brief stops
questions.explanation: Diagonal striped access aisles next to disabled spaces must remain completely clear. They provide necessary space for wheelchair deployment and are not parking areas.

questions.text: What does a 'Van Accessible' sign indicate at a disabled parking space?
choices: The space is wider for wheelchair lifts and ramps
Only vans can park there
The space is for commercial vehicles
The space has a longer time limit
questions.explanation: Van accessible spaces are wider than standard disabled spaces to accommodate wheelchair lifts and ramps. All vehicles with valid disabled permits can use them, but they prioritize vans.

questions.text: Is it legal to use someone else's disabled parking placard?
choices: No, it must be used only by the person to whom it was issued
Yes, if they give you permission
Yes, if you're running an errand for them
Yes, if they're in the vehicle with you
questions.explanation: Disabled parking permits are issued to specific individuals and cannot be transferred or borrowed. Using another person's permit is illegal and subject to fines.

questions.text: What makes a parking space legally designated as a disabled parking space?
choices: Both proper signage and pavement markings
Only the wheelchair symbol painted on the ground
Only the vertical sign post
Either signage or pavement markings
questions.explanation: Legal disabled parking spaces require both a vertical sign meeting specifications and pavement markings with the international symbol of access for proper designation.

questions.text: Can you park in a disabled space if you're just dropping off a person with disabilities?
choices: No, unless the vehicle displays a valid permit
Yes, for passenger loading only
Yes, if you stay in the vehicle
Yes, for less than 5 minutes
questions.explanation: Even when transporting a person with disabilities, the vehicle must display a valid disabled parking permit to use disabled parking spaces, or you must use regular passenger loading zones.

questions.text: What does the international symbol of access (wheelchair symbol) on pavement indicate?
choices: The space is reserved for disabled parking permit holders
Anyone can park if they assist disabled persons
Wheelchair repair services available
The area is wheelchair accessible
questions.explanation: The wheelchair symbol painted on pavement identifies spaces reserved exclusively for vehicles displaying valid disabled parking permits, ensuring accessibility for those who need it.

questions.text: When parallel parking, what should you monitor while backing into the space?
choices: All mirrors and the rear window
Only the driver's side mirror
Only the rearview mirror
Only the passenger side mirror
questions.explanation: Check all mirrors and look through the rear window while backing to monitor your distance from both the curb and other vehicles, ensuring safe clearance.

questions.text: You attempt to parallel park but end up more than 18 inches from the curb after your first try. What is the best course of action?
choices: Pull forward and repeat the parking maneuver from the beginning
Open your door to check the distance and adjust from your current position
Leave the car as is — 18 inches is close enough
Ask a bystander to guide you into the correct position
questions.explanation: Texas requires vehicles to park within 18 inches of the curb. If your first attempt puts you too far out, the safest approach is to pull completely forward and restart the maneuver. Trying to adjust from an awkward angle increases the risk of hitting adjacent vehicles.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.051; DL-7 Parking Rules

questions.text: Can you parallel park in front of a driveway if the space is large enough?
choices: No, blocking driveways is always illegal
Yes, if you fit completely in the space
Yes, if the driveway appears unused
Yes, during nighttime hours
questions.explanation: Regardless of space size, parking in front of any driveway is illegal because it blocks property access. Always ensure your entire vehicle is clear of driveway entrances.

questions.text: When preparing to parallel park, what should you do to alert other drivers?
choices: Use your turn signal
Flash your headlights
Sound your horn
Turn on hazard lights
questions.explanation: Always activate your turn signal before beginning to parallel park. This alerts following drivers of your intention to stop and allows them to safely pass or wait.

questions.text: After parallel parking on a steep hill, what additional precautions should you take?
choices: Turn wheels appropriately and set parking brake firmly
Leave the car in neutral for easy rolling
Keep the engine running
Place wheel chocks on all four tires
questions.explanation: On steep hills, combine proper wheel positioning with a firmly set parking brake and appropriate gear selection to create multiple safety systems against rolling.

questions.text: Why must access aisles next to disabled parking spaces remain clear?
choices: They provide room for wheelchair ramps and mobility devices
They are reserved for disabled motorcycles
They mark fire lanes
They indicate loading zones
questions.explanation: Access aisles provide essential space for people using wheelchairs, walkers, or other mobility devices to safely enter and exit their vehicles. Blocking them prevents access.

questions.text: What should you do if all regular parking spaces are full but disabled spaces are available?
choices: Find parking elsewhere; never use disabled spaces without a permit
Park in a disabled space briefly
Park in the access aisle instead
Wait for a regular space to open
questions.explanation: Disabled parking spaces are legally reserved for permit holders at all times. Without a valid permit, you must find alternative parking regardless of convenience.

questions.text: When exiting a parallel parking space on a busy street, what is the safest procedure?
choices: Check all mirrors and blind spots, signal, and merge when clear
Pull out quickly to avoid blocking traffic
Sound horn and pull out immediately
Wait for all traffic to stop
questions.explanation: Safety requires checking all mirrors and blind spots for traffic, cyclists, and pedestrians, signaling your intention, and merging smoothly when you have a safe gap.

questions.text: A car is parked facing uphill on a steep street with no curb. If the parking brake fails, which way will the car roll and why is the wheel position critical?
choices: Backward into traffic unless wheels are turned right toward the shoulder
Forward down the hill unless wheels are turned left
Backward into the shoulder if wheels are straight
It won't roll if in park gear
questions.explanation: Without a curb, gravity pulls the car backward downhill. Wheels turned right direct the car toward the shoulder and away from traffic if brake systems fail, preventing collisions.

questions.text: What is the primary reason Texas law requires parking within 18 inches of the curb when parallel parked?
choices: To maintain traffic flow and prevent obstruction of the travel lane
To prevent damage to the vehicle's tires
To make it easier for other drivers to parallel park
To comply with federal highway regulations
questions.explanation: The 18-inch rule ensures parked vehicles don't protrude excessively into the travel lane, maintaining safe traffic flow and reducing collision risks with passing vehicles.

questions.text: You are driving on a four-lane highway and want to change from the left lane to the right lane. There is a solid white line between the lanes. What does this mean?
choices: Lane changes are discouraged but not illegal — change only if necessary and safe
Lane changes are strictly prohibited
The line marks the boundary between opposing traffic flows
The line indicates a merge area ahead
questions.explanation: Solid white lines between same-direction lanes discourage lane changes but do not legally prohibit them. They are used in areas where lane changes are risky, such as near intersections or highway exits. Cross them only when necessary and after checking that it is safe to do so.

questions.text: On a three-lane highway, dashed white lines separate all three lanes. You want to move from the center lane to the right lane. Is this permitted?
choices: Yes — dashed white lines indicate lane changes are allowed when safe
No — you must stay in your lane until the next exit
Only if you use your turn signal for at least 5 seconds first
Only if a solid white line is not present on the other side
questions.explanation: Dashed white lines separate lanes of same-direction traffic and indicate that lane changes are permitted. Always signal your intent, check mirrors and blind spots, and change lanes only when there is a safe gap in traffic.

questions.text: You are on a two-lane road and want to pass a slow-moving truck. The center line on your side is solid yellow and the line on the truck's side is dashed yellow. Are you legally allowed to pass?
choices: No — the solid line on your side prohibits passing regardless of what the other side shows
Yes — the dashed line on either side permits passing for both directions
Yes — as long as no oncoming traffic is visible
Only if the truck is traveling below the posted speed limit
questions.explanation: When a double yellow center line has one solid and one dashed component, the rule applies to each side independently. The solid line on your side means passing is prohibited for you. The dashed line on the other side means oncoming traffic may pass when safe. This asymmetric marking is used where sight distance differs by direction — your direction has limited visibility for safe passing.

questions.text: What is the primary difference between yellow and white pavement lines?
choices: Yellow separates opposing traffic, white separates same-direction traffic
Yellow means caution, white means proceed
Yellow is for highways, white is for city streets
Yellow marks parking areas, white marks driving lanes
questions.explanation: Yellow lines separate traffic flowing in opposite directions, while white lines separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction. This color coding helps drivers understand traffic flow patterns.

questions.text: When you see a single dashed yellow line, what does it indicate?
choices: Passing is allowed when safe
Passing is never permitted
Two-way left turn lane
Emergency vehicles only
questions.explanation: A single dashed yellow line indicates that passing is permitted in both directions when it is safe to do so and you can see far enough ahead.

questions.text: What does it mean when there is a double yellow line with one solid and one dashed line?
choices: You can pass only if the dashed line is on your side
You can pass from either direction
No one can pass from either direction
Only emergency vehicles can pass
questions.explanation: With a solid/dashed combination, passing is allowed only from the side with the dashed line. If the solid line is on your side, you cannot pass.

questions.text: While driving at night on an unfamiliar rural road, you notice a white line running along the right edge of the pavement. What is its purpose?
choices: It marks where the paved roadway ends, helping you stay on the road
It marks a bicycle lane that you must not cross
It indicates a no-parking zone along the shoulder
It marks a passing zone on the right side
questions.explanation: White edge lines mark the right boundary of the roadway. They are especially helpful at night, in rain, or on unfamiliar roads because they give drivers a visible reference for staying within the travel lane. Drifting past the edge line means you are leaving the roadway.

questions.text: If you are driving and the solid yellow line is on your side with a dashed yellow line on the opposite side, what should you do?
choices: Do not pass, passing is only allowed for opposing traffic
Pass when safe to do so
Pass only if no traffic is visible
Slow down and prepare to stop
questions.explanation: When the solid yellow line is on your side, you are prohibited from passing. Only vehicles on the side with the dashed line may pass when safe.

questions.text: What do wider and more frequently spaced dashes in a white line indicate?
choices: An exit or entrance lane is approaching
Speed up to merge
Construction zone ahead
Emergency stopping area
questions.explanation: Wider, more frequent dashes indicate a lane transition area where vehicles will be entering or exiting the roadway. This gives drivers advance warning to prepare for merging traffic.

questions.text: What does a yellow edge line on the left side of a divided highway indicate?
choices: The left edge of traffic traveling in your direction
A passing zone
Emergency vehicle access
A carpool lane
questions.explanation: On divided highways, a yellow line on the left marks the left edge of your traffic lanes, separating your direction from the opposing traffic lanes or median.

questions.text: When approaching a solid white line at an intersection, what does it indicate?
choices: You should not change lanes within the intersection
You must stop immediately
Turn only lanes ahead
Pedestrian crossing area
questions.explanation: Solid white lines at intersections discourage lane changes through the intersection, helping maintain orderly traffic flow and reducing collision risks.

questions.text: You are approaching an intersection and see a solid white line across your lane. Are you legally required to stop at this line?
choices: Only if accompanied by a stop sign, red light, or other traffic control device
Yes — all solid white lines require you to stop
No — solid white lines are advisory only and never require a stop
Only during school hours
questions.explanation: A solid white line across a lane is a stop line that shows where to stop when required by a traffic signal, stop sign, or other control device. The line itself does not create a stop requirement — the accompanying signal or sign does. Without such a device, the line merely suggests a safe stopping point.

questions.text: What is the purpose of longer dashed white lines with shorter gaps?
choices: To mark a lane drop or merge area requiring extra caution
To indicate higher speed limits
To mark carpool lanes
To designate truck lanes
questions.explanation: Extended dashes with reduced gaps signal transition zones where lanes are ending or merging, alerting drivers to use extra caution and prepare for lane changes.

questions.text: What does a double solid white line between lanes indicate?
choices: Crossing is prohibited except in emergencies
Lanes are for same direction but different vehicle types
Passing is allowed when clear
Parking is permitted on both sides
questions.explanation: Double solid white lines indicate a barrier between lanes that should not be crossed except in emergency situations. These often separate HOV lanes or mark restricted zones.

questions.text: Why are yellow lines used instead of white on undivided two-way roads?
choices: To warn drivers that oncoming traffic is in the adjacent lane
To indicate construction zones
To mark school zones
To show speed limits
questions.explanation: Yellow lines clearly identify that traffic on the other side is traveling in the opposite direction, providing an important visual warning about oncoming vehicles.

questions.text: When can you legally cross a double solid yellow line?
choices: When turning left into or out of a driveway or side street
When passing slower traffic
When visibility is clear for at least 500 feet
Never under any circumstances
questions.explanation: While you cannot pass across double solid yellow lines, you may cross them to turn left into or out of driveways, alleys, or side streets when it is safe to do so.

questions.text: What do broken white lines that become solid white lines indicate?
choices: Lane changes should end, an intersection or restricted area is ahead
Speed limit is increasing
Emergency vehicles only beyond this point
Parking is now allowed
questions.explanation: The transition from broken to solid white lines warns drivers to complete lane changes before reaching an area where lane changes are discouraged, such as approaching intersections.

questions.text: What does it mean when yellow lines are painted on both sides of your lane?
choices: You are in a center turn lane shared by traffic from both directions
You are in a restricted zone
You are driving the wrong way
You are in a passing zone
questions.explanation: Yellow lines on both sides indicate a two-way left turn lane that is shared by traffic from both directions for making left turns only.

questions.text: You are driving on a two-lane road and notice that the center line is yellow. The line on the right edge of your lane is white. Why are different colors used?
choices: Yellow separates opposing traffic; white separates same-direction traffic or marks the road edge
Yellow means caution; white means the lane is safe to travel in
Yellow lines are older markings; white lines are newer
Yellow is used on rural roads; white is used on urban roads
questions.explanation: Yellow center lines always separate traffic moving in opposite directions, warning you that vehicles on the other side are coming toward you. White lines separate same-direction lanes or mark the road edge. This color system is standardized nationwide by the MUTCD so drivers can instantly understand lane configuration on any road.

questions.text: If you see solid yellow lines transitioning to dashed yellow lines, what is changing?
choices: You are entering a zone where passing is now permitted
The speed limit is decreasing
A school zone is ahead
You must change lanes
questions.explanation: The transition from solid to dashed yellow lines indicates the end of a no-passing zone and the beginning of an area where passing is allowed when safe.

questions.text: What does a wide white edge line indicate?
choices: The edge of the roadway, often used where extra visibility is needed
A parking lane
A bike path
An emergency stopping zone
questions.explanation: Wider white edge lines provide enhanced visibility of the roadway edge, especially useful in areas with limited lighting, curves, or poor weather conditions.

questions.text: What is the significance of seeing a dashed yellow line that becomes solid yellow?
choices: A no-passing zone is beginning, complete passes before reaching the solid line
The road is ending
A passing zone is starting
Slow traffic must exit
questions.explanation: This transition warns drivers that a no-passing zone is ahead. Any passing maneuver must be completed before reaching the solid yellow line.

questions.text: On a three-lane road with dashed yellow on both sides of the center lane, who can use the center lane?
choices: Traffic from both directions for left turns only
Only traffic traveling north or east
Only emergency vehicles
Faster traffic for passing
questions.explanation: This describes a two-way left turn lane where drivers from both directions can enter briefly to make left turns. It is not for passing or through traffic.

questions.text: What should you do when approaching an area where solid white lines separate multiple lanes in the same direction?
choices: Avoid changing lanes and stay in your current lane
Change lanes quickly before the lines become double
Slow down to 25 mph
Activate hazard lights
questions.explanation: Solid white lines indicate that lane changes are discouraged in that area. Drivers should remain in their lane to maintain traffic flow and safety.

questions.text: Under what condition might you see both yellow and white lines together in the same lane area?
choices: At a transition from one-way to two-way traffic flow
In construction zones only
At state borders
In residential areas
questions.explanation: Yellow and white lines together typically mark transitions between one-way streets (white lines) and two-way roads (yellow center line), helping drivers understand changing traffic patterns.

questions.text: What does a left turn arrow painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: This lane must turn left
Left turns are prohibited
This is a passing lane
Yield to left-turning traffic
questions.explanation: A left turn arrow on the pavement indicates a mandatory turn lane. Vehicles in this lane must turn left at the intersection.

questions.text: You are in a lane with a straight arrow painted on the pavement as you approach an intersection. You want to turn right. What should you do?
choices: Proceed straight — the arrow requires you to continue through the intersection
Turn right since the arrow only suggests a direction
Turn right but signal your intention
Stop and wait for the arrow to change
questions.explanation: A straight pavement arrow indicates a mandatory lane-use direction. Vehicles in a lane marked with a straight arrow must proceed straight through the intersection. To turn right, you must be in a lane marked with a right-turn or combination arrow. Changing lanes at the last moment to turn is unsafe and often illegal.

questions.text: What does the word 'ONLY' painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: The lane is restricted to the designated direction or purpose shown
Only one car allowed at a time
Only buses permitted
Emergency vehicles only
questions.explanation: ONLY emphasizes that the lane is exclusively designated for a specific use, such as turning or a particular vehicle type, and cannot be used for other purposes.

questions.text: As you approach a mid-block area, you see bold white zebra-stripe markings painted across the road. No traffic signal is present. What must you do?
choices: Watch for pedestrians and yield to anyone within or about to enter the crosswalk
Proceed at normal speed since there is no signal requiring you to stop
Stop completely before the markings whether or not pedestrians are present
Treat the markings as a speed bump and slow down slightly
questions.explanation: Zebra-stripe markings designate a pedestrian crosswalk. Even without a traffic signal, drivers must yield to pedestrians within or about to enter a marked crosswalk. Failing to yield can result in a citation and, more importantly, endanger pedestrians who have the right-of-way.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §552.003; DL-7 Pavement Markings

questions.text: What does a thick white line across the lane at an intersection indicate?
choices: The stopping point for traffic signals or stop signs
A speed bump location
A pedestrian-only zone
A merge point
questions.explanation: A stop line marks where vehicles must stop when required by a traffic signal, stop sign, or to yield to pedestrians. Vehicles should not enter the intersection beyond this line.

questions.text: What do white triangles pointing toward your vehicle indicate?
choices: A yield line where you must give right-of-way
Speed bumps ahead
Sharp turn warning
Lane ends
questions.explanation: Yield line triangles point toward approaching traffic to indicate where drivers must yield right-of-way to other vehicles or pedestrians. This is common at roundabouts and yield intersections.

questions.text: What does a right turn arrow painted on the pavement mean?
choices: This lane must turn right
Right turns are prohibited
Yield to right-turning traffic
Right lane ends
questions.explanation: A right turn arrow designates a mandatory right turn lane. Vehicles positioned in this lane must turn right and cannot proceed straight.

questions.text: What does a combined left and straight arrow on the pavement indicate?
choices: You may either turn left or continue straight from this lane
You must choose left or straight before entering the lane
Left turns have priority over straight traffic
This is a passing lane
questions.explanation: A combined arrow indicates an optional lane where drivers may either turn or proceed straight. Both movements are permitted from this lane.

questions.text: When you see the word 'STOP' painted on the pavement, what does it indicate?
choices: A stop line position even if the painted line is worn away
School zone crossing
Emergency stopping point
Construction zone boundary
questions.explanation: STOP painted on the pavement reinforces the stop requirement and shows where to stop, especially useful when stop lines have faded or in areas where the sign may be less visible.

questions.text: What is the purpose of crosswalk markings at an intersection?
choices: To designate the safe path for pedestrians crossing the street
To indicate where vehicles should stop
To mark parking boundaries
To separate different traffic lanes
questions.explanation: Crosswalk markings guide pedestrians across the street safely and alert drivers to areas where they must yield to foot traffic.

questions.text: If you see arrows and the word 'ONLY' together on the pavement, what does this combination mean?
choices: The lane is exclusively for the movement shown by the arrow
Only one vehicle at a time
Commercial vehicles only
Passing is permitted only in this lane
questions.explanation: The combination of an arrow with ONLY creates a mandatory lane designation, meaning vehicles in that lane must follow the arrow's direction exclusively.

questions.text: What should you do when you see a stop line at an intersection?
choices: Stop with your front bumper at or before the line
Stop with your rear bumper at the line
Slow down but you don't need to stop
Stop only if pedestrians are present
questions.explanation: Vehicles must stop at or before the stop line, ensuring the entire vehicle is behind the line. This provides safe clearance for cross traffic and pedestrians.

questions.text: What do school zone pavement markings typically indicate?
choices: Reduced speed limits and increased pedestrian activity ahead
Bus stops only
No parking zones
Emergency vehicle access
questions.explanation: School zone pavement markings warn drivers to reduce speed and watch carefully for children and crossing guards. These areas require heightened awareness.

questions.text: Why might you see a stop line positioned well back from the intersection?
choices: To provide sight distance for turning vehicles or large truck clearance
To create parking spaces
To mark a pedestrian waiting area
Because the marking was placed incorrectly
questions.explanation: Stop lines are sometimes set back to improve sight lines at difficult intersections or to provide adequate turning radius for large vehicles like trucks and buses.

questions.text: What does 'NO PASSING ZONE' painted on the pavement mean?
choices: Passing is prohibited in this area due to limited visibility or hazards
You must drive in single file
No trucks allowed
Speed limit is reduced
questions.explanation: NO PASSING ZONE pavement text reinforces that passing maneuvers are prohibited, typically due to limited sight distance, curves, or hills.

questions.text: What does a combined right and straight arrow mean?
choices: You may turn right or continue straight from this lane
You must turn right, but straight traffic may pass on the left
Right turns only during certain hours
Yield to traffic going straight
questions.explanation: A combined right-straight arrow indicates a shared lane where both right turns and through movements are permitted, giving drivers flexibility in their direction.

questions.text: If there is no marked crosswalk at an intersection, where should pedestrians cross?
choices: At the extension of the sidewalk across the intersection
Anywhere they choose
Only at traffic signals
Pedestrians cannot cross without markings
questions.explanation: Even without painted markings, an unmarked crosswalk exists at intersections where sidewalks extend. Pedestrians have the right-of-way, and drivers must yield.

questions.text: While driving, you see the word 'ONLY' painted in white on the pavement along with a right-turn arrow. Why is this marking white rather than yellow?
choices: White is used for lane-use markings because they guide same-direction traffic
White indicates the marking is mandatory; yellow would make it advisory
White markings are used in urban areas; yellow markings in rural areas
White is easier to see at night than yellow
questions.explanation: Pavement arrows, word markings, and lane-use symbols are white because they direct traffic traveling in the same direction. The MUTCD reserves yellow for markings that separate opposing traffic flows. This consistent color coding helps drivers instantly understand whether they are dealing with same-direction or opposing-direction guidance.

questions.text: What should you do if you realize you are in a turn-only lane but need to go straight?
choices: Complete the turn and find a safe way to return to your route
Stop and back up to change lanes
Go straight anyway
Turn on hazard lights and stop
questions.explanation: Once in a mandatory turn lane, you must complete the turn as indicated. Attempting to go straight or change lanes at the last moment creates dangerous situations.

questions.text: Why are some crosswalks marked with two parallel lines while others use zebra stripes?
choices: Both are valid; zebra stripes provide higher visibility in high-traffic areas
Zebra stripes are only for school zones
Parallel lines mean yield, zebra means stop
Different cities use different standards randomly
questions.explanation: Both marking styles are legal crosswalks. Zebra stripes are often used in high-traffic or high-risk areas because they provide better visibility and draw more attention from drivers.

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of white pavement markings?
choices: To separate lanes of traffic moving in the same direction
To separate opposing traffic
To indicate parking areas
To mark construction zones
questions.explanation: White markings are used to organize and separate traffic moving in the same direction, helping drivers stay in proper lanes and make safe lane changes.

questions.text: A newly licensed driver asks you why the center line on their street is yellow while the lane lines on the highway are white. What is the correct explanation?
choices: Yellow markings separate traffic flowing in opposite directions; white separates same-direction lanes
Yellow means the road has a lower speed limit; white means higher speed
Yellow is used on older roads; white on roads built after 2000
There is no standard — cities choose their own colors
questions.explanation: The color system is set by the MUTCD and used nationwide: yellow lines always separate opposing traffic flows (head-on risk), while white lines separate same-direction traffic or mark road edges. Understanding this distinction is critical — crossing a yellow line puts you in the path of oncoming vehicles.

questions.text: What does a red curb indicate?
choices: No stopping or parking at any time
Fire lane parking only
Emergency vehicle parking
Loading zone
questions.explanation: Red curbs designate no-stopping zones. Vehicles cannot stop, stand, or park in these areas, which are often near fire hydrants or emergency access points.

questions.text: What does a blue curb indicate?
choices: Parking reserved for disabled persons with proper permits
Police parking only
Passenger loading zone
Motorcycle parking
questions.explanation: Blue curbs mark disabled parking spaces. Only vehicles displaying valid disabled parking permits or license plates may park in these designated areas.

questions.text: What does a white curb typically indicate?
choices: Passenger loading and unloading only for a limited time
No parking restrictions
Disabled parking
Emergency vehicles only
questions.explanation: White curbs designate passenger loading zones where vehicles can stop briefly to pick up or drop off passengers but cannot park for extended periods.

questions.text: What does a yellow curb indicate?
choices: Loading zone or no parking during posted hours
School zone
Caution area
Taxi stand only
questions.explanation: Yellow curbs typically mark commercial loading zones where parking is prohibited but brief stops for loading/unloading are permitted during specified times.

questions.text: What does a green curb indicate?
choices: Limited time parking as posted
Electric vehicle charging only
Park and ride zone
Environmentally friendly parking
questions.explanation: Green curbs designate short-term parking areas with time limits, typically 15-30 minutes. These allow for brief stops while preventing all-day parking.

questions.text: Can you stop at a red curb to let a passenger out?
choices: No, red curbs prohibit all stopping
Yes, for up to 3 minutes
Yes, if you stay in the vehicle
Yes, during off-peak hours
questions.explanation: Red curbs mean absolutely no stopping at any time. This includes dropping off passengers, as these areas must remain clear for emergency access or fire safety.

questions.text: Why do yellow and white lines have different meanings?
choices: To help drivers quickly identify whether adjacent traffic is traveling the same or opposite direction
Yellow is older, white is newer
Different colors for different speed limits
To distinguish urban from rural roads
questions.explanation: The color-coding system provides instant visual information about traffic flow direction, which is critical for safety when deciding whether passing or lane changes are safe.

questions.text: What does colored pavement in a bike lane indicate?
choices: Enhanced visibility of the bike lane, especially at conflict points
Bike racing area
Bikes must stop
Bikes have absolute right-of-way
questions.explanation: Colored pavement in bike lanes increases visibility at intersections, driveways, or other locations where vehicle-bicycle conflicts are more likely to occur.

questions.text: What is the difference between a white curb and a blue curb?
choices: White is for passenger loading, blue is for disabled parking only
They mean the same thing
White is daytime only, blue is 24-hours
White is free, blue requires payment
questions.explanation: White curbs allow brief stops for passenger loading by any vehicle, while blue curbs are exclusively reserved for vehicles with disabled parking credentials.

questions.text: When is parking at a green curb typically allowed?
choices: For the limited time posted on nearby signs
Only with a permit
24 hours a day
Only for electric vehicles
questions.explanation: Green curbs indicate time-limited parking. Drivers must check posted signs for specific time limits and any applicable hours of enforcement.

questions.text: What does it mean when the pavement in a bike lane is painted green?
choices: It highlights conflict zones where drivers must be especially cautious of bicyclists
Only green bikes can use this lane
Environmentally friendly zone
Bike lane ends ahead
questions.explanation: Green pavement within bike lanes marks areas of potential conflict between bicycles and turning vehicles, alerting both to exercise extra caution.

questions.text: Are you required to park within white painted parking space lines?
choices: Yes, to ensure adequate space for other vehicles and safe access
No, they are only suggestions
Only in paid parking lots
Only if a parking attendant is present
questions.explanation: White parking space lines must be observed to ensure orderly parking, accessibility, and adequate space for all vehicles and pedestrians.

questions.text: What legal difference exists between a solid yellow curb and a yellow curb with specific time restrictions posted?
choices: Solid yellow may have restrictions that apply 24/7, while posted times indicate when restrictions are active
No difference, both mean the same thing
Solid yellow is more restrictive than posted times
Posted times override the yellow curb meaning entirely
questions.explanation: Yellow curbs must be evaluated based on posted signage. Without time-specific signs, restrictions may apply at all times. Posted signs specify exactly when loading is permitted or prohibited.

questions.text: What does a bicycle symbol painted on the pavement with a solid white line indicate?
choices: A designated bike lane that vehicles should not enter
Bicycles must exit the roadway
Bicycle parking area
Bicycle repair station
questions.explanation: A bicycle symbol with a solid white line marks a dedicated bike lane. Motor vehicles should not drive or park in these lanes except when necessary to turn.

questions.text: What does a white diamond symbol painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: A high-occupancy vehicle (HOV) or carpool lane
Jewelry store ahead
Premium parking
Diamond-shaped intersection ahead
questions.explanation: Diamond symbols mark HOV lanes reserved for vehicles with multiple occupants. Check posted signs for specific occupancy requirements and hours of operation.

questions.text: What does a bicycle symbol with chevron markings (sharrow) indicate?
choices: A shared lane where bicycles and vehicles both have right to use the full lane
Bicycles must stay to the right
Bicycle crossing ahead
Bicycles prohibited
questions.explanation: Sharrows indicate shared lane usage where bicycles and motor vehicles share the travel lane. They remind drivers that cyclists have the right to use the full lane.

questions.text: What do the pavement markings for a center two-way left turn lane look like?
choices: Yellow lines on both sides with breaks and arrows pointing in both directions
Solid white lines on both sides
Single dashed yellow line in the center
Double solid yellow lines
questions.explanation: Center turn lanes have distinctive yellow lines on both sides with arrows showing that traffic from both directions uses this lane exclusively for left turns, not through travel.

questions.text: What does an X with the letters RR painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: Railroad crossing ahead
Road repair zone
Rest area exit
Restricted route
questions.explanation: The RR with an X marking warns drivers that railroad tracks cross the road ahead. Drivers should slow down and look for trains before crossing.

questions.text: How should you use a center two-way left turn lane?
choices: Enter only to prepare for a left turn, not for passing or through travel
Use it to pass slow-moving vehicles
Use it to merge into traffic
Use it as a continuous travel lane
questions.explanation: Center turn lanes are exclusively for preparing to turn left. Drivers should enter the lane close to their turning point and not use it for passing or extended travel.

questions.text: What does a handicapped parking symbol painted on the pavement indicate?
choices: Parking space reserved for vehicles displaying disabled parking credentials
Accessible route to building entrance
Wheelchair rental location
Medical facility parking
questions.explanation: The wheelchair symbol marks parking spaces legally reserved for people with disabilities who display valid disabled parking permits or license plates.

questions.text: Can you drive in a bike lane to prepare for a right turn?
choices: Yes, you should merge into the bike lane within 200 feet of the turn when safe
No, never enter a bike lane
Yes, at any distance from the turn
Only if no bicycles are visible
questions.explanation: Drivers should merge into the bike lane before turning right to avoid cutting off cyclists. Check for bicyclists, signal, and merge safely within 200 feet of the intersection.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a sharrow versus a dedicated bike lane?
choices: Sharrows indicate shared use of the lane, while bike lanes provide exclusive space for bicycles
Sharrows are for faster cyclists only
They mean exactly the same thing
Sharrows are temporary, bike lanes are permanent
questions.explanation: Sharrows are used where space is insufficient for a separate bike lane, reminding drivers that cyclists have equal rights to the lane. Bike lanes provide dedicated space separated by lines.

questions.text: What should you do when approaching an HOV lane marked with diamonds?
choices: Check posted signs for occupancy requirements and hours before entering
Enter only during rush hour
Enter if your vehicle has two or more axles
These lanes are for emergency vehicles only
questions.explanation: HOV lanes have varying requirements for number of occupants and restricted hours. Always check posted signage before entering to ensure compliance with current regulations.

questions.text: At a 4-way stop intersection, two vehicles arrive at the same time from different directions. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle on the left
The larger vehicle
Whoever honks first
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, the driver on the right has the right-of-way. This rule prevents confusion and reduces the risk of collisions.

questions.text: You arrive at a four-way stop at the same time as another vehicle to your right. Neither of you has a clear priority based on arrival time. Who should go first?
choices: The driver on your right has the right-of-way
The driver on the larger road has the right-of-way
You should go first since you are on the left
Both drivers should proceed simultaneously with caution
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive at a four-way stop at approximately the same time, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. This 'yield to the right' rule provides a simple, predictable tiebreaker that all drivers can follow consistently.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.151; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: At an uncontrolled intersection where there are no signs or signals, who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle traveling faster
The vehicle on the left
The vehicle that arrives first
questions.explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way when two vehicles arrive at approximately the same time. Always approach these intersections with caution.

questions.text: You are turning left at an intersection with a green light. Oncoming traffic is approaching. What should you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic before turning
Turn immediately since you have a green light
Honk and proceed with caution
Wait for the light to turn yellow
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, vehicles turning left must yield to oncoming traffic traveling straight. Left-turning vehicles must wait for a safe gap in traffic.

questions.text: At a T-intersection, you are on the through street and another vehicle is at the end of the T. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way on the through street
The vehicle at the end of the T
Whoever arrives first
The larger vehicle
questions.explanation: Traffic on the through street at a T-intersection has the right-of-way over vehicles entering from the terminating street. The entering vehicle must yield.

questions.text: You are entering a roundabout. Traffic is already circulating inside. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already in the roundabout
You, as the entering vehicle
Vehicles to your left
Whoever is driving faster
questions.explanation: Vehicles already circulating in a roundabout always have the right-of-way. Entering vehicles must yield until there is a safe gap to merge.

questions.text: You arrive at an intersection controlled by a stop sign. After stopping, you see a vehicle approaching on the cross street with no stop sign. What should you do?
choices: Remain stopped and let the approaching vehicle pass before proceeding
Proceed quickly since you stopped first
Inch forward to signal your intent to go
Honk to alert the other driver that you were there first
questions.explanation: A stop sign means you must stop AND yield the right-of-way to all vehicles and pedestrians on the cross street. The vehicle on the uncontrolled street has the right-of-way over you. You may proceed only after it is safe and no conflicting traffic is approaching.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.151; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: At a 4-way stop, three vehicles arrive at the same time. Vehicle A is on your right, Vehicle B is across from you, and you are Vehicle C. Who goes first?
choices: Vehicle A on your right
You (Vehicle C)
Vehicle B across from you
All vehicles proceed together
questions.explanation: When multiple vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, the vehicle on the right has priority. In this case, Vehicle A has the right-of-way.

questions.text: You are at a 4-way stop and want to turn left. A vehicle across from you arrives at the same time and wants to go straight. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle going straight
You, turning left
Whoever proceeds first
Both can go simultaneously
questions.explanation: When two vehicles face each other at an intersection, straight-through traffic has the right-of-way over left-turning traffic. Wait for the straight vehicle to clear before turning.

questions.text: You approach an intersection where the traffic signal is not working. How should you treat this intersection?
choices: As a 4-way stop
As an uncontrolled intersection where you can proceed freely
As a yield sign for all directions
As a green light for your direction
questions.explanation: When traffic signals are not functioning, all drivers must treat the intersection as a 4-way stop. Come to a complete stop and proceed according to right-of-way rules.

questions.text: You approach a yield sign at a highway on-ramp. Traffic on the highway is flowing steadily. What is the correct action?
choices: Slow down, check for a gap in highway traffic, and merge only when it is safe
Stop completely at the yield sign before entering the highway
Maintain your speed and merge — highway traffic must make room for you
Accelerate to highway speed and force your way into traffic
questions.explanation: A yield sign requires you to slow down and be prepared to stop if necessary, giving the right-of-way to vehicles already on the highway. You do not have to stop if a safe gap exists, but you must not force your way into traffic. Adjust your speed to match a gap and merge smoothly.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.153; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive second. The first vehicle is turning left across your path, and a third vehicle arrives after you on your right. When do you proceed?
choices: After the first vehicle completes their turn, before the third vehicle
After both the first and third vehicles
At the same time as the third vehicle
Before the first vehicle completes their turn
questions.explanation: At a 4-way stop, proceed in order of arrival. Since you arrived second, you go after the first vehicle clears, and before the third vehicle that arrived after you.

questions.text: You are turning right at an intersection. A vehicle is approaching from the left intending to turn left onto the same street. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle turning left from the opposite direction
You, turning right
Whoever signals first
Whoever completes the turn faster
questions.explanation: When both vehicles are turning onto the same street, the vehicle making the left turn generally has the right-of-way over the right-turning vehicle to avoid collision in the intersection.

questions.text: You are driving on a two-lane road and want to turn left into a driveway. Oncoming traffic is approaching. What should you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic before turning
Turn quickly before oncoming traffic reaches you
Signal and expect oncoming traffic to stop
Turn only if you can complete it in under 3 seconds
questions.explanation: Drivers turning left across oncoming traffic must yield the right-of-way to vehicles traveling straight. Wait for a safe gap before turning.

questions.text: You're stopped at a red light and want to turn right. The intersection has no 'No Turn on Red' sign. A pedestrian is crossing in the crosswalk to your right. What must you do?
choices: Remain stopped until the pedestrian clears your path, then turn when safe
Turn right slowly behind the pedestrian since you already stopped
Honk to alert the pedestrian, then turn
Wait for the light to turn green before turning
questions.explanation: Before turning right on red in Texas, you must come to a complete stop and yield to ALL pedestrians and vehicles. Even though right-on-red is permitted, the pedestrian in the crosswalk has the right-of-way. Wait until they have completely cleared your turning path before proceeding.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007(d); DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: At an uncontrolled intersection, you and another vehicle approach from perpendicular directions at about the same time. You are both going straight. Who yields?
choices: You yield if the other vehicle is on your right
The other vehicle always yields to you
Whoever is traveling faster proceeds first
Both vehicles should stop and wait
questions.explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, when two vehicles arrive simultaneously, the vehicle on the left must yield to the vehicle on the right. This is the fundamental right-of-way rule.

questions.text: You are in a roundabout and want to exit. A vehicle is trying to enter. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way while in the roundabout
The entering vehicle
Whoever signals first
Both proceed with caution
questions.explanation: Vehicles already circulating in a roundabout always have the right-of-way over entering vehicles. The entering driver must wait for a safe gap.

questions.text: At an intersection, you have a green light but there are vehicles still in the intersection from the previous signal cycle. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the intersection to clear before entering
Proceed immediately since you have the green light
Honk to clear the intersection
Enter slowly and navigate around the vehicles
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, you must yield to vehicles already in the intersection. Never enter an intersection until it is clear and you can completely cross.

questions.text: You have a green light and are turning right at an intersection. A jogger is in the crosswalk completing their crossing. What should you do?
choices: Yield to the jogger and turn only after they have cleared your path
Proceed with the turn since your green light gives you the right-of-way over pedestrians
Honk to alert the jogger and proceed with your turn
Speed up to turn before the jogger reaches your lane
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, drivers must yield to pedestrians already in the crosswalk. A green light permits you to proceed through the intersection but does not override a pedestrian's right-of-way. Always scan crosswalks before and during any turn.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §552.003; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: Two vehicles arrive at a 4-way stop at the same time. One is turning right, the other is turning left. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle turning right
The vehicle turning left
Both can proceed at the same time
Whoever signals first
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously and one is turning right, the right-turning vehicle generally has the right-of-way because the turn is less complex and involves less crossing traffic.

questions.text: At an intersection with a flashing red light, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat it as a stop sign
Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop only if other vehicles are present
Proceed at normal speed
questions.explanation: A flashing red light means the same as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to traffic and pedestrians, and proceed when safe.

questions.text: At an intersection with a flashing yellow light, what should you do?
choices: Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop completely
Proceed at normal speed
Treat it as a yield sign
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow light means slow down and proceed with caution. You do not need to stop, but should be alert for potential hazards at the intersection.

questions.text: You are at a 4-way stop and the vehicle on your left arrived just before you. That vehicle is going straight, and you want to turn left. Who proceeds first?
choices: The vehicle on your left that arrived first
You can proceed at the same time
You should proceed first since you are turning
Whoever has more space to maneuver
questions.explanation: At a 4-way stop, vehicles proceed in the order they arrive. The vehicle that arrived first has the right-of-way regardless of the direction they intend to travel.

questions.text: At an intersection, you have a left turn arrow (green arrow) but pedestrians are still crossing. What should you do?
choices: Yield to pedestrians even though you have the arrow
Proceed since you have the green arrow
Honk to alert pedestrians
Turn slowly and expect pedestrians to move
questions.explanation: Pedestrians always have the right-of-way when they are legally in a crosswalk, even if you have a green arrow. You must wait for them to clear before turning.

questions.text: When leaving a parking lot or driveway to enter a street, who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already on the street
You, as the exiting vehicle
Whoever signals first
Whoever proceeds first
questions.explanation: Vehicles on the street always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering from driveways or parking lots. You must yield before entering the roadway.

questions.text: At a complex intersection with multiple lanes, you are in a left turn lane with a green light (not an arrow). Oncoming traffic has a green light. Pedestrians are crossing the street you want to turn onto. Who goes first?
choices: Pedestrians, then oncoming traffic, then you
You have priority with your green light
Oncoming traffic only
Pedestrians only
questions.explanation: Pedestrians have the highest priority, followed by oncoming straight traffic, and finally left-turning vehicles. You must yield to both pedestrians and oncoming vehicles.

questions.text: In a roundabout, you need to exit but a pedestrian is in the crosswalk at your exit. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Proceed slowly since you are exiting
Honk to warn the pedestrian
Take the next exit instead
questions.explanation: Pedestrians always have the right-of-way in crosswalks, including those at roundabout exits. You must stop and wait for them to cross safely.

questions.text: The traffic light turns green. A delivery truck that entered the intersection on the previous yellow phase is still clearing the intersection. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the truck to clear the intersection before proceeding
Proceed immediately since your light is green
Honk to hurry the truck through the intersection
Go around the truck using the oncoming lane
questions.explanation: A green light means you may proceed, but you must yield to any vehicles and pedestrians already lawfully in the intersection. The truck entered on yellow and has the right to finish clearing. Entering the intersection while it is still occupied creates a collision risk.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: At a 4-way stop, all four vehicles arrive at exactly the same time. How should this situation be resolved?
choices: Drivers should make eye contact and proceed cautiously one at a time
All vehicles proceed simultaneously
The largest vehicle goes first
Wait for a police officer to direct traffic
questions.explanation: When all vehicles arrive simultaneously at a 4-way stop, drivers should use caution, make eye contact, and communicate to determine a safe order of proceeding.

questions.text: You approach a T-intersection where you are on the terminating street. You have a stop sign. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles on the through street
You, after stopping
Whoever arrives first
Vehicles turning into your street
questions.explanation: At a T-intersection, traffic on the through street has the right-of-way. You must stop and yield to all traffic on the through street before entering.

questions.text: A pedestrian is crossing the street at a marked crosswalk. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Proceed if you have a green light
Honk to warn the pedestrian
Speed up to cross before them
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in marked crosswalks, regardless of traffic signals. Pedestrian safety is the top priority.

questions.text: You are driving through a residential neighborhood and approach an intersection with no traffic signals or stop signs. A pedestrian steps off the curb at the corner, intending to cross. What must you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian — crosswalks exist at intersections even without markings
Proceed since there is no marked crosswalk
Slow down but continue if the pedestrian can wait
Flash your headlights to signal the pedestrian to wait
questions.explanation: Under Texas law, crosswalks exist at every intersection whether or not they are painted. Drivers must yield to pedestrians crossing within any crosswalk — marked or unmarked. A pedestrian stepping off the curb at an intersection corner is entering a legal crosswalk.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §552.003; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: A pedestrian has a white cane or is using a guide dog. What does this indicate?
choices: The pedestrian is blind or visually impaired and has the right-of-way
The pedestrian is a crossing guard
The pedestrian is conducting a safety demonstration
The pedestrian prefers not to be disturbed
questions.explanation: A white cane or guide dog indicates the pedestrian is blind or visually impaired. These pedestrians always have the right-of-way, and drivers must yield and take extra caution.

questions.text: You are turning right at an intersection and a pedestrian is crossing the street you are turning onto. The pedestrian has a 'Don't Walk' signal. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The pedestrian still has the right-of-way if they are in the crosswalk
You have the right-of-way since the pedestrian's signal says 'Don't Walk'
Whoever reaches the crosswalk first
Neither, both should stop
questions.explanation: Once a pedestrian is in the crosswalk, they have the right-of-way regardless of the pedestrian signal. Drivers must yield to pedestrians already crossing.

questions.text: You are driving through an active school zone at 20 mph. A group of children is crossing the road with a crossing guard holding a stop sign. What should you do?
choices: Stop completely and wait until all children are safely across and the guard signals you to proceed
Slow to 10 mph and carefully drive around the group
Stop only if the children are directly in your lane
Proceed at 20 mph since that is the posted school zone speed
questions.explanation: When a crossing guard displays a stop sign, all traffic must stop. Children in school zones have absolute right-of-way. Wait until every child has safely reached the sidewalk and the crossing guard signals that it is safe to proceed. Fines are doubled in school zones.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.152; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: A pedestrian is crossing in the middle of the block (not at a crosswalk or intersection). Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way, but should still avoid hitting the pedestrian
The pedestrian always has the right-of-way
Whoever reaches the point first
The pedestrian if they signal to cross
questions.explanation: Pedestrians jaywalking outside of crosswalks must yield to vehicles. However, drivers still have a duty to avoid hitting pedestrians even when the pedestrian is at fault.

questions.text: You are approaching a crosswalk where a pedestrian has just stepped off the curb on the far side of the road (multiple lanes away from you). What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian
Continue since the pedestrian is far away
Slow down slightly but proceed
Honk to alert the pedestrian
questions.explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to pedestrians in any part of the crosswalk, not just the lane closest to you. Stop and allow the pedestrian to cross safely.

questions.text: A bicycle is riding on the road in front of you. How should you treat this bicycle?
choices: As a vehicle with the same rights and responsibilities
As a pedestrian that must move to the sidewalk
As an obstacle to avoid quickly
As having less right-of-way than cars
questions.explanation: Bicycles are considered vehicles under Texas law and have the same rights and responsibilities as cars. Treat cyclists with respect and follow all right-of-way rules.
