questions.text: You are turning right and there is a bicycle lane to your right. A cyclist is approaching in the bike lane. What should you do?
choices: Yield to the cyclist before turning across the bike lane
Turn quickly before the cyclist reaches you
Honk and proceed with your turn
Signal for the cyclist to stop
questions.explanation: Drivers must yield to cyclists in bike lanes before turning across the lane. Check your mirrors and blind spots, and wait for the cyclist to pass before turning.

questions.text: A pedestrian is on the sidewalk next to the road, not attempting to cross. Do you need to yield?
choices: No, but be prepared to stop if they enter the roadway
Yes, always yield to pedestrians on sidewalks
Yes, if they make eye contact
No, pedestrians on sidewalks have no priority
questions.explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks are not in the roadway and you do not need to yield. However, stay alert and be ready to stop if they enter the roadway or approach a crosswalk.

questions.text: You are at an intersection with a traffic light. The vehicle signal is red, but the pedestrian signal shows a white WALK symbol. As a pedestrian, may you cross?
choices: Yes — the pedestrian WALK signal authorizes you to begin crossing in that direction
No — the red vehicle signal applies to both drivers and pedestrians
Only if a crossing guard is present
Only if you can make it across before the signal changes
questions.explanation: Pedestrians follow the pedestrian signal, not the vehicle signal. When the pedestrian signal shows WALK (or the walking person symbol), pedestrians may begin crossing in the indicated direction, even if the vehicle signal for the same direction is red. The signals are timed to protect pedestrians from conflicting vehicle movements.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §552.002; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: You are driving on a road with a bike lane. The bike lane is to your right and there are no cyclists present. Can you drive in the bike lane?
choices: Only when turning, merging, or parking where permitted
Yes, if no cyclists are present
Never, under any circumstances
Yes, to pass slow-moving traffic
questions.explanation: Drivers may only enter bike lanes when necessary for turning, merging, or legal parking. Otherwise, bike lanes are reserved exclusively for bicycle traffic.

questions.text: A pedestrian is crossing mid-block against a 'Don't Walk' signal. You have a green light. What should you do?
choices: Slow or stop to avoid hitting the pedestrian, even though you have the right-of-way
Proceed at speed since you have the right-of-way
Honk loudly and maintain speed
Flash your lights and continue
questions.explanation: While the pedestrian is violating the law, drivers still have a duty to avoid collisions. Slow down or stop to prevent hitting the pedestrian, even when you have the legal right-of-way.

questions.text: A bicycle is traveling on the road without a bike lane. Where should the cyclist ride?
choices: As far right as practicable, but still on the roadway
On the left side facing traffic
In the center of the lane at all times
On the sidewalk only
questions.explanation: Cyclists should ride as far to the right as safely practicable when there is no bike lane. They are entitled to use the full lane when necessary for safety.

questions.text: You are driving on a two-lane road and come upon a cyclist riding in the right portion of your lane. You want to pass. How much clearance does Texas law require?
choices: At least 3 feet between your vehicle and the cyclist
At least 1 foot as long as you slow down
No specific distance — just pass when you feel it is safe
At least 6 feet, which usually requires crossing the center line
questions.explanation: Texas law requires motorists to maintain at least 3 feet of clearance when passing a cyclist. If the lane is too narrow to provide 3 feet of space, you must wait for a safe opportunity to move partially into the adjacent lane. Cyclists are legally entitled to use the roadway.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.060; DL-7 Right-of-Way Rules

questions.text: You see a pedestrian with a white cane crossing at an intersection. The light turns green for you. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to completely finish crossing before proceeding
Proceed slowly and honk to alert them
Drive around the pedestrian carefully
Flash your lights to signal them to hurry
questions.explanation: Blind or visually impaired pedestrians always have the right-of-way. Wait patiently and allow them to cross completely before proceeding, regardless of your signal.

questions.text: You are approaching a crosswalk where the pedestrian signal is flashing 'Don't Walk' but no pedestrians are present. Can you turn?
choices: Yes, if there are no pedestrians in or approaching the crosswalk
No, you must wait for a solid 'Walk' signal
Yes, but only if you honk first
No, the flashing signal means stop
questions.explanation: A flashing 'Don't Walk' signal is for pedestrians who haven't started crossing. If no pedestrians are present or approaching, you may proceed with caution after yielding appropriately.

questions.text: A cyclist is making a left turn at an intersection from the left turn lane. You are behind them. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the cyclist to complete the turn, treating them as any other vehicle
Pass the cyclist on the right before they turn
Honk to encourage them to move faster
Move to the straight lane to avoid waiting
questions.explanation: Bicycles are vehicles and have the right to use turn lanes and make turns like any other vehicle. Wait patiently for the cyclist to complete their turn safely.

questions.text: You see a pedestrian crossing sign warning. What does this mean?
choices: Be alert for pedestrians crossing in this area
Pedestrians must use this crossing only
Stop and wait for pedestrians
Pedestrians are prohibited in this area
questions.explanation: Pedestrian crossing warning signs alert drivers to areas where pedestrians frequently cross. Slow down and be prepared to yield to pedestrians.

questions.text: A group of pedestrians is crossing at a crosswalk. Half have crossed and are now on the other side, while the rest are still crossing. Can you proceed?
choices: No, wait for all pedestrians to completely finish crossing
Yes, you can proceed in the empty lanes
Yes, if you proceed slowly
Yes, if you honk first
questions.explanation: You must wait for all pedestrians to completely clear the crosswalk before proceeding. Even if some lanes appear clear, more pedestrians may still be crossing.

questions.text: Can pedestrians walk in the roadway if a sidewalk is available?
choices: No, pedestrians must use the sidewalk when one is available
Yes, pedestrians can always choose to walk in the road
Yes, but only during daylight hours
Yes, if they walk facing traffic
questions.explanation: Texas law requires pedestrians to use sidewalks when they are available. Walking in the roadway when a sidewalk exists is prohibited.

questions.text: You see a bicycle crossing warning sign. What should you do?
choices: Be alert for cyclists crossing or entering the roadway
Stop and wait for cyclists
Cyclists are prohibited from crossing here
Sound your horn when you see cyclists
questions.explanation: Bicycle crossing warning signs indicate areas where cyclists frequently cross or enter the roadway. Slow down and watch carefully for cyclists.

questions.text: A cyclist is riding in the center of a narrow lane. Can you pass them?
choices: Only if you can change lanes completely or provide at least 3 feet of clearance
Yes, by squeezing past them in the same lane
Yes, by honking first to move them over
No, you must follow behind until they move
questions.explanation: Cyclists may take the full lane when necessary for safety. You may only pass by changing lanes completely or ensuring at least 3 feet of clearance, never by squeezing past in the same lane.

questions.text: You are stopped at a red light. A pedestrian starts crossing against the 'Don't Walk' signal. What should you do when your light turns green?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to finish crossing before proceeding
Proceed slowly and honk
Proceed since you have the green light
Turn on your hazard lights and wait
questions.explanation: Even if a pedestrian is crossing illegally, you must yield and allow them to finish crossing safely. Never enter an intersection with pedestrians still in your path.

questions.text: A cyclist is approaching a stop sign at the same time as you. You are also at a stop sign from a different direction. Who proceeds first?
choices: Follow normal right-of-way rules as if the cyclist is a vehicle
You always have priority over cyclists
The cyclist must always yield to motor vehicles
Whoever is faster proceeds first
questions.explanation: Bicycles are treated as vehicles and follow the same right-of-way rules. Apply the same rules you would for two motor vehicles arriving at a stop sign.

questions.text: If a sidewalk is not available, which side of the road should pedestrians walk on?
choices: On the left side, facing oncoming traffic
On the right side, with traffic flow
In the center of the road
On whichever side has better lighting
questions.explanation: When no sidewalk is available, pedestrians should walk on the left side of the road facing oncoming traffic so they can see vehicles approaching.

questions.text: At an intersection, you have a green light. A pedestrian with a white cane is crossing against the pedestrian signal, and a cyclist is making a left turn in front of you. Who has priority?
choices: The pedestrian with the white cane has highest priority, then the cyclist, then you
You have priority with your green light
The cyclist has priority as they arrived first
All should proceed with caution simultaneously
questions.explanation: Blind or visually impaired pedestrians always have the highest priority. Cyclists are treated as vehicles. You must yield to both the pedestrian and the cyclist before proceeding.

questions.text: You are driving on a road where there is both a bike lane and a sidewalk. Where should cyclists ride?
choices: In the bike lane, not on the sidewalk
On the sidewalk only
Either the bike lane or sidewalk, their choice
On the road with motor vehicles
questions.explanation: When a bike lane is present, cyclists should use it rather than the sidewalk. Bike lanes are designed specifically for bicycle traffic and provide the safest route.

questions.text: You are turning into a driveway and must cross a sidewalk. Pedestrians are walking on the sidewalk. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Pedestrians on the sidewalk
You, as you are entering private property
Whoever reaches the driveway first
Neither, both must stop
questions.explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering or exiting driveways. You must stop and yield before crossing the sidewalk.

questions.text: A pedestrian is standing at the curb at a marked crosswalk, looking as if they want to cross. Are you required to stop?
choices: Yes, if the pedestrian indicates intent to cross or steps into the roadway
No, only if they are already in the crosswalk
Yes, pedestrians always have priority near crosswalks
No, they must wait for you to pass
questions.explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to pedestrians who have shown intent to cross by stepping into the roadway or clearly indicating they wish to cross.

questions.text: An emergency vehicle with flashing lights and sirens is approaching from behind. What should you do?
choices: Pull over to the right and stop
Speed up to get out of the way
Stop immediately in your current lane
Change lanes to the left
questions.explanation: When an emergency vehicle approaches with lights and sirens, you must pull over to the right side of the road and stop until it passes. This provides a clear path for the emergency vehicle.

questions.text: You hear sirens from an emergency vehicle but don't see it. What should you do?
choices: Slow down, be alert, and be prepared to pull over
Continue driving normally
Stop immediately
Speed up to clear the area
questions.explanation: If you hear sirens but don't see the emergency vehicle, slow down and stay alert. Be prepared to pull over when you locate the vehicle's position.

questions.text: An emergency vehicle is approaching with lights and sirens while you are in an intersection. What should you do?
choices: Clear the intersection first, then pull over
Stop immediately in the intersection
Speed through the intersection
Back up to let the emergency vehicle through
questions.explanation: Never stop in an intersection, even for an emergency vehicle. Continue through the intersection, then pull over to the right and stop as soon as safely possible.

questions.text: A school bus has stopped with its red lights flashing and stop sign extended. You are on the same side of the road. What must you do?
choices: Stop at least 20 feet away and remain stopped until the bus moves or the lights stop flashing
Slow down and proceed with caution
Stop briefly then proceed if no children are visible
Change lanes and pass the bus slowly
questions.explanation: When a school bus displays flashing red lights and an extended stop sign, you must stop at least 20 feet away and remain stopped until the bus begins moving or the lights stop flashing.

questions.text: A school bus is stopped with red flashing lights on a two-lane road. You are approaching from the opposite direction. What should you do?
choices: Stop and remain stopped until the bus moves or the lights stop flashing
Slow down but proceed with caution
Proceed normally as the bus is on the other side
Stop only if you see children
questions.explanation: On an undivided two-lane road, traffic in both directions must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights. This protects children who may cross the road.

questions.text: You are on a highway separated by a median or barrier. A school bus on the other side has stopped with red lights flashing. Must you stop?
choices: No, you may proceed with caution
Yes, you must always stop for school buses
Only if the median is less than 10 feet wide
Yes, but only if children are present
questions.explanation: On a divided highway with a physical barrier or median, traffic traveling in the opposite direction does not need to stop for a school bus. The barrier prevents children from crossing.

questions.text: What do flashing yellow lights on a school bus indicate?
choices: The bus is preparing to stop; slow down and prepare to stop
You may pass the bus
The bus is stopped; you must stop
Children are boarding; stop immediately
questions.explanation: Flashing yellow lights on a school bus mean it is preparing to stop. Slow down and be ready to stop when the red lights begin flashing.

questions.text: An emergency vehicle is parked on the side of the road with flashing lights. What should you do?
choices: Move over to a non-adjacent lane if safe, or slow down to 20 mph below the speed limit
Maintain your speed and lane
Stop behind the emergency vehicle
Flash your lights and proceed
questions.explanation: Texas Move Over law requires drivers to move over to a non-adjacent lane if safe. If you cannot move over, you must slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit.

questions.text: You are at a red light and an emergency vehicle behind you has lights and sirens on. There is no room to pull to the right. What should you do?
choices: Stay stopped and wait for the light to change or for the emergency vehicle to find another route
Drive through the red light to clear the way
Back up to make room
Pull into the intersection
questions.explanation: Never run a red light, even for an emergency vehicle. Stay stopped and the emergency vehicle will navigate around you or wait for the light to change.

questions.text: A funeral procession is passing through an intersection. The procession has a green light but you arrived at the intersection first. What should you do?
choices: Yield to the entire funeral procession
Proceed since you arrived first
Proceed if you have a green light
Honk to alert the procession
questions.explanation: Funeral processions have the right-of-way at intersections. All vehicles in the procession may proceed together, and other traffic must yield to the entire procession.

questions.text: How can you identify a funeral procession?
choices: Vehicles have headlights on and often have funeral flags or follow a hearse
Vehicles are driving slowly
Vehicles have their hazard lights on
There is always a police escort
questions.explanation: Funeral processions typically have headlights on during the day, may display funeral flags, and follow a hearse. Not all processions have police escorts.

questions.text: Can you pass an emergency vehicle that is stopped on the side of the road with lights flashing?
choices: Yes, but you must move over or slow down significantly
No, you must stop behind it
Yes, at normal speed in the far lane
No, you must turn around and find another route
questions.explanation: You may pass a stopped emergency vehicle, but you must follow the Move Over law: change lanes if safe, or slow down to 20 mph below the speed limit.

questions.text: You are on a single-lane road and an emergency vehicle approaches from behind with lights and sirens. What should you do?
choices: Pull over to the right as far as possible and stop
Speed up to find a wider area
Stop in the middle of the road
Continue until you reach a parking lot
questions.explanation: Even on a single-lane road, pull as far to the right as safely possible and stop. The emergency vehicle will navigate around you if there is room, or wait until you can move further.

questions.text: A school bus has its red lights flashing. When can you proceed?
choices: When the red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted
When you don't see any children
After stopping for 10 seconds
When the bus driver waves you on
questions.explanation: You may only proceed past a stopped school bus when the red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted, indicating it is safe for the bus to resume travel.

questions.text: You are on a five-lane road (two lanes each direction with a center turn lane). A school bus on your side has stopped with red lights flashing. Must you stop?
choices: Yes, all traffic on your side must stop
No, you can change lanes and proceed
Only if you are in the lane next to the bus
No, five-lane roads are exempt
questions.explanation: All traffic traveling in the same direction as a stopped school bus must stop, regardless of the number of lanes. You cannot change lanes to go around the bus.

questions.text: A city bus is signaling to merge back into traffic from a bus stop. What should you do?
choices: Yield and allow the bus to merge when safe
Maintain your speed and position
Speed up to pass the bus
Honk to indicate the bus should wait
questions.explanation: Texas law requires drivers to yield to buses signaling to re-enter traffic from a designated stop. Slow down and allow the bus to merge safely.

questions.text: Can you follow closely behind an emergency vehicle with lights and sirens to get through traffic faster?
choices: No, this is illegal and dangerous
Yes, if you maintain a safe following distance
Yes, but only on highways
Yes, if you also turn on your hazard lights
questions.explanation: It is illegal to follow within 500 feet of an emergency vehicle responding to a call. This practice is dangerous and can result in tickets and fines.

questions.text: You are approaching an emergency vehicle with flashing lights stopped on a two-lane road with no room to move over. What should you do?
choices: Slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit
Stop completely behind the emergency vehicle
Proceed at the posted speed limit
Turn around and find another route
questions.explanation: If you cannot safely move over to a non-adjacent lane, you must slow down to 20 mph below the posted speed limit when passing emergency vehicles with flashing lights.

questions.text: At an intersection, a school bus with flashing red lights is stopped on your right, an emergency vehicle with sirens is approaching from behind, and a pedestrian is in the crosswalk ahead. Who has priority?
choices: The pedestrian, then the school bus, then the emergency vehicle
The emergency vehicle has priority over all
The school bus has priority over all
Follow order of arrival
questions.explanation: Pedestrian safety is paramount. The school bus stop creates a protected zone for children. The emergency vehicle can navigate around once pedestrians are clear and the bus situation is resolved.

questions.text: Can you pass a school bus that is stopped with flashing red lights on a multi-lane highway if you are in the far left lane?
choices: No, all lanes of traffic in your direction must stop
Yes, if you are more than two lanes away
Yes, if you slow down significantly
Yes, if the highway is divided
questions.explanation: All traffic traveling in the same direction as the school bus must stop when red lights are flashing, regardless of how many lanes separate you from the bus.

questions.text: You want to change lanes on a highway. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle already in the lane you want to enter
You, if you signal first
Whoever is traveling faster
You, if you complete the lane change quickly
questions.explanation: The vehicle already established in a lane has the right-of-way. You must yield to traffic in the lane you wish to enter and only merge when it is safe.

questions.text: You are merging onto a highway from an entrance ramp. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles already on the highway
You, as the merging vehicle
Whoever is traveling faster
Whoever signals first
questions.explanation: Traffic already on the highway has the right-of-way. Merging vehicles must yield, adjust speed, and find a safe gap to enter the highway traffic.

questions.text: You are on a highway and see a vehicle merging from an entrance ramp. What should you do?
choices: Maintain your speed and position, or move over if safe to help them merge
Speed up to prevent them from merging in front of you
Slow down and stop to let them in
Honk to warn them you have the right-of-way
questions.explanation: While highway traffic has the right-of-way, it is courteous and safer to move over or adjust speed if possible to help merging traffic. If not possible, maintain your speed and position.

questions.text: You are on a highway and need to exit. Another vehicle is in your blind spot. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle in your blind spot
You, because you need to exit
Whoever signals first
Both should proceed with caution
questions.explanation: The vehicle already in the lane has the right-of-way. If a vehicle is in your blind spot, you must slow down or speed up to create space before changing lanes to exit.

questions.text: Two vehicles are merging onto a highway from separate entrance ramps at the same point. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle that is ahead or on the right
The vehicle traveling faster
Both must stop and yield
The vehicle on the left
questions.explanation: When two vehicles are merging simultaneously, standard right-of-way rules apply. The vehicle ahead or to the right has priority, but both must yield to highway traffic.

questions.text: You are passing a slower vehicle on a two-lane highway. An oncoming vehicle appears. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The oncoming vehicle in its own lane
You, because you started passing first
Whoever is traveling faster
Both should slow down
questions.explanation: Oncoming traffic always has the right-of-way in their own lane. If you cannot complete a pass safely before oncoming traffic reaches you, you must abort the pass and return to your lane.

questions.text: You are entering a highway from a parking lot or driveway. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: All vehicles already on the highway
You, if you signal properly
Whoever proceeds first
You, if no vehicles are immediately visible
questions.explanation: When entering any roadway from private property like a parking lot or driveway, you must yield to all traffic already on the road. Wait for a safe gap before entering.

questions.text: You see a merge warning sign on the highway. What does this indicate?
choices: Traffic from another roadway will be merging ahead; be prepared to adjust
You must merge into another lane immediately
All traffic must stop
Your lane is ending
questions.explanation: A merge warning sign alerts you that traffic from an entrance ramp or merging lane will be joining your roadway. Be prepared to adjust speed or move over if safe.

questions.text: You are driving on a highway and your lane is ending (forced merge). Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles in the continuing lane
You, because your lane is ending
Whoever signals first
Whoever is ahead
questions.explanation: When your lane is ending and you must merge, you must yield to traffic in the continuing lane. You cannot force your way in; wait for a safe gap.

questions.text: You are on a highway entrance ramp with a yield sign. When can you merge?
choices: Only when there is a safe gap in highway traffic
After stopping completely
Whenever you signal your intention
When you reach the end of the ramp
questions.explanation: A yield sign means you must give right-of-way to highway traffic and merge only when there is a safe gap. Adjust your speed to find an appropriate opening.

questions.text: You are on a three-lane highway. You are in the center lane. Vehicles are merging from the right, and a vehicle on your left is signaling to move into your lane. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way in your current lane over both vehicles
The merging vehicle has priority
The vehicle on your left has priority
Whoever signals first
questions.explanation: As the vehicle established in your lane, you have the right-of-way over both vehicles trying to enter your lane. Both the merging and lane-changing vehicles must yield to you.

questions.text: You are exiting a highway and need to cross lanes of traffic. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: Vehicles in the lanes you need to cross
You, because you are exiting
Whoever signals first
You, if you are running out of road
questions.explanation: When changing lanes to exit, you must yield to all vehicles in the lanes you need to cross. Plan ahead and move over early to avoid last-minute dangerous maneuvers.

questions.text: On a two-lane road, you are behind a slow-moving vehicle and want to pass. There is a dashed yellow line. What should you do?
choices: Check for oncoming traffic, and pass only if you can complete it safely before any oncoming vehicle arrives
Pass whenever you want since the line is dashed
Honk first, then pass
Wait until the yellow line is completely gone
questions.explanation: A dashed yellow line indicates passing is permitted, but you must yield to oncoming traffic. Only pass when you can see far enough ahead and complete the pass safely.

questions.text: You are on a highway acceleration lane (entrance ramp). The lane is about to end and you need to merge, but there is steady traffic and no gaps. What should you do?
choices: Adjust your speed to create a gap, or use the shoulder if necessary and safe, rather than forcing a merge
Force your way into traffic
Stop at the end of the ramp and wait for a gap
Sound your horn and merge gradually
questions.explanation: Never stop on an acceleration lane unless absolutely necessary. Adjust speed to find or create a gap. If the lane ends, carefully use the shoulder before forcing an unsafe merge.

questions.text: You see a lane ends sign. What should you do?
choices: Merge into the continuing lane when it is safe to do so
Stop and wait for an opening
Speed up to merge before the lane ends
Continue to the very end and force your way in
questions.explanation: A lane ends sign gives you advance warning to merge safely into the continuing lane. Signal, check blind spots, and merge when there is a safe gap in traffic.

questions.text: You are passing a vehicle on a two-lane road. Oncoming traffic suddenly appears closer than expected. What should you do?
choices: Abort the pass and return to your lane immediately
Complete the pass as quickly as possible
Flash your lights at the oncoming vehicle
Both you and the oncoming vehicle should pull over
questions.explanation: If oncoming traffic appears during a pass and you cannot complete it safely, immediately abort the pass and return to your original lane. Oncoming traffic has the right-of-way in their lane.

questions.text: You are on a highway and traffic ahead is slowing down for a vehicle entering from an entrance ramp. What should you do?
choices: Slow down with traffic and maintain safe following distance
Change lanes immediately to avoid slowing down
Speed up to pass before the merging vehicle
Flash your lights at the merging vehicle
questions.explanation: When traffic slows to allow merging vehicles, maintain a safe following distance and slow down with traffic. Abrupt lane changes or speed increases can cause accidents.

questions.text: You are on a two-lane highway passing a slow vehicle. Another faster vehicle behind you is tailgating. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way to complete your pass safely before returning to your lane
The tailgating vehicle should pass both of you
You should abort your pass for the faster vehicle
The slow vehicle you are passing
questions.explanation: Once you have legally and safely begun passing, you have the right to complete the maneuver. The tailgating vehicle must wait. However, complete your pass promptly and return to your lane.

questions.text: You are preparing to merge onto a highway. Should you stop on the entrance ramp?
choices: Only if absolutely necessary; use the ramp to accelerate and merge smoothly
Yes, always stop before merging
Yes, unless you have a clear view
No, never stop under any circumstances
questions.explanation: Entrance ramps are designed for acceleration to match highway speed and merge smoothly. Stopping creates a dangerous situation. Only stop if there is no other safe option.

questions.text: You are on a highway in heavy traffic. Your exit is coming up, but you are in the left lane and there is no gap to move right. What should you do?
choices: Miss your exit and take the next one
Force your way across lanes immediately
Stop and wait for traffic to let you in
Drive on the shoulder to reach your exit
questions.explanation: Never make unsafe lane changes or stop on a highway. If you cannot safely reach your exit, miss it and take the next exit. Plan ahead in the future to move over earlier.

questions.text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive at the same time as another vehicle to your left. You are both turning right onto the same road. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You have the right-of-way since you are on the right
The vehicle on your left
Both can proceed simultaneously
Whoever has a larger turning radius
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way. Even though both are turning onto the same road, standard right-of-way rules apply.

questions.text: You are turning left from a minor road onto a major highway. Traffic on the highway is heavy in both directions. When can you proceed?
choices: Only when there is a sufficient gap in both directions to complete the turn safely
When traffic in one direction clears
After waiting 30 seconds
When another driver signals you to go
questions.explanation: When turning left onto a highway, you must yield to traffic from both directions. Wait for a gap large enough to enter and cross or merge safely without causing others to brake.

questions.text: You are at an intersection waiting to turn left. Your light turns yellow, then red, but you are already in the intersection. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn when oncoming traffic stops
Reverse back behind the stop line
Turn immediately before the light turns red
Wait in the intersection through the entire red light cycle
questions.explanation: If you are already legally in the intersection when the light turns red, you have the right to clear the intersection by completing your turn once oncoming traffic stops.

questions.text: At an intersection with a four-way flashing red light, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat each direction as a stop sign and proceed in order of arrival
Proceed with caution without stopping
Yield to all traffic then proceed
The main road has priority
questions.explanation: When all directions have flashing red lights, treat the intersection as a four-way stop. Each vehicle must stop completely and proceed in order of arrival, yielding to the right if simultaneous.

questions.text: You are in a roundabout. An emergency vehicle with lights and sirens is trying to enter. What should you do?
choices: Exit the roundabout at the next available exit and pull over
Stop immediately in the roundabout
Speed up to clear the roundabout quickly
Continue normally since you have the right-of-way
questions.explanation: Never stop in a roundabout. Continue to the next exit, then pull over to the right to allow the emergency vehicle to pass. Clear the roundabout as quickly and safely as possible.

questions.text: At a T-intersection, you are on the through road. A vehicle on the terminating road has a stop sign. You want to turn left onto the terminating road. Who proceeds first?
choices: You proceed first as you are on the through road
The vehicle with the stop sign proceeds first
Both proceed with caution
The vehicle going straight always has priority
questions.explanation: Traffic on the through road has the right-of-way over traffic entering from the terminating road. You may turn left without yielding to the stopped vehicle, though caution is always wise.

questions.text: You are merging onto a highway. The vehicle behind you on the highway is tailgating the car in front of it. Should you merge into that gap?
choices: No, find a safer gap with adequate following distance
Yes, signal and merge quickly
Yes, the tailgater will make room
Yes, you have the right to merge
questions.explanation: Never merge into an unsafe gap with inadequate following distance. Look for a safe gap where vehicles have proper spacing. Merging into a tight space increases collision risk.

questions.text: You are at a complex intersection. You have a green left turn arrow. A pedestrian with a guide dog is crossing the street you want to turn onto, but their signal shows 'Don't Walk'. An oncoming car runs the red light. Who do you yield to?
choices: Both the pedestrian and the red-light-running vehicle to avoid collisions
Neither, you have a green arrow
Only the pedestrian
Only the vehicle running the red light
questions.explanation: Safety always comes first. Despite having the legal right-of-way with your green arrow, you must avoid collisions with both the pedestrian and the vehicle violating the signal.

questions.text: You are driving on a highway in the left lane. You see a slower vehicle ahead in your lane. Do you have the right to stay in the left lane?
choices: No, the left lane is for passing; move right after passing
Yes, you can drive in any lane at any time
Yes, if you are going the speed limit
Only if there is heavy traffic
questions.explanation: The left lane on multi-lane highways is designated for passing. After passing slower traffic, you should move back to the right lane to allow others to pass.

questions.text: You are on a two-lane road following a mail carrier who stops frequently. Can you pass?
choices: Yes, if it is safe and legal to pass
No, you must always follow postal vehicles
Yes, postal vehicles do not have right-of-way
No, unless they signal you to pass
questions.explanation: Mail carriers do not have special right-of-way privileges while delivering mail. You may pass when it is safe and legal to do so, following normal passing rules.

questions.text: At an uncontrolled intersection, you are turning left and another vehicle is approaching from the right going straight. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right going straight has right-of-way over your left turn
You have the right-of-way since you arrived first
Both should proceed with caution
Whoever signals first
questions.explanation: At an uncontrolled intersection, the vehicle on the right has priority. Additionally, left-turning vehicles must yield to straight-through traffic. The vehicle on the right going straight has double priority.

questions.text: You are exiting a parking garage onto a busy street. A pedestrian is walking on the sidewalk approaching your exit. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The pedestrian on the sidewalk
You, as you are exiting private property
Whoever reaches the driveway first
You, if you honk to alert the pedestrian
questions.explanation: Pedestrians on sidewalks always have the right-of-way over vehicles entering or exiting driveways. You must stop and yield before crossing the sidewalk to enter the street.

questions.text: You approach a railway crossing with flashing lights. The gates are not down yet. What should you do?
choices: Stop and do not proceed until the lights stop flashing
Proceed quickly before the gates come down
Slow down and proceed with caution
Proceed if you don't see a train
questions.explanation: Flashing lights at a railway crossing mean a train is approaching. Stop at least 15 feet from the tracks and do not proceed until the lights stop flashing and gates are fully raised.

questions.text: At an intersection with a traffic light, you want to go straight and have a green light. Do you need to yield to any traffic?
choices: Yes, yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and vehicles already in the intersection
No, green means you have absolute right-of-way
Only to emergency vehicles
Only if the light just turned green
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, you must yield to pedestrians lawfully in the crosswalk and any vehicles already in the intersection before you enter.

questions.text: You are on a highway that is ending (merging into another highway). Does traffic on the continuing highway need to yield to you?
choices: No, you must yield to traffic on the continuing highway
Yes, they must let you merge
Whoever is traveling faster has priority
You have equal priority
questions.explanation: When your highway is ending and merging into another highway, you must yield to traffic on the continuing highway. Watch for merge signs and find a safe gap to merge.

questions.text: At a 4-way stop, you arrive first. As you begin to proceed, another vehicle runs the stop sign from your right. What should you do?
choices: Stop or slow down to avoid a collision, even though you have the right-of-way
Continue since you have the right-of-way
Honk and maintain speed
Accelerate to assert your right-of-way
questions.explanation: Having the legal right-of-way does not guarantee safety. Always be prepared to yield to avoid a collision, even when another driver violates traffic laws.

questions.text: You see a one-way sign. A vehicle is driving the wrong way toward you. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: You do, but avoid the collision by pulling to the right if possible
The wrong-way driver must turn around
Whoever is driving faster
Neither, both should stop
questions.explanation: You have the legal right-of-way on a one-way street, but safety is paramount. Pull to the right and avoid the wrong-way driver, then report the dangerous situation if possible.

questions.text: You are in the intersection waiting to turn left. The light is green. Oncoming traffic is heavy but stops for a pedestrian in the crosswalk. The light turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to clear and oncoming traffic to stop, then complete your turn
Turn immediately while oncoming traffic is stopped
Back up out of the intersection
Wait through the red light until the next green
questions.explanation: If you are legally in the intersection, you must clear it. Wait for the pedestrian to clear and oncoming traffic to stop, then complete your turn even if the light is red.

questions.text: Two vehicles approach an uncontrolled intersection from perpendicular directions. Vehicle A is on a wider road, Vehicle B is on a narrow road. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle on the right, regardless of road width
Vehicle A on the wider road
Vehicle B on the narrow road
Both should stop and negotiate
questions.explanation: At uncontrolled intersections, the vehicle on the right has the right-of-way regardless of road size. Road width does not determine priority unless signs or signals indicate otherwise.

questions.text: You are turning right at a red light (where permitted). A vehicle to your left is turning left onto the same road with a green arrow. Who has the right-of-way?
choices: The vehicle with the green left turn arrow
You, making the right turn
Both can proceed simultaneously
Whoever signals first
questions.explanation: A green arrow gives that driver the right-of-way. When turning right on red, you must yield to all traffic, including vehicles with a green arrow turning onto the same road.

questions.text: What is the most important defensive driving technique?
choices: Maintaining a space cushion around your vehicle
Driving at the speed limit
Using cruise control
Following traffic flow
questions.explanation: Maintaining a space cushion gives you time and room to react to hazards. Space on all sides of your vehicle is your best protection against collisions.

questions.text: How often should you check your mirrors while driving?
choices: Every 5-8 seconds
Every 15-20 seconds
Only when changing lanes
Once per minute
questions.explanation: You should check your mirrors every 5-8 seconds to maintain awareness of your surroundings. Regular mirror checks help you spot potential hazards and make informed driving decisions.

questions.text: You are following a pickup truck on a dry highway at 60 mph. What is the minimum safe following distance you should maintain?
choices: At least 3 seconds behind the truck
At least 2 car lengths behind the truck
At least 50 feet behind the truck
Close enough to read the truck's license plate
questions.explanation: The 3-second rule is the standard for good conditions. Pick a fixed object ahead; when the vehicle in front passes it, count 'one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two, one-thousand-three.' If you reach the object before finishing, you are too close. Time-based following distance works at any speed because the gap automatically increases as you go faster.

questions.text: How far ahead should you scan the road while driving on a highway?
choices: 12-15 seconds ahead
5-8 seconds ahead
3-5 seconds ahead
20-25 seconds ahead
questions.explanation: Scanning 12-15 seconds ahead allows you to identify potential hazards early and make smooth adjustments. This gives you adequate time to plan your response without sudden maneuvers.

questions.text: When should you check your blind spots?
choices: Before changing lanes, turning, or backing up
Only when backing up
Once every few minutes
Only in heavy traffic
questions.explanation: Blind spots hide vehicles that aren't visible in your mirrors. Checking blind spots before lane changes, turns, and backing prevents collisions with vehicles you can't see in mirrors alone.

questions.text: What does 'aim high in steering' mean in defensive driving?
choices: Look far down the road, not just at the vehicle ahead
Hold the steering wheel at the top
Drive in the left lane
Keep your hands high on the wheel
questions.explanation: Aiming high means focusing your vision far ahead rather than just the immediate area. This helps you spot hazards early and maintain better vehicle control by looking where you want to go.

questions.text: What should you do when encountering an aggressive driver?
choices: Let them pass and maintain a safe distance
Speed up to stay ahead of them
Brake suddenly to teach them a lesson
Signal aggressively to show your frustration
questions.explanation: The safest response to aggressive drivers is to avoid engagement and let them pass. Responding aggressively creates dangerous situations and escalates conflict on the road.

questions.text: Your phone rings while you are driving on a highway. You are not using a hands-free device. What is the safest action?
choices: Let the call go to voicemail and return it after you've stopped safely
Answer using speakerphone while keeping your eyes on the road
Answer quickly and keep the conversation under one minute
Pull onto the highway shoulder immediately to answer
questions.explanation: Any phone interaction while driving creates cognitive distraction that diverts attention from the road. The safest option is to let the call go to voicemail. If the call is urgent, exit the highway and pull into a safe location such as a parking lot before returning it. Highway shoulders are for emergencies, not phone calls.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.4251; DL-7 Safe Driving Practices

questions.text: What does 'leave yourself an out' mean in defensive driving?
choices: Always have an escape route if trouble develops
Keep an extra car key hidden
Park near exits
Avoid dead-end streets
questions.explanation: Having an escape route means positioning your vehicle so you have space to maneuver if a hazard appears. This strategy prevents being boxed in with nowhere to go during emergencies.

questions.text: When should you increase your following distance beyond 3 seconds?
choices: In rain, fog, or poor visibility conditions
Only when driving at night
Only on highways
Never, 3 seconds is always adequate
questions.explanation: Adverse conditions like rain, fog, or darkness require more following distance because your stopping distance increases and visibility decreases. Doubling to 6 seconds or more provides an adequate safety margin.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of the 'Smith System' of defensive driving?
choices: To organize driver behavior for early hazard recognition
To teach emergency braking techniques
To improve fuel economy
To reduce insurance premiums
questions.explanation: The Smith System provides five principles that help drivers identify hazards before they become emergencies. Early recognition allows time for smooth, controlled responses rather than panic reactions.

questions.text: What should you watch for to predict another driver's actions?
choices: Brake lights, turn signals, and head movements
Vehicle color and make
License plate numbers
The driver's age
questions.explanation: Visual clues like brake lights, signals, and where drivers are looking help predict their next move. Anticipating actions allows you to prepare and avoid conflicts before they develop.

questions.text: What does 'keep your eyes moving' mean in defensive driving?
choices: Continuously scan mirrors, gauges, and ahead rather than fixating
Look left and right constantly
Never focus on any one thing
Avoid looking at the road ahead
questions.explanation: Moving your eyes prevents tunnel vision and helps you gather information from all around your vehicle. Scanning creates a complete awareness picture rather than focusing on just one area.

questions.text: You have a green light and begin to enter an intersection. Another driver runs their red light and is heading toward you. What should you do?
choices: Yield and take evasive action to avoid the collision — safety overrides right-of-way
Continue through since you legally have the right-of-way
Stop in the intersection and honk your horn
Flash your headlights to assert your right-of-way
questions.explanation: Even when you have the legal right-of-way, you are expected to take reasonable action to avoid a collision. Texas law states that right-of-way rules do not relieve a driver from the duty to exercise due care. Insisting on your right-of-way when a crash is imminent is both dangerous and potentially negligent.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.151(d); DL-7 Safe Driving Practices

questions.text: How can you make sure other drivers see you?
choices: Use signals, horn, and lights to communicate your presence
Drive faster than traffic
Use bright colored vehicles only
Stay in the left lane
questions.explanation: Communication through signals, lights, and horn alerts others to your presence and intentions. Active communication prevents the 'I didn't see them' type of collision.

questions.text: What is the safest position when stopped behind another vehicle at a traffic light?
choices: Far enough back to see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead
As close as possible to maximize space
One car length back
Two feet behind their bumper
questions.explanation: Seeing the rear tires and some pavement gives you space to maneuver if needed and prevents being trapped if you're rear-ended. This position also allows you to pull around a disabled vehicle.

questions.text: What should you do if you realize you're about to miss your exit on a highway?
choices: Continue to the next exit and turn around
Slow down and change lanes quickly
Stop on the highway and back up
Cut across multiple lanes immediately
questions.explanation: Missing an exit is inconvenient but not dangerous. Making sudden lane changes or stopping creates collision risks that far outweigh the time lost by taking the next exit.

questions.text: What is the best strategy for driving in heavy traffic?
choices: Maintain steady speed and avoid unnecessary lane changes
Change lanes frequently to find faster movement
Drive on the shoulder when traffic slows
Follow vehicles closely to prevent lane changes
questions.explanation: Steady driving in heavy traffic reduces collision risk and actually doesn't cost much time compared to aggressive lane changing. Constant lane changes create more opportunities for crashes.

questions.text: What is the primary cause of rear-end collisions?
choices: Following too closely for conditions
Driving too slowly
Using brake lights improperly
Poor road maintenance
questions.explanation: Most rear-end crashes result from inadequate following distance. When drivers follow too closely, they don't have time to react when the vehicle ahead slows or stops suddenly.

questions.text: What should you do when you see a vehicle preparing to enter your lane?
choices: Adjust speed or position to create space for them
Speed up to close the gap
Honk your horn continuously
Maintain your exact speed and position
questions.explanation: Defensive driving means helping other drivers execute their maneuvers safely. Creating space prevents conflicts even when other drivers don't signal properly or misjudge gaps.

questions.text: How should you position your hands to maintain best control while driving?
choices: At 9 and 3 o'clock or 8 and 4 o'clock positions
At 10 and 2 o'clock positions
One hand at 12 o'clock
Both hands at the bottom of the wheel
questions.explanation: The 9 and 3 or 8 and 4 positions provide excellent control while reducing injury risk from airbag deployment. These positions allow full steering range without crossing arms.

questions.text: What is the best way to handle distractions inside your vehicle?
choices: Address them before driving or pull over safely
Glance at them quickly while driving straight
Handle them only at traffic lights
Deal with them while other passengers watch the road
questions.explanation: Even brief distractions significantly increase crash risk. Taking care of issues before starting to drive or pulling over safely eliminates the danger of divided attention.

questions.text: When is it acceptable to drive in another vehicle's blind spot?
choices: Never, always move ahead or drop back
When passing on the right
In slow-moving traffic only
When the other driver appears experienced
questions.explanation: Staying in blind spots puts your safety in another driver's hands. Positioning yourself where you can be seen gives you control over your safety and prevents being struck during their lane changes.

questions.text: What should you do when approaching an intersection with a green light?
choices: Check for vehicles running the red light before entering
Accelerate through quickly
Assume all cross traffic will stop
Focus only on the signal
questions.explanation: Green lights give you the right-of-way but not absolute safety. Checking for red light runners before entering intersections prevents the most common type of intersection crash.

questions.text: What is the main benefit of smooth, gradual steering and braking?
choices: Maintains vehicle stability and gives you more control
Uses less fuel
Extends brake life
Looks more professional
questions.explanation: Smooth inputs keep weight transfer gradual, maintaining tire traction and vehicle stability. Sudden movements can break traction and cause loss of control, especially in adverse conditions.

questions.text: After a dinner party, a 25-year-old driver feels fine but has consumed several drinks over several hours. A breathalyzer shows 0.07% BAC. Can they legally drive in Texas?
choices: Technically yes, since 0.07% is below the 0.08% legal limit, but impairment has already begun
No — the legal limit for adults in Texas is 0.05%
Yes — they are completely safe to drive at 0.07%
Only if they wait one more hour for their BAC to drop further
questions.explanation: The legal BAC limit for drivers 21 and over in Texas is 0.08%. At 0.07%, a driver is technically below the per se limit, but alcohol impairs judgment and reaction time starting with the first drink. A driver can still be charged with DWI at any BAC if their driving is visibly impaired. The safest choice is always a designated driver or rideshare.
questions.reference: Texas Penal Code §49.01; DL-7 Safe Driving Practices

questions.text: What is the BAC limit for drivers under 21 years old in Texas?
choices: Any detectable amount
questions.explanation: Texas has a zero-tolerance policy for underage drinking and driving. Any detectable amount of alcohol in a driver under 21 results in license suspension and other penalties.

questions.text: A friend tells you they feel perfectly fine after one beer and are going to drive. When does alcohol actually begin to impair driving ability?
choices: With the very first drink, even before any noticeable effects
Only after reaching the 0.08% BAC legal limit
After the third drink for most adults
Only when the person feels dizzy or uncoordinated
questions.explanation: Alcohol begins impairing judgment, reaction time, and coordination with the very first drink — long before a person 'feels drunk.' Studies show measurable impairment at BAC levels as low as 0.02%. The 0.08% legal limit marks significant impairment, but any amount of alcohol reduces driving ability. Feeling fine is not a reliable indicator.

questions.text: What is the approximate rate at which the body eliminates alcohol?
choices: One standard drink per hour
One standard drink per 30 minutes
Two standard drinks per hour
Three standard drinks per hour
questions.explanation: The liver metabolizes approximately one standard drink per hour. This rate cannot be increased by coffee, cold showers, or exercise - only time eliminates alcohol from your system.

questions.text: Which abilities are most affected by alcohol consumption?
choices: Judgment, reaction time, and coordination
Hearing and taste
Strength and flexibility
Memory of traffic laws only
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairs the brain functions most critical for driving: making good decisions, reacting quickly to hazards, and coordinating precise movements. These impairments dramatically increase crash risk.

questions.text: After a night out, you realize you've had too much to drink. Your home is only 2 miles away. What is the safest decision?
choices: Call a rideshare, taxi, or designated driver — do not drive any distance
Drive slowly using back roads to avoid traffic
Wait 30 minutes, drink some water, then drive home
Drive home since the distance is very short
questions.explanation: There is no safe distance to drive while impaired. A large percentage of alcohol-related crashes occur within a few miles of the starting point. Coffee, water, and fresh air do not reduce BAC — only time does. The safest choice is always a sober driver, taxi, or rideshare service, regardless of how close your destination is.

questions.text: What is the BAC limit for commercial drivers in Texas?
questions.explanation: Commercial drivers face a stricter 0.04% BAC limit due to the greater responsibility of operating large vehicles. This stricter standard reflects the increased danger posed by impaired commercial vehicle operation.

questions.text: Can prescription medications impair driving ability?
choices: Yes, many prescriptions can cause drowsiness or impairment
No, prescription medications are always safe for driving
Only if taken in excess
Only if mixed with alcohol
questions.explanation: Many prescription medications cause drowsiness, dizziness, or impaired judgment that affects driving ability. Always check medication labels and ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving effects.

questions.text: What happens when alcohol is combined with other drugs?
choices: The combined effect is greater than either substance alone
They cancel each other out
Only the alcohol effect matters
The effects remain the same
questions.explanation: Combining alcohol with other drugs creates multiplied impairment beyond the sum of individual effects. This synergistic effect dramatically increases danger and can be fatal even at lower doses.

questions.text: What are warning signs of drowsy driving?
choices: Yawning, heavy eyelids, drifting from lane, and missing exits
Slight hunger and thirst
Needing to adjust the radio
Feeling energetic but bored
questions.explanation: These physical and behavioral signs indicate dangerous fatigue levels. If you experience any of these symptoms, you should stop driving immediately and rest.

questions.text: How often should you take breaks on a long trip?
choices: Every 2 hours or 100 miles
Every 4 hours or 200 miles
Every 30 minutes
Only when you feel tired
questions.explanation: Regular breaks every 2 hours or 100 miles prevent fatigue from building to dangerous levels. Taking breaks before you feel tired is more effective than waiting until fatigue sets in.

questions.text: During a long drive, you find yourself yawning repeatedly, drifting between lanes, and having trouble keeping your eyes open. You roll down the window and turn up the radio. Are you now safe to continue driving?
choices: No — the only effective remedy for drowsiness is actual sleep
Yes — fresh air and music are proven to restore alertness
Yes — as long as you also drink coffee within 15 minutes
Yes — but only if you take a 5-minute stretching break first
questions.explanation: Fresh air, loud music, and coffee may provide a brief illusion of alertness but do not address the underlying sleep deficit. Drowsy driving impairs reaction time and judgment similarly to alcohol. The only effective countermeasure is pulling over to a safe location and sleeping for at least 15–20 minutes.

questions.text: How long should a power nap be if you're drowsy while driving?
choices: 15-20 minutes
5 minutes
45 minutes
2 hours
questions.explanation: A 15-20 minute power nap can temporarily restore alertness without entering deep sleep that causes grogginess. However, this is only a temporary solution - you still need proper sleep.

questions.text: Can over-the-counter medications impair driving?
choices: Yes, many cause drowsiness or reduced alertness
No, over-the-counter medications are always safe
Only if you take more than directed
Only cold medications can impair driving
questions.explanation: Many over-the-counter medications, especially antihistamines and cold remedies, cause drowsiness or reduced reaction time. Always read labels and choose non-drowsy formulations when available.

questions.text: Why is drowsy driving as dangerous as drunk driving?
choices: It impairs reaction time, judgment, and can cause microsleeps
It only affects reaction time slightly
It's actually less dangerous than drunk driving
It only affects vision
questions.explanation: Severe drowsiness impairs driving abilities as much as alcohol intoxication. Microsleeps, where you briefly lose consciousness for seconds, mean you're driving blind and completely unable to react.

questions.text: What should you do if you start feeling drowsy while driving?
choices: Find a safe place to pull over and rest or sleep
Open the windows and continue
Turn up the radio and keep driving
Drink an energy drink and continue
questions.explanation: Once drowsiness sets in, temporary measures like fresh air or caffeine are unreliable. The only safe response is to stop driving and rest or sleep until you're fully alert.

questions.text: Which illegal drugs can impair driving ability?
choices: All illegal drugs can impair driving
Only marijuana affects driving
Only stimulants affect driving
Illegal drugs don't affect driving as much as alcohol
questions.explanation: Every illegal drug affects brain function in ways that impair driving ability. Whether depressants, stimulants, or hallucinogens, all illegal drugs compromise the skills needed for safe driving.

questions.text: What should you check before taking any medication and driving?
choices: Read labels and ask your doctor or pharmacist about driving effects
Only check if it's a new medication
Just see how you feel after taking it
Check only if it's a prescription medication
questions.explanation: Medication labels and professional advice help you understand potential impairment effects before you drive. Waiting to see how you feel puts you on the road already impaired.

questions.text: What is the greatest danger of driving after drinking small amounts of alcohol?
choices: Impaired judgment may lead to poor decisions
You'll get a ticket
Your vision becomes blurry
You'll drive too slowly
questions.explanation: Alcohol impairs judgment first, often before physical impairments are obvious. Poor judgment leads to risky decisions like speeding, tailgating, or attempting maneuvers you wouldn't try sober.

questions.text: What time of day are you most at risk for drowsy driving?
choices: Late night and early morning hours, especially 2-6 AM
During rush hour
Mid-afternoon only
Evening hours before dinner
questions.explanation: Your body's natural sleep-wake cycle makes you most drowsy during typical sleeping hours, especially 2-6 AM. Many drowsy driving crashes occur during these hours when alertness is naturally lowest.

questions.text: Rain begins falling heavily as you drive on the highway. The road surface quickly becomes wet. What combination of actions should you take?
choices: Reduce speed, increase following distance, and turn on headlights
Maintain speed but turn on windshield wipers
Speed up to get through the rain faster and reduce exposure
Move to the left lane where water accumulates less
questions.explanation: Rain reduces both traction and visibility. Reducing speed lowers your hydroplaning risk. Increasing following distance gives you more stopping room on slippery pavement. Headlights make you visible to other drivers. The first few minutes of rain are especially dangerous because oil on the road surface mixes with water, creating the slickest conditions.

questions.text: Why are roads most slippery during the first few minutes of rain?
choices: Rain mixes with oil and dust to create a slick film
Rainwater alone is very slippery
Tires don't work well when first wet
Road surface expands when wet
questions.explanation: Accumulated oil, grease, and dust on dry roads mix with initial rain to create an extremely slippery surface. After heavier rain washes this away, traction improves somewhat.

questions.text: How much should you increase your following distance in rain?
choices: Double it to at least 6 seconds
Add 1 second to make it 4 seconds
Keep it at 3 seconds
Triple it to 9 seconds
questions.explanation: Wet roads double your stopping distance, requiring doubled following time. Six seconds provides the space needed to stop safely when traction is reduced by wet pavement.

questions.text: What is hydroplaning?
choices: When tires lose contact with the road due to water
When wipers don't clear water fast enough
When water gets in the engine
When rain reduces visibility
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs when water builds up faster than tires can push it aside, causing tires to ride on a water film. This eliminates traction and control.

questions.text: What should you do if your vehicle starts hydroplaning?
choices: Ease off the gas and steer straight until you regain traction
Brake hard immediately
Accelerate to power through
Turn the steering wheel sharply
questions.explanation: When hydroplaning, braking or sharp steering can cause loss of control when traction returns. Easing off the gas and steering straight lets the vehicle slow naturally and regain traction smoothly.

questions.text: What type of headlights should you use in fog?
choices: Low beams
High beams
Parking lights
No lights
questions.explanation: Low beams illuminate the road without reflecting back from fog. High beams reflect off fog particles, creating glare that actually reduces visibility.

questions.text: You encounter dense fog while driving. Visibility drops to about 200 feet. What is the correct combination of actions?
choices: Slow down, use low-beam headlights, and increase following distance significantly
Turn on high-beam headlights and maintain your speed
Follow the taillights of the car ahead as closely as possible for guidance
Pull over and wait only if visibility drops below 50 feet
questions.explanation: In fog, use low beams — high beams reflect off water droplets and actually reduce your visibility. Slow down so you can stop within the distance you can see. Increase following distance because the car ahead may brake suddenly. Following taillights too closely creates a chain-reaction crash risk if the lead vehicle stops.

questions.text: How should you adjust your speed on icy roads?
choices: Reduce speed drastically and increase following distance to 9+ seconds
Reduce speed by 5-10 mph
Maintain normal speed with winter tires
Slow down only on curves
questions.explanation: Ice eliminates most tire traction, requiring drastically reduced speeds and greatly increased following distances. Even small inputs can cause loss of control on ice.

questions.text: What is the best technique for driving on ice or snow?
choices: Use gentle, smooth steering and braking inputs
Brake and steer sharply to maintain control
Accelerate hard to power through
Use cruise control to maintain steady speed
questions.explanation: Ice and snow provide minimal traction. Gentle inputs work within the limited available traction, while sudden movements break traction and cause loss of control.

questions.text: When must you use headlights in Texas?
choices: From 30 minutes after sunset to 30 minutes before sunrise
From sunset to sunrise
Only when you can't see clearly
Whenever it's raining
questions.explanation: Texas law requires headlights from 30 minutes after sunset to 30 minutes before sunrise. This ensures visibility during twilight hours when light is poor but not completely dark.

questions.text: When should you use high beams, and when should you dim them?
choices: Use high beams in rural areas, dim within 500 feet of oncoming traffic
Use high beams everywhere except in cities
Dim high beams within 1000 feet of oncoming traffic
Never use high beams
questions.explanation: High beams improve visibility in dark, rural areas but must be dimmed within 500 feet of oncoming traffic to avoid blinding other drivers and causing crashes.

questions.text: Why should you reduce speed when driving at night?
choices: Your headlights don't illuminate as far as you can see during the day
There's always more traffic at night
Speed limits are lower at night
Your reaction time is slower at night
questions.explanation: Even high beams illuminate only a limited distance ahead. Driving at daytime speeds at night can mean you're overdriving your headlights and unable to stop for hazards you see.

questions.text: What additional hazards should you watch for at night?
choices: Pedestrians, cyclists, and animals that are harder to see
Higher speed limits
More traffic
Better visibility
questions.explanation: Darkness makes pedestrians, cyclists, and animals much harder to see, yet they're often more present at night. Extra vigilance compensates for reduced visibility of these hazards.

questions.text: What should you do when experiencing sun glare?
choices: Use sun visor, wear sunglasses, and slow down
Speed up to get through it quickly
Close your eyes briefly
Look directly at the sun to adjust your eyes
questions.explanation: Sun glare can temporarily blind drivers. Using visors and sunglasses helps, but slowing down is essential since you may not see hazards until very close.

questions.text: What factors contribute to hydroplaning?
choices: Speed, tire tread depth, and water depth on the road
Only vehicle speed
Only tire pressure
Only the type of road surface
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning risk increases with higher speeds, worn tire treads that can't channel water away, and deeper standing water. All three factors work together to determine risk.

questions.text: When should you use headlights during rain in Texas?
choices: Anytime you need windshield wipers
Only at night
Only in heavy rain
Headlights aren't required in rain
questions.explanation: Texas law requires headlights when using windshield wipers. This improves your visibility of the road and helps other drivers see your vehicle in reduced visibility conditions.

questions.text: Why is black ice particularly dangerous?
choices: It's nearly invisible on the road surface
It's thicker than regular ice
It only forms on highways
It's actually less slippery than white ice
questions.explanation: Black ice is transparent, allowing the black pavement to show through, making it nearly invisible to drivers. This invisibility means drivers don't slow down or prepare for the ice.

questions.text: What should you avoid during rain to prevent hydroplaning?
choices: Sudden braking or steering and high speeds
Using windshield wipers
Turning on headlights
Driving in the right lane
questions.explanation: Sudden movements and high speeds increase hydroplaning risk. Smooth, gradual inputs and moderate speeds keep tires in contact with the road despite water on the surface.

questions.text: Where is ice most likely to form on roads?
choices: On bridges, overpasses, and shaded areas
In direct sunlight
In the center lanes only
On well-traveled roads
questions.explanation: Bridges and overpasses freeze first because cold air circulates above and below, cooling them faster. Shaded areas stay cold longer, allowing ice to persist after sunny areas thaw.

questions.text: What is the main purpose of windshield wipers?
choices: To maintain clear visibility through the windshield
To clean bugs off the windshield
To cool the windshield
To alert other drivers of your presence
questions.explanation: Windshield wipers maintain visibility by removing rain, snow, and debris from your line of sight. Clear visibility is essential for seeing hazards and reacting appropriately.

questions.text: You check your tires and the tread depth measures 1/32 of an inch. Is this tire safe and legal to drive on in Texas?
choices: No — Texas requires a minimum tread depth of 2/32 of an inch
Yes — 1/32 of an inch meets the Texas minimum standard
It depends on whether the tires are on the front or rear axle
Yes, as long as there are no visible cords or wires
questions.explanation: Texas requires a minimum tire tread depth of 2/32 of an inch (approximately 1.6 mm). At 1/32 inch, your tires are below the legal limit and dangerously worn. Tread channels water away from the tire's contact patch — without adequate tread, hydroplaning risk increases dramatically, and braking distance on wet roads can double or triple.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §547.101; DL-7 Safe Driving Practices

questions.text: How can you check tire tread depth using a penny?
choices: Insert penny with Lincoln's head down; if you see his full head, tires are worn
Insert penny with Lincoln's head up; if you see his feet, tires are worn
Insert penny sideways between treads
Place penny flat on the tire surface
questions.explanation: The penny test uses Lincoln's head as a gauge. If his entire head is visible when inserted upside down into tread grooves, the tread is worn to unsafe levels and tires should be replaced.

questions.text: How often should you check tire pressure?
choices: At least once a month
Once a year
Only when tires look low
Every time you get gas
questions.explanation: Tire pressure changes with temperature and slowly decreases over time. Monthly checks ensure proper pressure, which affects handling, tire wear, fuel economy, and safety.

questions.text: What are signs that your brakes need service?
choices: Grinding noise, pulling to one side, or soft brake pedal
Brakes work perfectly as always
Slight squeaking when first starting to drive
Firm brake pedal with no noise
questions.explanation: Grinding indicates worn brake pads damaging rotors, pulling suggests uneven brake wear, and soft pedal indicates fluid or system problems. All require immediate service to maintain safe stopping ability.

questions.text: Why is it important to keep all vehicle lights working?
choices: They help you see and help others see you
They're required only for inspection
They only matter at night
They don't affect safety
questions.explanation: Headlights illuminate the road ahead, while brake lights and turn signals communicate your intentions to other drivers. Non-working lights create hazards for you and others.

questions.text: When should you adjust your mirrors?
choices: Before you start driving
While driving in traffic
Only when changing lanes
Once a month
questions.explanation: Mirrors should be adjusted before driving to provide the best view of surrounding traffic. Adjusting while driving diverts attention from the road and creates danger.

questions.text: What should you do if your windshield wipers are leaving streaks or missing spots?
choices: Replace the wiper blades
Use more washer fluid
Increase wiper speed
Clean the windshield more often
questions.explanation: Streaking and missed spots indicate worn wiper blades that no longer make proper contact. Worn blades reduce visibility in rain, so replacement is necessary for safety.

questions.text: How often should tires be rotated?
choices: Every 5,000-7,500 miles
Once a year regardless of mileage
Every 15,000 miles
Only when you notice uneven wear
questions.explanation: Regular rotation every 5,000-7,500 miles promotes even wear across all tires, extending tire life and maintaining consistent traction. Waiting until wear is visible means the damage is already done.

questions.text: Why should you never ignore dashboard warning lights?
choices: They indicate problems that could affect vehicle safety or cause damage
They're just reminders for service
They usually turn off on their own
They only matter for newer vehicles
questions.explanation: Warning lights alert you to problems affecting safety, performance, or component longevity. Ignoring them can lead to breakdowns, accidents, or expensive repairs that could have been prevented.

questions.text: What fluids should be checked regularly in your vehicle?
choices: Engine oil, coolant, brake fluid, power steering fluid, and windshield washer fluid
Only engine oil
Only windshield washer fluid
No fluids need regular checking
questions.explanation: Each fluid serves critical functions for safe operation. Low levels can lead to engine damage, overheating, brake failure, steering problems, or reduced visibility - all serious safety issues.

questions.text: What can happen if you drive on severely worn tires?
choices: Increased risk of blowouts, hydroplaning, and reduced traction
Better fuel economy
Smoother ride
No significant effect
questions.explanation: Worn tires have less rubber to absorb stress, increasing blowout risk, and shallow treads can't channel water away, causing hydroplaning. Both situations drastically increase crash risk.

questions.text: What should you check on tires besides tread depth?
choices: Pressure, uneven wear patterns, and sidewall damage
Only the color
Only the brand
Only the age based on the manufacturer date
questions.explanation: Proper pressure affects handling and wear, uneven wear indicates alignment or suspension problems, and sidewall damage can cause sudden failure. All factors affect tire safety beyond just tread depth.

questions.text: Why should you keep your windshield clean both inside and out?
choices: To maintain maximum visibility in all conditions
To improve vehicle appearance
To prevent insurance issues
Only the outside needs cleaning
questions.explanation: Inside film and outside dirt both reduce visibility, especially at night or in bright sun when glare is magnified. Clean glass provides the clearest view for identifying hazards.

questions.text: What is the main benefit of regular vehicle maintenance?
choices: Prevents breakdowns and ensures all safety systems work properly
Improves vehicle resale value
Satisfies insurance requirements
Makes the vehicle look newer
questions.explanation: Regular maintenance catches problems before they cause breakdowns or accidents. Well-maintained brakes, tires, lights, and other systems provide the reliability you need for safe operation.

questions.text: What is the purpose of checking tire pressure with a gauge rather than visual inspection?
choices: Tires can be significantly under-inflated without looking flat
Visual inspection is actually more accurate
Gauges are only needed for new tires
Tire pressure doesn't affect safety
questions.explanation: Modern radial tires can be dangerously under-inflated yet appear normal visually. Only a pressure gauge provides accurate measurement to ensure proper inflation for safety and performance.

questions.text: Who must wear seatbelts in Texas?
choices: All vehicle occupants
Only the driver
Only front seat passengers
Only children under 12
questions.explanation: Texas law requires all vehicle occupants to wear seatbelts. Unbelted passengers become projectiles in crashes, endangering themselves and others in the vehicle.

questions.text: How much do seatbelts reduce the risk of death in a crash?
choices: By about 45%
By about 10%
By about 75%
By about 90%
questions.explanation: Seatbelts reduce death risk by approximately 45% and serious injury risk by 50%. They keep occupants in the vehicle and positioned for airbag protection during crashes.

questions.text: How should you wear your seatbelt correctly?
choices: Lap belt across hips, shoulder belt across chest and shoulder
Both straps loose and comfortable
Shoulder belt under your arm
Lap belt across stomach
questions.explanation: Proper seatbelt positioning distributes crash forces across strong body parts. Lap belts across hips engage pelvis bones, shoulder belts across chest spread forces across the ribcage and collarbone.

questions.text: Until what age or height must children use booster seats in Texas?
