choices: Age 8 or 4 feet 9 inches tall
Age 6 or 4 feet tall
Age 10 or 5 feet tall
Age 12 or 5 feet 5 inches tall
questions.explanation: Texas law requires booster seats until children are 8 years old or reach 4 feet 9 inches in height. Boosters position adult seatbelts correctly on smaller bodies for maximum protection.

questions.text: Where is the safest place for children under 13 to ride?
choices: In the back seat
In the front passenger seat
In the front seat with airbag turned off
Anywhere with a seatbelt
questions.explanation: The back seat is safest for children under 13 because it's farther from front impact zones and airbag deployment forces. Rear seats provide maximum protection for smaller occupants.

questions.text: How far should you sit from the steering wheel to allow for safe airbag deployment?
choices: At least 10 inches
At least 6 inches
At least 15 inches
Distance doesn't matter
questions.explanation: Ten inches allows the airbag space to inflate before reaching you, cushioning impact rather than striking you. Sitting too close means the inflating airbag itself can cause injury.

questions.text: Do airbags replace the need for seatbelts?
choices: No, airbags are designed to work with seatbelts, not replace them
Yes, airbags provide complete protection alone
Only in newer vehicles
Only for front seat passengers
questions.explanation: Airbags are supplemental restraints that work with seatbelts. Without seatbelts, occupants can strike the airbag too hard or miss it entirely, defeating its protective benefit.

questions.text: How should pregnant women wear seatbelts?
choices: Lap belt below the belly, shoulder belt between breasts
Not wear seatbelts at all
Lap belt across belly, no shoulder belt
Shoulder belt only
questions.explanation: Proper positioning protects both mother and baby. Lap belt below the belly avoids abdominal pressure, while shoulder belt across the chest provides upper body restraint without harming the baby.

questions.text: When should rear-facing child safety seats be turned to face forward?
choices: After age 2 or when child exceeds seat's height/weight limits
After age 1
Immediately after birth
After age 3
questions.explanation: Rear-facing seats protect infants' developing necks and spines better than forward-facing. Children should remain rear-facing past age 2 or until they outgrow the seat's limits for maximum protection.

questions.text: Why should you never place a rear-facing child seat in front of an active airbag?
choices: Airbag deployment can cause severe injury or death to the child
It will damage the airbag
It's uncomfortable for the child
It blocks the driver's view
questions.explanation: Airbags deploy with tremendous force designed for adults. This force can cause fatal injuries when directed at a rear-facing seat, which positions the child's head close to the airbag deployment zone.

questions.text: You are teaching a new driver and they ask why STOP signs have a unique shape. What is the reason for the octagonal design?
choices: So drivers can recognize it instantly — even from behind or when covered in snow
The eight sides represent the eight seconds you should wait before proceeding
It is the only shape that can be seen from all angles equally
Federal law requires red signs to have at least eight sides
questions.explanation: The STOP sign's unique octagonal shape is designed for instant recognition under any condition — at night, from behind, or when obscured by snow or dirt. No other traffic sign uses this shape, making it identifiable by silhouette alone. This design principle has been part of the MUTCD since 1954.

questions.text: You approach an intersection with a yield sign. There is a steady stream of cross traffic. What is required of you?
choices: Slow down and stop if necessary — you must wait for a safe gap before entering
Come to a complete stop regardless of traffic conditions
Merge into traffic at your current speed — cross traffic must adjust
Proceed without slowing if the road ahead appears clear
questions.explanation: A yield sign requires you to slow down and give right-of-way to all vehicles and pedestrians on the intersecting road. If traffic is continuous, you must stop and wait for a safe gap. Unlike a stop sign, you are not required to stop if there is no conflicting traffic, but you must be prepared to do so.

questions.text: What is the shape of a YIELD sign?
choices: Downward-pointing triangle
Upward-pointing triangle
Diamond
Pentagon
questions.explanation: YIELD signs are uniquely shaped as downward-pointing triangles with a red border and white background, making them easily distinguishable from other traffic signs.

questions.text: You are driving on a highway and see a white rectangular sign reading 'SPEED LIMIT 65.' Heavy rain begins falling. Must you still drive at 65 mph?
choices: No — the sign shows the maximum speed for ideal conditions; you must reduce speed for safety
Yes — the posted speed is the legal requirement in all conditions
Only if visibility drops below 100 feet
No — the speed limit automatically drops by 10 mph in rain
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs show the maximum legal speed under ideal conditions. Texas law requires drivers to reduce speed when conditions such as rain, fog, ice, or heavy traffic make the posted limit unsafe. Driving at the posted speed in poor conditions can constitute reckless driving even though you are not exceeding the limit.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.351; DL-7 Traffic Signs

questions.text: What must you do when you see a DO NOT ENTER sign?
choices: Do not proceed in that direction
Proceed with caution
Only commercial vehicles are prohibited
Stop and check for traffic
questions.explanation: DO NOT ENTER signs prohibit entry into a roadway or area, typically marking wrong-way entry points on one-way streets or exit ramps.

questions.text: If you see a WRONG WAY sign, you should:
choices: Immediately pull over safely and turn around
Continue if no traffic is visible
Sound your horn to warn others
Speed up to exit quickly
questions.explanation: A WRONG WAY sign means you are traveling in the wrong direction on a one-way road or ramp. You must safely pull over and turn around immediately to avoid a head-on collision.

questions.text: You approach an intersection and see a sign with a left-turn arrow crossed out by a red circle and slash. You need to reach a business on the left side of the cross street. What should you do?
choices: Proceed past the intersection and find an alternate route — left turns are prohibited here
Turn left carefully since the sign is only advisory
Make a U-turn past the intersection and approach from the other direction
Turn left only if no oncoming traffic is present
questions.explanation: A No Left Turn sign (MUTCD R3-1) is a regulatory sign that legally prohibits left turns at that location. Violating it can result in a traffic citation. The sign is typically placed where left turns create sight-distance problems or dangerous conflicts with oncoming traffic. Find an alternative route such as turning right and circling the block.

questions.text: When you see a NO RIGHT TURN sign at an intersection, you must:
choices: Not turn right at that location
Turn right only after stopping
Turn right only on green
Yield before turning right
questions.explanation: NO RIGHT TURN signs prohibit right turns at that specific location, often due to safety concerns or traffic flow patterns.

questions.text: You are driving on a divided highway and see a No U-Turn sign at a median opening. You just passed your destination. What should you do?
choices: Continue to the next legal turning point — U-turns are prohibited at this location
Make a U-turn if no traffic is coming since the sign is advisory
Make a three-point turn instead, since only U-turns are prohibited
Make the U-turn but yield to oncoming traffic
questions.explanation: No U-Turn signs are regulatory and legally binding. They are placed where U-turns are particularly dangerous — often at median openings with limited sight distance. Continue to the next legal turning point, intersection, or driveway where you can safely reverse direction. A three-point turn at a median opening would be equally dangerous.

questions.text: What does a NO PARKING ANYTIME sign mean?
choices: Parking is never permitted at this location
Parking allowed only for loading
No parking during business hours
Parking allowed on weekends
questions.explanation: NO PARKING ANYTIME signs prohibit parking at all times, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, with no exceptions unless specifically noted.

questions.text: You turn onto a street and immediately notice a One Way sign with an arrow pointing to the right. You need to go left. What must you do?
choices: Do not go left — you must travel only in the direction the arrow indicates
You may go left if you stay in the leftmost lane
You may go left only if no other vehicles are on the street
The sign applies only to commercial vehicles
questions.explanation: One Way signs indicate that all traffic on that street must travel in the direction of the arrow. Driving against a One Way sign means traveling into the path of oncoming traffic, which is extremely dangerous and illegal. If you need to go in the opposite direction, you must find an alternate route using adjacent streets.

questions.text: What does a DO NOT PASS sign indicate?
choices: Passing is prohibited in this zone
Pass only on the right
Pass only when safe
No trucks allowed to pass
questions.explanation: DO NOT PASS signs mark areas where passing is prohibited due to limited visibility or other hazards, and violating this can result in head-on collisions.

questions.text: What does this sign indicate about railroad crossings?
choices: A railroad crossing is ahead
Railroad traffic has priority
Trains run only during daytime
Sound horn before crossing
questions.explanation: The railroad crossing sign warns drivers that train tracks cross the roadway ahead. Always look both ways and be prepared to stop for approaching trains.

questions.text: What does a NO TRUCKS sign typically prohibit?
choices: Commercial vehicles above a certain weight
All pickup trucks
Delivery vehicles at all times
Trucks during daytime only
questions.explanation: NO TRUCKS signs typically prohibit commercial trucks above a specified weight limit from using that road, often to protect residential areas or roads not designed for heavy vehicles.

questions.text: What does a KEEP RIGHT sign require you to do?
choices: Stay to the right of an obstruction or divider
Drive in the right lane only
Pass on the right side
Turn right at the next intersection
questions.explanation: KEEP RIGHT signs direct drivers to pass to the right side of an island, median, or other obstruction in the roadway.

questions.text: What does a LEFT TURN ONLY sign indicate?
choices: Vehicles in this lane must turn left
Left turns are optional
Only left turns are allowed at this intersection
Left lane is for turning only
questions.explanation: LEFT TURN ONLY signs indicate that traffic in the marked lane must turn left and cannot proceed straight or turn right.

questions.text: If you are in a lane marked with a RIGHT TURN ONLY sign, you must:
choices: Turn right from that lane
Merge left before the intersection
Stop before turning
Yield to pedestrians only
questions.explanation: RIGHT TURN ONLY signs indicate that vehicles in that lane are required to turn right and may not go straight or turn left.

questions.text: What is the penalty for parking in a space marked with a HANDICAPPED PARKING sign without proper authorization?
choices: Substantial fine and possible towing
Warning citation only
No penalty if brief
Fine only for commercial vehicles
questions.explanation: Parking in handicapped spaces without proper permits or plates results in substantial fines (typically $500+) and possible vehicle towing in Texas.

questions.text: At a STOP sign, you must stop:
choices: Before the stop line, crosswalk, or intersection
Within 10 feet of the sign
Only if other vehicles are present
Where you can see traffic clearly
questions.explanation: You must come to a complete stop before the stop line, before the crosswalk if present, or before entering the intersection if neither is marked.

questions.text: What color are most regulatory signs?
choices: White background with black or red symbols
Yellow background with black symbols
Green background with white symbols
Blue background with white symbols
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs typically have a white background with black text or symbols, or red symbols for prohibitions. These signs tell you what you must or must not do.

questions.text: If a speed limit sign shows 70 mph, but weather conditions are poor, you should:
choices: Drive slower than the posted limit based on conditions
Maintain exactly 70 mph as posted
Drive 10 mph below the limit
Use hazard lights and maintain speed
questions.explanation: Speed limits indicate the maximum safe speed under ideal conditions. Drivers must reduce speed in rain, fog, ice, or other hazardous conditions.

questions.text: You see a school speed limit sign showing 20 mph with flashing beacons. It is 3:30 PM on a Tuesday. The beacons are not flashing. Must you drive at 20 mph?
choices: Not necessarily — the 20 mph limit applies when the beacons are flashing or during posted times
Yes — school zone speed limits apply 24 hours a day
No — school speed limits only apply before 8 AM
Only if children are physically visible on the sidewalks
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits in Texas apply when the beacons are flashing or during times posted on the sign. If the beacons are off and the current time is outside posted hours, the regular speed limit applies. However, always watch for children — you may be cited for unsafe speed near a school regardless of the posted limit.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.3561; DL-7 Traffic Signs

questions.text: A red circle with a red slash over a black symbol on a white background indicates:
choices: A prohibited action
A required action
A warning of hazard
A guide to services
questions.explanation: The red circle with a diagonal slash is the international prohibition symbol, indicating that the action shown is not permitted.

questions.text: What is the minimum speed you should drive on a road with a 65 mph speed limit in Texas?
choices: There is no minimum unless posted separately
45 mph
55 mph
40 mph
questions.explanation: Unless a separate minimum speed limit is posted, there is no specific minimum speed, but driving unreasonably slow can be unsafe and illegal.

questions.text: Where are you most likely to see a NO PARKING sign?
choices: Near fire hydrants, intersections, or driveways
On residential streets only
Only in commercial zones
On highways and freeways
questions.explanation: NO PARKING signs are placed where parking would create safety hazards or block emergency access, such as near fire hydrants, intersections, and building entrances.

questions.text: Which sign would you expect to see at the entrance ramp to a highway going the wrong direction?
choices: Both DO NOT ENTER and WRONG WAY signs
Only a STOP sign
Only a YIELD sign
A speed limit sign only
questions.explanation: Highway exit ramps typically have both DO NOT ENTER and WRONG WAY signs to prevent wrong-way drivers from entering, using redundancy for safety.

questions.text: A residential street with a speed limit of 30 mph means:
choices: 30 mph is the maximum legal speed
30 mph is recommended but not required
30 mph applies only during daytime
30 mph is for passenger vehicles only
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits are legal maximums that apply at all times unless otherwise specified, and apply to all vehicles unless the sign indicates otherwise.

questions.text: If you encounter both a YIELD sign and a stopped school bus with flashing red lights, which takes priority?
choices: The school bus - you must stop
The YIELD sign - you may proceed with caution
Both equally - stop and yield
Whichever you encounter first
questions.explanation: A school bus with flashing red lights creates an absolute stop requirement that overrides YIELD signs. You must stop until the bus turns off its lights.

questions.text: At an intersection with a STOP sign and a malfunctioning traffic signal, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat it as a four-way stop if multiple approaches have signals
The STOP sign overrides the signal - stop and go
Proceed with caution without stopping
Wait for signal to function before proceeding
questions.explanation: When traffic signals malfunction at an intersection, drivers should treat it as an all-way stop, with vehicles taking turns in order of arrival.

questions.text: What does it mean if a NO PARKING sign has an arrow pointing right?
choices: No parking from the sign onward in that direction
No parking only to the right of the sign
Park on the right side only
Right lane parking prohibited
questions.explanation: Arrows on NO PARKING signs indicate the direction and extent of the parking restriction from that sign location.

questions.text: At a railroad crossing with both signals and a STOP sign, when must you stop?
choices: When signals are flashing or a train is approaching
At all times before crossing
Only if a train is visible
Only during daytime hours
questions.explanation: At railroad crossings with signals, you must stop when lights flash or gates lower. Some crossings also have STOP signs requiring stops regardless of signals.

questions.text: While driving on a rural road, you see a yellow diamond-shaped sign with a curve symbol. What type of sign is this, and what should you do?
choices: It is a warning sign — reduce speed because a curve or hazard is ahead
It is a regulatory sign — you must follow the direction shown
It is a guide sign — it shows the direction to a nearby town
It is a construction sign — slow to the work zone speed limit
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped yellow signs are warning signs that alert drivers to upcoming road conditions, curves, or hazards. They are advisory, not regulatory — meaning they do not set a legal speed — but ignoring them is dangerous. A curve warning often includes an advisory speed plaque below it suggesting a safe speed for the curve.

questions.text: What does a CURVE RIGHT warning sign indicate?
choices: The road curves to the right ahead
Turn right at the next intersection
Right lane curves away
Keep to the right of the curve
questions.explanation: CURVE RIGHT warning signs alert drivers that the roadway ahead curves to the right, allowing them to reduce speed appropriately before entering the curve.

questions.text: When you see a CURVE LEFT sign, you should:
choices: Slow down before entering the curve
Maintain speed through the curve
Shift to the right lane
Accelerate through the curve
questions.explanation: Warning signs for curves indicate you should reduce speed before entering the curve to maintain control, especially if the curve is sharp or visibility is limited.

questions.text: What does a WINDING ROAD sign warn you about?
choices: A series of curves ahead
One sharp curve ahead
Road surface is uneven
Wind gusts are common
questions.explanation: WINDING ROAD signs warn that there are multiple curves ahead in succession, requiring continued vigilance and reduced speed.

questions.text: What does a SIDE ROAD warning sign indicate?
choices: Another road intersects from the side
Stay in your lane
Side road parking available
Exit ramp ahead
questions.explanation: SIDE ROAD signs warn that another road intersects from the left or right, alerting you to watch for vehicles entering from that direction.

questions.text: What type of intersection does a Y-INTERSECTION warning sign indicate?
choices: The road splits into two roads ahead
Three roads meet in a Y-shape
A yield is required
Yellow light ahead
questions.explanation: Y-INTERSECTION signs warn that the road ahead divides into two separate roads, requiring you to choose which direction to take.

questions.text: A T-INTERSECTION warning sign means:
choices: The road ends ahead at a cross street
Three roads meet
Turn only
Traffic light ahead
questions.explanation: T-INTERSECTION signs warn that the road you are on ends ahead at an intersection with a cross street, requiring you to turn left or right.

questions.text: What does a MERGE warning sign indicate?
choices: Traffic from another road is entering your lane
You must merge into another lane
Two lanes become one
Yield to merging traffic
questions.explanation: MERGE signs warn that traffic from another roadway will be entering and merging with your lane, requiring increased awareness and possible speed adjustment.

questions.text: A LANE ENDS MERGE sign indicates:
choices: Your lane will end and you must merge into the adjacent lane
An additional lane is being added
The merge lane is ending
All lanes merge ahead
questions.explanation: LANE ENDS MERGE signs warn that the lane you are in will end soon, requiring you to safely merge into the continuing lane before your lane terminates.

questions.text: What does a HILL warning sign indicate?
choices: A steep grade or hill is ahead
Hill parking rules apply
Trucks must use lower gear
Slow vehicles keep right
questions.explanation: HILL warning signs alert drivers to steep grades ahead, warning them to prepare for reduced visibility over the crest or the need for braking on downhill sections.

questions.text: You are driving at 40 mph and see a yellow diamond sign showing a pedestrian symbol ahead. There is no crosswalk or traffic signal visible yet. What should you do?
choices: Slow down and be alert — pedestrians frequently cross at this location
Maintain speed since there is no crosswalk or signal
Stop and look both ways before continuing
Change lanes to the lane farthest from the sign
questions.explanation: A Pedestrian Crossing warning sign alerts you that pedestrians regularly cross the road ahead — often at a mid-block crosswalk you may not yet see. Reduce speed and watch for pedestrians stepping into the roadway. The crosswalk markings may be ahead of you around a curve or over a hill.

questions.text: A BICYCLE CROSSING warning sign indicates:
choices: Watch for bicycles crossing the roadway
Bicycle lane begins
No bicycles allowed
Bicycle parking ahead
questions.explanation: BICYCLE CROSSING signs warn drivers that bicycles may cross the road at that location, often marking bike paths or trails that cross the roadway.

questions.text: What does a TRUCK CROSSING warning sign indicate?
choices: Large trucks frequently cross or enter the roadway
Truck stop ahead
Trucks only beyond this point
Truck route begins
questions.explanation: TRUCK CROSSING signs warn that large commercial vehicles frequently cross or enter the road, often near industrial areas, quarries, or truck terminals.

questions.text: A FARM EQUIPMENT warning sign is most likely to be found:
choices: In rural areas where slow-moving farm vehicles use the road
Near agricultural supply stores
On farm property only
At farmer's markets
questions.explanation: FARM EQUIPMENT signs warn drivers in rural areas to watch for slow-moving tractors, combines, and other agricultural machinery that may use the roadway.

questions.text: As you drive past houses near an elementary school, you see a yellow-green pentagon-shaped sign showing two children. What does this sign warn you about?
choices: You are near a school — children may be crossing the road
A playground is ahead — slow to 15 mph
School buses stop frequently in this area
A school zone speed camera is active ahead
questions.explanation: The pentagon-shaped school sign (MUTCD S1-1) with the image of two children warns that a school area is ahead and children may be crossing the road. The yellow-green fluorescent color is designed for maximum daytime visibility. Be especially alert during school arrival and dismissal times, and watch for children who may dart into the street unexpectedly.

questions.text: What does a SLIPPERY WHEN WET warning sign mean?
choices: The road surface becomes slippery in wet conditions
No driving allowed when raining
Wet weather is common
Water on roadway ahead
questions.explanation: SLIPPERY WHEN WET signs warn that the road surface has poor traction when wet, requiring drivers to reduce speed and increase following distance in rainy conditions.

questions.text: What does a ROAD CONSTRUCTION warning sign indicate?
choices: Workers and equipment may be on or near the roadway
Road is closed
Construction vehicles only
Detour required
questions.explanation: ROAD CONSTRUCTION signs warn of work zones ahead where workers, equipment, and changed traffic patterns require increased caution and reduced speed.

questions.text: A FLAGGER AHEAD sign warns that:
choices: A person will be directing traffic ahead
Flags mark the road edge
Flagpole in roadway
Flag signals are used
questions.explanation: FLAGGER AHEAD signs warn that a worker will be using a flag or paddle to manually direct traffic through a work zone, and you must obey their signals.

questions.text: What color are warning signs typically?
choices: Yellow or orange with black symbols
Red with white symbols
White with black symbols
Green with white symbols
questions.explanation: Warning signs are typically yellow with black symbols, or orange with black symbols in work zones, making them highly visible and distinct from regulatory signs.

questions.text: When you see a curve warning sign with an advisory speed plaque showing 35 mph:
choices: 35 mph is the recommended safe speed for that curve
35 mph is the legal maximum in the curve
35 mph applies only in wet conditions
35 mph is for trucks only
questions.explanation: Advisory speed plaques below curve signs show the recommended maximum safe speed for that curve under ideal conditions, though not a legal speed limit.

questions.text: A chevron sign in a curve indicates:
choices: The direction and sharpness of the curve
Speed limit in the curve
One-way traffic through curve
Curve ends ahead
questions.explanation: Chevron signs with arrows are placed on the outside of sharp curves to guide drivers through the curve and indicate its direction, especially at night.

questions.text: If you see multiple CURVE warning signs in succession, this indicates:
choices: Several curves following one another
An extremely sharp single curve
Alternative route available
Curve under construction
questions.explanation: Multiple curve warning signs placed sequentially indicate a series of curves ahead, each requiring careful speed management and attention.

questions.text: At a T-intersection, if there is no warning sign, who typically has the right-of-way?
choices: Traffic on the through road (cross street)
Traffic on the terminating road
First vehicle to arrive
Larger vehicle
questions.explanation: At T-intersections, traffic on the through road (the road that continues) generally has the right-of-way over traffic on the terminating road, though signs or signals may specify otherwise.

questions.text: A MERGE sign is different from a YIELD sign because:
choices: MERGE warns of entering traffic; YIELD requires you to give way
They mean the same thing
MERGE requires stopping; YIELD does not
YIELD is only at intersections
questions.explanation: MERGE signs warn that traffic streams are combining and careful lane positioning is needed, while YIELD signs require you to give the right-of-way to others.

questions.text: When a PEDESTRIAN CROSSING sign is accompanied by a school crossing symbol, what does this indicate?
choices: School children cross at this location
Both school and public crossings are present
The sign is in a school zone
Crossing guards are present
questions.explanation: When pedestrian crossing signs include school-related symbols, they specifically warn that school-age children cross at that location, requiring extra vigilance during school hours.

questions.text: In a work zone with both a posted speed limit and a ROAD CONSTRUCTION sign, which speed should you follow?
choices: The posted work zone speed limit
The regular speed limit
Either, as they are the same
Slower of the two
questions.explanation: Work zones often have reduced speed limits posted on signs that override regular speed limits. Always follow the work zone speed limit when present.

questions.text: A warning sign with a downward-pointing arrow symbol typically indicates:
choices: Steep downgrade ahead
Arrow direction to follow
Lower speed required
Downward exit ramp
questions.explanation: Downward-pointing arrows on hill warning signs indicate steep downgrades where trucks may need to use lower gears and all vehicles should prepare for increased braking needs.

questions.text: Why are curve warning signs important in rural areas?
choices: Higher speeds make curves more dangerous
Curves are sharper in rural areas
There are more curves in rural areas
Rural drivers are less experienced
questions.explanation: Rural roads often have higher speed limits, and curves at high speeds require advance warning so drivers can reduce speed appropriately before entering the curve.

questions.text: If a LANE ENDS MERGE sign shows the right lane ending, and both lanes are full, who should yield?
choices: Traffic in the ending lane should yield
Traffic in the continuing lane should yield
Vehicles should alternate like a zipper
Larger vehicles have priority
questions.explanation: When a lane ends, traffic in the ending lane is responsible for safely merging into the continuing lane, yielding to traffic already in that lane.

questions.text: What does an Interstate highway sign look like?
choices: Red, white, and blue shield shape
Green rectangle
Yellow diamond
White circle
questions.explanation: Interstate highway signs are distinctive red, white, and blue shields that display the Interstate route number, making them easily recognizable across the United States.

questions.text: What does Interstate 10 signage indicate?
choices: You are on a major cross-country highway
The speed limit is 10 mph
10 miles to destination
Highway has 10 lanes
questions.explanation: Interstate 10 is a major east-west transcontinental highway running from California to Florida, with significant portions running through Texas.

questions.text: What shape is a US Route highway sign?
choices: White shield with black numbers
Red and blue shield
Green rectangle
Yellow diamond
questions.explanation: US Route signs are white shields with black route numbers, distinguishing them from Interstate signs and state route markers.

questions.text: What does a State Route marker indicate in Texas?
choices: A state-maintained highway route
County road number
City street designation
Private road identifier
questions.explanation: State Route markers designate highways maintained by the state of Texas, distinct from Interstate and US highways.

questions.text: What does an EXIT sign on a highway indicate?
choices: An upcoming exit ramp to leave the highway
Emergency exit only
Exit the vehicle
Express lane exit
questions.explanation: EXIT signs mark exit ramps that allow drivers to leave the highway, typically showing the exit number and destination.

questions.text: What information does a DISTANCE sign typically provide?
choices: Miles to upcoming cities or destinations
Distance to next exit
Speed distance requirement
Safe following distance
questions.explanation: DISTANCE signs display the mileage to upcoming cities or destinations along the route, helping drivers plan their travel and exits.

questions.text: What does a REST AREA sign indicate?
choices: A facility with parking and restrooms is ahead
Rest required for tired drivers
Area for resting vehicles
Residential area ahead
questions.explanation: REST AREA signs direct drivers to highway facilities offering parking, restrooms, and sometimes picnic areas for travelers to take breaks.

questions.text: What does a HOSPITAL sign indicate?
choices: Medical facility location and direction
Hospital zone - quiet required
Emergency vehicles only
Medical personnel parking
questions.explanation: HOSPITAL signs with the H symbol direct drivers to nearby medical facilities, important for emergencies and wayfinding.

questions.text: What does a GAS STATION service sign indicate?
choices: Fuel services available at next exit or ahead
Gas leak area
Gas-powered vehicles only
Gas station parking only
questions.explanation: GAS STATION service signs inform drivers where fuel is available, typically indicating availability at upcoming exits on highways.

questions.text: What color are most guide and information signs?
choices: Green with white lettering
Blue with white lettering
White with black lettering
Brown with white lettering
questions.explanation: Guide signs for highways and destinations are typically green with white lettering, making them easily distinguishable from regulatory and warning signs.

questions.text: What is the difference between even and odd Interstate numbers?
choices: Even numbers run east-west; odd numbers run north-south
Even numbers are longer routes
Odd numbers are in eastern states
Even numbers are toll roads
questions.explanation: The Interstate numbering system uses even numbers for east-west routes and odd numbers for north-south routes, helping with navigation across the country.

questions.text: Blue service signs typically indicate:
choices: Food, gas, lodging, and other services
Emergency services only
Public services like libraries
Business districts
questions.explanation: Blue service signs direct drivers to traveler services such as gas stations, restaurants, hotels, and hospitals near highway exits.

questions.text: What do brown signs typically indicate?
choices: Parks, recreational areas, and points of interest
Construction zones
Private property
Unpaved roads
questions.explanation: Brown signs mark recreational and cultural interest areas such as parks, historic sites, scenic areas, and tourist attractions.

questions.text: Mile marker signs help drivers by:
choices: Providing location reference for navigation and emergencies
Showing speed limits per mile
Indicating miles to destination
Marking speed enforcement zones
questions.explanation: Mile markers show your location along a highway, helping with navigation and allowing you to report your exact location in emergencies.

questions.text: An EXIT ONLY lane sign means:
choices: This lane must exit and cannot continue on the highway
Only use this lane for exiting
Exit is optional from this lane
Entrance prohibited in this lane
questions.explanation: EXIT ONLY signs indicate that the lane you are in will exit the highway and does not continue, requiring you to merge if you want to stay on the highway.

questions.text: A three-digit Interstate number starting with an even digit (like I-210) typically indicates:
choices: A loop or beltway around a city
A spur route into a city
A business route
A temporary detour
questions.explanation: Three-digit Interstate numbers beginning with even digits typically indicate loop routes or beltways that both begin and end at the parent Interstate.

questions.text: A three-digit Interstate number starting with an odd digit (like I-335) typically indicates:
choices: A spur route connecting to a city
A complete loop around a city
An alternate route
A scenic route
questions.explanation: Three-digit Interstate numbers beginning with odd digits typically indicate spur routes that connect to a city or area but do not return to the parent Interstate.

questions.text: What should you do when you see a REST AREA sign and you feel drowsy?
choices: Exit and take a break to rest before continuing
Increase speed to reach destination faster
Open windows and continue driving
Drink coffee and keep driving
questions.explanation: Drowsy driving is extremely dangerous. When you feel tired, the safest action is to exit at a rest area and take a break, nap, or stop for the night.

questions.text: When following Interstate 35 through Texas, you are traveling:
choices: Generally north-south through central Texas
East-west across northern Texas
Along the Texas coast
Through west Texas
questions.explanation: Interstate 35 is a major north-south route running through central Texas from Laredo to the Oklahoma border, passing through San Antonio, Austin, and Dallas-Fort Worth.

questions.text: If you miss your intended highway exit, you should:
choices: Continue to the next exit and backtrack safely
Stop and reverse on the shoulder
Cross multiple lanes quickly to exit
Make a U-turn on the highway
questions.explanation: Missing an exit is inconvenient but not dangerous. Never stop, reverse, or make unsafe maneuvers on a highway. Always continue to the next exit and find a safe alternate route.

questions.text: What does a KEEP RIGHT sign in the center of a roadway indicate?
choices: Traffic must pass to the right of an island or obstruction
Slower traffic keep right
Right lane only
Right turn ahead
questions.explanation: KEEP RIGHT signs placed on or near islands and obstructions direct drivers to pass on the right side of that object.

questions.text: A KEEP LEFT sign would typically appear:
choices: On an island or median to direct traffic left
In the left lane only
Before left turns
At one-way streets
questions.explanation: KEEP LEFT signs are placed on islands or obstructions to direct traffic to pass on the left side, similar to KEEP RIGHT signs but for the opposite direction.

questions.text: When approaching a curve with both a warning sign and chevron markers, you should:
choices: Follow the chevron arrows while maintaining safe speed
Ignore the chevrons and follow the center line
Accelerate through the curve
Stop before the curve
questions.explanation: Chevron markers provide visual guidance through curves, especially at night. Follow the direction shown by the chevrons while maintaining a safe speed for the curve.

questions.text: If regulatory and warning signs give conflicting information, which should you follow?
choices: Regulatory signs, as they indicate legal requirements
Warning signs, as they indicate hazards
The more restrictive of the two
Neither, use your judgment
questions.explanation: Regulatory signs indicate legal requirements that must be followed. Warning signs provide important safety information but regulatory signs take precedence for legal compliance.

questions.text: A sign showing a truck on a downgrade typically warns:
choices: Steep hill where trucks may have brake problems
Truck parking area
Truck weighing station
Truck loading zone
questions.explanation: Signs showing trucks on downgrades warn of steep hills where large trucks may experience brake failure or reduced braking ability, requiring extra caution.

questions.text: When warning signs are placed on both sides of the road, this typically indicates:
choices: The hazard affects both directions of travel
Two-way traffic ahead
Divided highway
Passing is prohibited
questions.explanation: When identical warning signs appear on both sides of the road, the hazard or condition they warn about typically affects traffic in both directions.

questions.text: A pennant-shaped sign indicates:
choices: No passing zone begins
Sharp curve ahead
Construction zone
Reduced speed ahead
questions.explanation: Pennant-shaped signs are uniquely used to mark the beginning of no-passing zones, positioned on the left side of the road where passing would occur.

questions.text: If you see a STOP sign with a white border versus one without, what is the difference?
choices: No functional difference; both require a complete stop
White border means four-way stop
White border is optional stop
White border indicates school zone
questions.explanation: Older STOP signs sometimes have white borders, but this is only a design variation. All STOP signs require a complete stop regardless of border presence.

questions.text: What does a sign with a circular red symbol typically indicate?
choices: A prohibition or restriction
A required action
A warning
A guide
questions.explanation: Red circles on signs typically indicate prohibitions or restrictions, such as no parking, no turns, or no entry, following international sign conventions.

questions.text: At night, sign colors appear differently. Which sign color is most visible at night?
choices: All are equally visible due to reflective materials
Yellow signs
White signs
Green signs
questions.explanation: Modern traffic signs use reflective materials that make all colors highly visible at night when illuminated by headlights, maintaining sign recognition regardless of color.

questions.text: Why are STOP signs red?
choices: Red is the most attention-getting color indicating danger
Red is easiest to see
Red matches brake lights
Tradition only
questions.explanation: Red is universally recognized as the color of danger and prohibition, making it the appropriate choice for STOP signs which indicate a critical safety requirement.

questions.text: A damaged or faded sign that is unreadable means:
choices: Exercise extra caution and follow general traffic rules
The sign can be ignored
Speed limits no longer apply
Traffic rules are suspended
questions.explanation: Damaged signs do not negate traffic rules. If you cannot read a sign, exercise extra caution and follow general traffic laws and common sense for that situation.

questions.text: When two different speed limit signs are visible with different numbers, which applies?
choices: The lower speed limit closest to you
The higher speed limit
The average of both
Either one
questions.explanation: When multiple speed limits are visible, follow the most recent sign you have passed, which typically shows the lower speed as you enter a reduced-speed zone.

questions.text: Why are some warning signs larger than others?
choices: Larger signs are used where higher speeds require more advance warning
Larger signs indicate more severe hazards
Sign size is random
Larger signs are newer
questions.explanation: Warning sign size is determined by road speed and design standards. Higher-speed roads require larger signs for visibility at greater distances.

questions.text: What should you do if a traffic light and a STOP sign are both present at an intersection?
choices: Obey the traffic light when functioning; treat as stop when not
Always stop for the sign
The sign overrides the light
Stop for both
questions.explanation: When both a traffic signal and STOP sign are present, follow the traffic signal when it is functioning. If the signal is out, treat the intersection as an all-way stop.

questions.text: Work zone signs are typically what color?
choices: Orange with black symbols
Yellow with black symbols
Red with white symbols
White with black symbols
questions.explanation: Work zone and construction signs use orange backgrounds with black symbols to distinguish them from permanent warning signs and increase visibility in work areas.

questions.text: At an intersection with a YIELD sign and a vehicle approaching from your right, you should:
choices: Yield to the vehicle on your right
Proceed if you arrived first
Both vehicles should stop
Larger vehicle has priority
questions.explanation: YIELD signs require you to give the right-of-way to other vehicles. When in doubt, vehicles on your right generally have priority at intersections.

questions.text: A sign reading 'ROAD CLOSED' means:
choices: Do not enter; the road is impassable or dangerous
Road closed to trucks only
Proceed with extreme caution
Closed during certain hours
questions.explanation: ROAD CLOSED signs indicate the road is impassable or dangerous due to construction, flooding, or other hazards. Do not proceed beyond this sign.

questions.text: What does 'REDUCED SPEED AHEAD' mean?
choices: The speed limit will decrease soon
Slow down immediately
Speed reduction recommended
Construction ahead
questions.explanation: REDUCED SPEED AHEAD warning signs alert you that a lower speed limit sign is coming up, giving you time to slow down before reaching the new limit.

questions.text: A 'DETOUR' sign indicates:
choices: Follow alternate route due to road closure
Optional scenic route
Truck route available
Parking area ahead
questions.explanation: DETOUR signs direct drivers to an alternate route when the regular road is closed or impassable, with additional signs guiding you back to your original route.

questions.text: What does a 'CROSS TRAFFIC DOES NOT STOP' sign mean?
choices: You have a stop sign but cross traffic does not
Cross traffic must stop
Four-way stop ahead
No cross traffic present
questions.explanation: This sign warns that while you must stop, vehicles on the cross street do not have stop signs and will continue through the intersection.

questions.text: A black and white circular sign with 'RR' and an 'X' indicates:
choices: Railroad crossing ahead
Restricted road
Rural route
Repair required
questions.explanation: The circular railroad crossing sign (crossbuck) warns that train tracks cross the road, requiring you to look both ways and be prepared to stop for trains.

questions.text: If you encounter a sign you do not recognize or understand, you should:
choices: Proceed with caution and research the sign later
Stop immediately
Ignore it and continue
Turn around
questions.explanation: Unknown signs should prompt increased caution. Proceed carefully, observe traffic behavior, and look up the sign meaning when safe to do so.

questions.text: Why do some areas have multiple speed limit signs close together?
choices: To ensure visibility after passing points and for emphasis
Speed limits change frequently
Different limits for different lanes
Signs are redundant
questions.explanation: Multiple speed limit signs are placed to ensure drivers entering from side streets or parking lots see the limit, and to reinforce compliance in critical areas.

questions.text: A sign showing two arrows pointing in opposite directions indicates:
choices: Two-way traffic or divided highway ends
Two lanes merge
Two exits ahead
Turn either direction
questions.explanation: Signs with opposing arrows warn that a one-way or divided highway is ending and you will encounter two-way traffic, requiring extra caution.

questions.text: What does an 'EMERGENCY PARKING ONLY' sign mean?
choices: Park here only for vehicle emergencies
Emergency vehicles may park here
Parking available 24/7
Short-term parking allowed
questions.explanation: EMERGENCY PARKING ONLY areas are designated for vehicles experiencing mechanical problems or other emergencies, not for regular parking or rest stops.

questions.text: A 'BRIDGE ICES BEFORE ROAD' sign warns that:
choices: Bridge surfaces freeze before regular roadway in cold weather
Bridge is always icy
Ice on bridge ahead
Bridge closed in winter
questions.explanation: Bridges freeze before regular road surfaces because cold air circulates above and below them, making them more hazardous in near-freezing temperatures.

questions.text: What is the purpose of a 'PHOTO ENFORCED' sign below a traffic signal?
choices: Cameras monitor and ticket traffic violations
Photography prohibited
Surveillance area
Photo ID required
questions.explanation: PHOTO ENFORCED signs warn that cameras monitor the intersection and automatically photograph vehicles running red lights or violating other traffic laws.

questions.text: If a speed limit sign has the words 'NIGHT' or 'NIGHTTIME' on it, this means:
choices: A different speed limit applies during nighttime hours
Night driving prohibited
Lights required
Night construction
questions.explanation: Some areas have reduced nighttime speed limits due to decreased visibility or increased pedestrian activity, with specific hours typically indicated on the sign.

questions.text: A 'TRUCKS USE RIGHT LANE' sign means:
choices: Commercial trucks should stay in the right lane
All vehicles use right lane
Trucks turning right only
Right lane for trucks only
questions.explanation: These signs direct large commercial trucks to use the right lane, typically on hills or multi-lane highways to improve traffic flow and safety.

questions.text: What does a 'SOFT SHOULDER' sign indicate?
choices: The road edge is unpaved and may not support vehicle weight
Shoulder suitable for parking
Shoulder maintenance ahead
Soft road surface
questions.explanation: SOFT SHOULDER signs warn that the area beyond the pavement edge is unpaved and may be unstable, potentially causing loss of control if you drive onto it.

questions.text: A sign reading 'SLOWER TRAFFIC KEEP RIGHT' is:
choices: A suggestion for courtesy but not legally enforceable
A legal requirement in all states
For trucks only
Enforceable during rush hour only
questions.explanation: While SLOWER TRAFFIC KEEP RIGHT promotes safety and traffic flow, it is generally advisory. However, most states have laws against impeding traffic in left lanes.

questions.text: What does a 'DIP' warning sign indicate?
choices: A low place in the road where water may collect
Road curves down
Deep pothole
Ditch alongside road
questions.explanation: DIP signs warn of a depression in the roadway where water may accumulate during rain and where vehicles may bottom out if taken at high speed.

questions.text: A 'BUMP' warning sign means:
choices: A raised area in the pavement ahead
Speed bump ahead
Rough road
Railroad crossing
questions.explanation: BUMP signs warn of raised areas in the pavement that can cause vehicles to become airborne or lose control if taken at excessive speed.

questions.text: What does a 'DIVIDED HIGHWAY BEGINS' sign indicate?
choices: The road ahead will have a median separating opposing traffic
Highway splits into two roads
Multiple lanes ahead
Divided speed limits ahead
questions.explanation: DIVIDED HIGHWAY BEGINS signs warn that the road ahead will have a median or barrier separating traffic traveling in opposite directions.

questions.text: A 'DIVIDED HIGHWAY ENDS' sign warns that:
choices: Two-way traffic with no median is ahead
Highway is ending
Lanes are merging
Speed limit ending
questions.explanation: DIVIDED HIGHWAY ENDS signs warn that the median will end and oncoming traffic will share the same roadway, requiring increased caution for head-on traffic.

questions.text: What does 'PAVEMENT ENDS' mean?
choices: Paved road surface changes to gravel or dirt ahead
Road ends ahead
Pavement damage ahead
Construction zone
questions.explanation: PAVEMENT ENDS signs warn that the paved surface ends and becomes gravel or dirt, requiring reduced speed and increased following distance.

questions.text: A regulatory sign with a white arrow on blue background indicates:
choices: Direction of required travel or movement
Information only
Optional direction
Pedestrian direction
questions.explanation: Blue signs with white arrows are regulatory and indicate mandatory direction of travel, commonly seen on one-way streets or for required turn movements.

questions.text: What does 'SIGNAL AHEAD' warn you about?
choices: A traffic light is coming up
Emergency signals ahead
Signal for help
Railroad signal ahead
questions.explanation: SIGNAL AHEAD signs warn that a traffic light is approaching, often used where signals are unexpected or on high-speed roads to allow drivers to prepare to stop.

questions.text: A 'STOP AHEAD' warning sign is used when:
choices: A stop sign is not visible until you are very close to it
Stop sign visibility is good
Stop is optional
Four-way stop ahead
questions.explanation: STOP AHEAD warning signs are placed where the actual stop sign may be hidden by curves, hills, or vegetation, giving drivers advance warning to prepare to stop.

questions.text: When a school bus stops with flashing red lights and an extended stop sign on an undivided roadway, vehicles in both directions must:
choices: Stop and remain stopped until the lights stop flashing
Slow to 20 mph and proceed with caution
Stop only if on the same side as the bus
Stop only if children are visible
questions.explanation: On an undivided roadway, all vehicles in both directions must stop and remain stopped until the school bus's red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted. This protects children crossing the street.

questions.text: You are traveling on a divided highway with a raised concrete median barrier. A school bus on the opposite side stops with red lights flashing. What should you do?
choices: Continue driving at normal speed since the barrier separates traffic
Stop until the bus turns off its lights
Slow to 20 mph until past the bus
Stop only if the median is less than 5 feet wide
questions.explanation: On a divided highway with a physical barrier or median at least 5 feet wide, vehicles on the opposite side do not need to stop for a school bus. The barrier provides adequate separation and children cannot cross.

questions.text: You see a school bus ahead stopped with its red lights flashing and stop arm extended. You are on the same undivided two-lane road. How far back must you stop?
choices: At least 20 feet from the bus
At least 10 feet from the bus
Directly behind the bus is sufficient
At least 50 feet from the bus
questions.explanation: Texas law requires all vehicles on an undivided road to stop at least 20 feet from a school bus displaying flashing red lights. This 20-foot buffer gives children a safe zone to cross the road and protects them from vehicles that might not see them behind the bus.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.066; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: When driving through an active school zone with flashing signals, the speed limit is typically:
choices: 15 to 20 mph when children are present
25 mph regardless of conditions
30 mph during school hours only
10 mph at all times
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits are typically reduced to 15-20 mph when children are present or when school zone signals are flashing. These reduced speeds give drivers more time to react to children.

questions.text: A school bus ahead of you is slowing down with amber (yellow) warning lights flashing. What does this indicate?
choices: The bus is preparing to stop to load or unload children
The bus is experiencing mechanical problems
You should pass the bus quickly before it stops
The bus is turning at the next intersection
questions.explanation: Amber warning lights on a school bus indicate the driver is preparing to stop to load or unload children. You should slow down and prepare to stop when the red lights begin flashing.

questions.text: What is the penalty range for illegally passing a stopped school bus with flashing red lights in Texas?
choices: $100 to $300 fine
$250 to $500 fine
questions.explanation: Texas imposes significant penalties for passing a stopped school bus, with fines ranging from $500 to $1,250. These heavy penalties reflect the serious danger this violation poses to children.

questions.text: When are school zone speed limits typically in effect?
choices: When posted signs or flashing lights indicate, usually 30 minutes before and after school
Only during the exact start and end times of school
From 7 AM to 7 PM on school days
24 hours a day when school is in session
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits are typically enforced when posted times indicate or when signals are flashing, usually starting 30 minutes before school begins and ending 30 minutes after school ends.

questions.text: You are driving on a two-lane undivided road. A school bus coming toward you activates its flashing red lights. Must you stop?
choices: Yes — on an undivided road, traffic from both directions must stop for a school bus with red lights
No — only vehicles behind the bus must stop
Only if children are visibly crossing the road
Only if you are within 50 feet of the bus
questions.explanation: On an undivided road (no physical median barrier), vehicles traveling in BOTH directions must stop when a school bus displays flashing red lights. Children may cross from either side. The only exception is roads with a physical dividing barrier (such as a raised median), where oncoming traffic is not required to stop.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.066; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: You are on a four-lane road with a painted center turn lane. A school bus on the opposite side stops with red lights flashing. What must you do?
choices: Stop, because a painted median does not divide the roadway
Continue, because the turn lane separates traffic
Slow to 20 mph but continue driving
Stop only if children are crossing
questions.explanation: A painted center turn lane or painted median does not divide a roadway. You must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights regardless of which side of the road you are on unless there is a physical barrier or median at least 5 feet wide.

questions.text: When a school bus stop sign is extended and red lights are flashing, when can you proceed?
choices: When the lights stop flashing and the stop sign is retracted
When the last child has boarded the bus
After waiting 10 seconds at a complete stop
When the bus driver waves you forward
questions.explanation: You must remain stopped until both the red lights stop flashing and the stop sign is fully retracted. Only then is it safe to proceed, as this signals all children have safely crossed.

questions.text: While driving in a school zone, you see a crossing guard holding up a stop sign. What should you do?
choices: Stop immediately and remain stopped until the guard signals it is safe to proceed
Slow to 10 mph and proceed carefully around the guard
Stop only if children are in the crosswalk
Honk to alert the guard and proceed slowly
questions.explanation: A crossing guard has the authority to stop traffic to protect children. You must stop immediately when a guard signals and wait until the guard indicates it is safe to proceed.

questions.text: What does a pentagon-shaped yellow sign with black symbols indicate?
choices: A school zone or school crossing ahead
A railroad crossing ahead
A construction zone ahead
A pedestrian crossing ahead
questions.explanation: Pentagon-shaped signs are unique to school zones and school crossings. The distinctive five-sided shape makes these signs easily recognizable so drivers can prepare to watch for children.

questions.text: A school bus is stopped ahead with alternating flashing red lights but the stop sign is not yet extended. What should you do?
choices: Stop immediately, as flashing red lights require you to stop
Continue driving since the stop sign is not out
Slow down and prepare to stop
Pass quickly before the stop sign extends
questions.explanation: Flashing red lights on a school bus require you to stop immediately, regardless of whether the stop sign is extended. The lights are the primary signal that children are loading or unloading.

questions.text: You are driving through a school zone at 20 mph during dismissal time. Several children are walking on the sidewalk, and one child appears to be chasing a ball toward the curb. What should you expect?
choices: The child may run into the street without looking — be prepared to stop immediately
The child will stop at the curb and look both ways
The crossing guard will intervene before the child reaches the street
Other children will stop them before they enter the roadway
questions.explanation: Children are unpredictable and often focus on play rather than traffic safety. A child chasing a ball is very likely to run into the street without checking for vehicles. In school zones, always expect the unexpected and be ready to stop instantly. Reaction time at 20 mph gives you about 30 feet of stopping distance.

questions.text: You are on a highway with five lanes: two in each direction and a center turn lane. A school bus stops on the opposite side with red lights flashing. What is required?
choices: You must stop because the center turn lane does not create a divided highway
You can continue because there are multiple lanes separating you
You must slow to 20 mph but need not stop
You must stop only if the bus is directly across from you
questions.explanation: Unless there is a physical barrier or median at least 5 feet wide, the roadway is not considered divided. A center turn lane is painted only, so all traffic must stop for a school bus with flashing red lights.

questions.text: You approach a railroad crossing with flashing red lights and the crossing gate is lowering. You stop your vehicle. What distance from the nearest rail should you maintain?
choices: Between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest rail
Between 5 and 10 feet from the nearest rail
At least 100 feet from the nearest rail
As close as the gate allows
questions.explanation: Texas law requires you to stop between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest railroad rail. Stopping closer than 15 feet puts you dangerously close to the train's path, as trains extend beyond the rails. Stopping beyond 50 feet could put you too far back to see clearly when it is safe to proceed.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.251; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: You must stop at a railroad crossing when:
choices: Lights are flashing, gates are lowering, or a train is visible or audible
Only when a train is visible
Only when gates are completely down
Only when a flag person signals you to stop
questions.explanation: You must stop at a railroad crossing when warning lights flash, gates are lowering, a train is approaching or visible, or a flag person signals. Any of these conditions indicates an approaching train.

questions.text: While crossing railroad tracks, your vehicle becomes stalled on the tracks. What is the first thing you should do?
choices: Get everyone out of the vehicle immediately and move away from the tracks
Try to restart the vehicle
Call 911 from inside the vehicle
Put the vehicle in neutral and try to push it off the tracks
questions.explanation: If your vehicle stalls on railroad tracks, immediately get everyone out and move far away from the tracks, preferably in the direction the train is coming from. Lives are more important than the vehicle.

questions.text: When crossing railroad tracks, you should:
choices: Not shift gears while on the tracks
Speed up to cross as quickly as possible
Stop on the tracks to look both ways
Cross at an angle to reduce the distance
questions.explanation: Never shift gears while crossing railroad tracks because your vehicle could stall. Cross in the gear you are already in and wait until you have completely cleared the tracks before shifting.

questions.text: You see a round yellow sign with a black X and the letters RR while driving on an unfamiliar country road. What should you do?
choices: Slow down, look and listen for trains — a railroad crossing is ahead
Watch for a rest area entrance on the right
Prepare for a roundabout ahead
Yield to cross traffic at the next intersection
questions.explanation: The round yellow advance warning sign with the black X and RR is the Railroad Advance Warning sign (MUTCD W10-1). It tells you a railroad crossing is ahead, giving you time to slow down and prepare to stop if a train is approaching. On rural roads, crossings may not have gates or flashing lights, making this advance warning critical.
questions.reference: MUTCD Section 8B.04; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: After one train passes at a railroad crossing with multiple tracks, you should:
choices: Check for a second train on other tracks before crossing
Cross immediately before another train comes
Wait at least 30 seconds before crossing
Cross only when the gates fully rise
questions.explanation: At crossings with multiple tracks, a second train may be approaching on another track. Always check all tracks in both directions before crossing, even after one train has passed.

questions.text: Is it legal to drive around lowered railroad crossing gates?
choices: No, it is illegal and extremely dangerous
Yes, if you can see no train is coming
Yes, if you are already partially across when gates lower
Yes, if the lights stop flashing
questions.explanation: Driving around lowered railroad gates is illegal and extremely dangerous. Gates lower because a train is approaching, and going around them can result in a fatal collision.

questions.text: Before crossing railroad tracks, you should make sure:
choices: You can completely clear all tracks without stopping
No other vehicles are crossing at the same time
Your vehicle is in first gear
Your windows are rolled down to hear trains
questions.explanation: Before starting to cross railroad tracks, make sure there is enough space on the other side for your entire vehicle to clear all tracks without stopping. Never stop on the tracks.

questions.text: After your vehicle is stalled on railroad tracks and everyone has evacuated, what should you do next?
choices: Call 911 and provide the crossing number posted on the signal equipment
Return to the vehicle and try to start it again
Wait by the tracks for the police to arrive
Try to flag down passing vehicles for help
questions.explanation: After evacuating a stalled vehicle on tracks, immediately call 911 and give them the crossing number (posted on the signal or nearby). This helps railroad operators stop any approaching trains.

questions.text: You are stopped at a railroad crossing with flashing red lights. After a train passes, the lights continue to flash. What should you do?
choices: Remain stopped — a second train may be approaching from the other direction
Proceed carefully after the first train has fully passed
Inch forward slowly to check if the track is clear
Wait exactly 30 seconds after the train passes, then proceed
questions.explanation: If the red lights continue flashing after a train passes, another train may be approaching on a different track. Never proceed while the warning lights are active, even if you just saw a train go by. Multi-track crossings are common, and a second train can arrive from the opposite direction within seconds.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.251; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: What is the minimum distance you must park from railroad tracks?
choices: 100 feet
50 feet
75 feet
150 feet
questions.explanation: Texas law requires parking at least 100 feet away from railroad tracks. This distance prevents your vehicle from being struck by passing trains and keeps the crossing clear for other traffic.

questions.text: You see a pavement marking with a large X and two R's at an intersection. This indicates:
choices: Railroad tracks cross the road ahead
Do not enter this intersection
Reversible lanes ahead
Restricted parking zone
questions.explanation: The X with RR pavement marking warns drivers that railroad tracks cross the roadway. This marking provides an additional visual warning to prepare drivers to stop if a train is approaching.

questions.text: When approaching railroad tracks, you should always:
choices: Look both directions before crossing, even if no warning signals are present
Trust the warning signals to alert you to approaching trains
Cross quickly to minimize time on the tracks
Stop completely regardless of signals or gates
questions.explanation: Always look both ways before crossing railroad tracks, even if there are no signals or if signals are not activated. Signals can malfunction, and trains may approach unexpectedly.

questions.text: If you cannot get your vehicle off railroad tracks and you can see or hear a train approaching, you should move away from the tracks:
choices: In the direction the train is coming from, at an angle away from the tracks
In the direction the train is traveling
Perpendicular to the tracks on either side
Directly away from your vehicle
questions.explanation: Move in the direction the train is coming from at an angle away from the tracks. This protects you from debris that will fly in the direction the train is traveling when it strikes your vehicle.

questions.text: At a railroad crossing without gates or flashing lights, you must:
choices: Slow down, look both ways, and be prepared to stop
Always come to a complete stop
Proceed at normal speed if no train is visible
Sound your horn before crossing
questions.explanation: At passive railroad crossings (no gates or lights), you must slow down, look carefully in both directions, and be prepared to stop if a train is approaching. Not all crossings have warning devices.

questions.text: What does an orange diamond-shaped sign indicate?
choices: Work zone or construction area ahead
School zone ahead
Railroad crossing ahead
Detour ahead
questions.explanation: Orange diamond-shaped signs indicate temporary work zones or construction areas. These signs warn drivers to prepare for changed conditions, workers, and equipment on or near the roadway.

questions.text: You are driving through a highway work zone and see workers and equipment near the road. You notice a sign saying 'Fines Doubled.' If you are cited for speeding here, how are the fines affected?
choices: The fine is doubled compared to the normal amount for that violation
The fine remains the same but points on your license are doubled
The fine is tripled in active work zones
Fines are only doubled if a worker is injured
questions.explanation: Texas law doubles traffic fines in active work zones where workers are present. This applies to speeding, failure to obey traffic control devices, and other moving violations. The doubled fines serve as a deterrent because work zone crashes are disproportionately fatal — workers have no protection from passing vehicles.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §542.404; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: When you see a flagger holding a STOP paddle, you must:
choices: Stop immediately and remain stopped until the flagger signals you to proceed
Slow to 10 mph and proceed with caution
Stop, then proceed if the way looks clear
Stop only if workers are in the roadway
questions.explanation: A flagger with a STOP paddle has the same authority as a stop sign. You must stop immediately and wait until the flagger uses the SLOW paddle or signals you to proceed.

questions.text: Under Texas Move Over Law, when you see a stopped emergency vehicle with flashing lights on the roadside, you must:
choices: Change lanes away from the vehicle, or slow to 20 mph below the limit if you cannot change lanes
Slow to 20 mph regardless of which lane you are in
Stop completely until the vehicle leaves
Change lanes only if directed by emergency personnel
questions.explanation: Texas Move Over Law requires drivers to change lanes away from stopped emergency vehicles with flashing lights. If you cannot change lanes safely, you must slow to 20 mph below the posted limit.

questions.text: A flagger displays a SLOW paddle. What should you do?
choices: Reduce your speed and proceed with caution
Come to a complete stop
Maintain your current speed
Slow to exactly 20 mph
questions.explanation: When a flagger displays a SLOW paddle (orange), reduce your speed and proceed with caution. Be prepared to stop if conditions require or if the flagger changes to a STOP signal.

questions.text: If the posted speed limit is 25 mph or less and you cannot change lanes away from a stopped emergency vehicle, how much must you slow down?
choices: To 5 mph
To 10 mph
To 15 mph
To 20 mph below the limit
questions.explanation: Under Texas Move Over Law, if the posted limit is 25 mph or less and you cannot change lanes, you must slow to 5 mph. For higher speed limits, slow to 20 mph below the posted limit.

questions.text: You are driving through a construction zone on a highway. The lanes are narrower than usual, cones line both sides, and workers are operating equipment near the right shoulder. What is the safest approach?
choices: Reduce speed, stay centered in your lane, and watch for workers or equipment entering the roadway
Speed up to exit the work zone as quickly as possible
Change lanes frequently to find the lane with the least cones
Follow the vehicle ahead as closely as possible to prevent other cars from cutting in
questions.explanation: In work zones, reduce speed to account for narrow lanes and unexpected hazards. Stay centered in your lane to maintain maximum clearance from cones and barriers. Watch for workers, equipment, and sudden lane shifts. Work zone crashes kill hundreds of drivers and workers each year, and most are caused by speeding and inattention.

questions.text: What is the maximum fine for violating the Texas Move Over Law?
questions.explanation: Violating Texas Move Over Law can result in fines up to $2,000. If the violation results in property damage, bodily injury, or death, penalties are even more severe.

questions.text: Which vehicles are covered under the Texas Move Over Law?
choices: Police, fire, EMS, tow trucks, and TxDOT vehicles with flashing lights
Only police and fire vehicles
Only emergency medical vehicles
Any vehicle with hazard lights on
questions.explanation: Texas Move Over Law applies to police, fire, EMS, tow trucks, and TxDOT maintenance vehicles when they are stopped with flashing lights. This protects all roadside workers and emergency personnel.

questions.text: When approaching a work zone where lanes are merging, you should:
choices: Merge early and avoid unnecessary lane changes
Continue in your lane until the last possible moment
Speed up to merge ahead of other traffic
Change lanes multiple times to find the fastest route
questions.explanation: Merge early when approaching lane closures in work zones. This reduces congestion and dangerous last-minute lane changes, making the work zone safer for everyone.

questions.text: A flagger extends their arm horizontally. This signal means:
choices: Stop
Slow down
Proceed
Prepare to stop
questions.explanation: When a flagger extends their arm horizontally, this is a stop signal. You must stop immediately and remain stopped until the flagger signals you to proceed.

questions.text: As you approach a highway construction area, you see an orange diamond sign with a figure of a person holding a flag. What does this sign indicate?
choices: A flagger is ahead directing traffic — prepare to slow or stop as directed
A flag ceremony is being held near the road
Pedestrian crossing ahead within the work zone
A road survey crew is working and may be standing in the lane
questions.explanation: The orange Flagger Ahead sign (MUTCD W20-7) warns that a flagger is controlling traffic ahead, typically because of lane closures or alternating one-way traffic in the work zone. Slow down and be prepared to stop. The flagger's directions have the force of law — you must obey them just like a traffic signal.
questions.reference: MUTCD Section 6E.03; DL-7 Special Driving Situations

questions.text: When a flagger waves a flag in a vertical up-and-down motion, you should:
choices: Slow down
Stop immediately
Proceed at normal speed
Speed up to clear the area
questions.explanation: A vertical up-and-down flag motion from a flagger signals drivers to slow down. This is different from the STOP paddle and indicates caution is needed but you may continue at reduced speed.

questions.text: In work zones, you should NOT:
choices: Change lanes unnecessarily
Obey reduced speed limits
Watch for workers
Follow posted detour signs
questions.explanation: Avoid unnecessary lane changes in work zones. Frequent lane changes increase the risk of collisions and can endanger workers. Stay in your lane unless you must merge due to lane closures.

questions.text: You must treat a flagger's signals the same as:
choices: Official traffic control signals
Suggestions for safer driving
Warning signs only
Advisory speed limits
questions.explanation: Flaggers have the same authority as traffic control signals. You must obey their directions just as you would obey a stop sign or traffic light. Failure to obey can result in citations.

questions.text: Your car's engine suddenly dies while you are in the right lane of a busy highway. You can still steer and brake. What is the safest course of action?
choices: Steer to the right shoulder, activate hazard lights, and raise the hood to signal distress
Stop immediately in your lane and turn on hazard lights
Try to restart the engine while coasting in the travel lane
Coast to the left shoulder for better visibility to approaching traffic
questions.explanation: When your vehicle breaks down on a highway, use your remaining momentum to steer safely onto the right shoulder, as far from traffic as possible. Activate your hazard lights immediately to warn other drivers. Raising the hood is a universal signal of a disabled vehicle. Stopping in a travel lane or the left shoulder exposes you to high-speed rear-end collisions.

questions.text: If you experience a tire blowout while driving, you should:
choices: Grip the wheel firmly, avoid sudden braking, and let the vehicle slow naturally
Brake hard immediately to stop quickly
Accelerate to maintain control
Turn sharply toward the shoulder
questions.explanation: During a tire blowout, grip the wheel firmly, avoid sudden braking, and let the vehicle slow down naturally. Steer straight and brake gently once speed is reduced, then pull off the road safely.

questions.text: If your brakes fail while driving, you should first:
choices: Pump the brake pedal rapidly several times
Pull the parking brake hard
Turn off the engine
Shift into neutral
questions.explanation: If brakes fail, first pump the brake pedal rapidly to build up brake fluid pressure. This may restore enough braking power to slow or stop. If this fails, downshift and use the parking brake gradually.

questions.text: If your vehicle catches fire, you should:
choices: Pull over immediately, get everyone out, move far away, and call 911
Drive to the nearest fire station
Try to put out the fire with a portable extinguisher
Open the hood to see where the fire is
questions.explanation: If your vehicle catches fire, immediately pull over, evacuate everyone, move far from the vehicle, and call 911. Vehicle fires spread rapidly and the vehicle may explode. Never open the hood of a car with an engine fire.

questions.text: If you are involved in a crash, you must:
choices: Stop immediately at the scene or nearby
Continue to the nearest police station
Exchange information only if someone is injured
Leave if the other driver agrees it was minor
questions.explanation: Texas law requires you to stop immediately after any crash. Leaving the scene is a hit-and-run crime with serious penalties, even for minor crashes with no injuries.

questions.text: After a crash, you must report it to police if:
choices: There are injuries or property damage exceeding $1,000
Any vehicle needs to be towed
Airbags deployed in any vehicle
More than two vehicles are involved
questions.explanation: Texas law requires crash reports when there are injuries, deaths, or property damage exceeding $1,000. File the report within 10 days of the crash, even if police did not come to the scene.

questions.text: If your vehicle is broken down on a busy highway, you should generally:
choices: Stay in your vehicle with doors locked until help arrives
Stand behind your vehicle to warn other drivers
Walk to the nearest exit to call for help
Accept rides from passing motorists
questions.explanation: On busy highways, it is generally safer to stay inside your locked vehicle with your seatbelt on until help arrives. Standing outside puts you at risk of being struck by passing vehicles.

questions.text: If you must exit your disabled vehicle on a highway, you should:
