choices: Exit through the passenger side door away from traffic
Exit through the driver's side door
Exit only after stopping all traffic with hand signals
Wait until emergency vehicles arrive to exit
questions.explanation: If you must exit a disabled vehicle on a highway, use the passenger side door to exit away from traffic. This reduces your risk of being struck by passing vehicles.

questions.text: After a crash, you should exchange which information with the other driver?
choices: Name, address, phone number, insurance information, and driver license number
Only insurance information
Only name and phone number
Only insurance and vehicle registration
questions.explanation: After a crash, exchange names, addresses, phone numbers, insurance information, and driver license numbers with all involved parties. This information is needed for insurance claims and police reports.

questions.text: If you encounter a hazardous materials spill on the roadway, you should:
choices: Stay upwind and uphill from the spill, do not touch it, and call 911
Drive through it quickly to avoid prolonged exposure
Stop and help injured people immediately
Place warning flares near the spill to alert others
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials spills can be deadly. Stay upwind and uphill to avoid fumes, do not touch the material, and immediately call 911. Let trained hazmat teams handle the situation.

questions.text: After a crash with no injuries, should you move the vehicles if they are blocking traffic?
choices: Yes, if it is safe to do so, move vehicles to the shoulder
No, never move vehicles until police arrive
Yes, always move vehicles immediately regardless of conditions
No, leave vehicles in place to preserve evidence
questions.explanation: If there are no injuries and it is safe to do so, Texas law requires you to move vehicles to the shoulder to prevent additional crashes. Take photos first if possible for insurance purposes.

questions.text: If your brakes fail and pumping does not restore pressure, you should next:
choices: Downshift to a lower gear to use engine braking
Turn off the ignition immediately
Swerve side to side to slow down
Drive off the road into a ditch
questions.explanation: If pumping the brakes does not work, downshift to a lower gear to use engine braking to slow the vehicle. Then gradually apply the parking brake. Look for an escape route such as an uphill area or open space.

questions.text: If you are involved in a crash, you should NOT:
choices: Admit fault or apologize at the scene
Check for injuries to all parties
Call 911 if anyone is hurt
Exchange insurance information
questions.explanation: Never admit fault or apologize at the scene of a crash, as statements can be used against you later. Stick to facts when exchanging information and let insurance companies and authorities determine fault.

questions.text: If you have warning triangles or flares after a breakdown, you should place them:
choices: Behind your vehicle at increasing distances to warn approaching traffic
In front of your vehicle only
Under your vehicle to mark its location
On top of your vehicle for better visibility
questions.explanation: Place warning triangles or flares behind your vehicle at increasing distances (such as 10, 100, and 200 feet) to give approaching drivers advance warning. This helps prevent additional crashes.

questions.text: If you are the first to arrive at a crash scene with injured people, your first priority should be to:
choices: Call 911 and keep injured people still unless they are in immediate danger
Move all injured people away from vehicles immediately
Give first aid before calling for emergency help
Direct traffic around the crash scene
questions.explanation: At a crash scene, first call 911 to get professional help on the way. Keep injured people still unless there is immediate danger like fire, as moving them can worsen injuries. Let trained medical personnel provide treatment.

questions.text: You are driving through a residential area at 30 mph and enter an active school zone with flashing beacons. What speed must you reduce to?
choices: 20 mph or the speed posted on the school zone sign
25 mph unless children are in the road
10 mph during school hours only
No change needed if you are already below 35 mph
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits in Texas are typically 15–20 mph and are enforceable when the beacons are flashing or during posted times. You must reduce to the posted school zone speed regardless of whether children are currently visible — they could emerge at any moment. School zone violations carry enhanced fines.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.3561; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You are driving through a residential neighborhood and don't see any speed limit signs. What is the default speed limit you should follow?
choices: 30 mph
25 mph
35 mph
20 mph
questions.explanation: Texas law establishes a prima facie (default) speed limit of 30 mph in urban districts and residential areas when no other speed limit is posted. This speed accounts for pedestrians, children playing, vehicles backing out of driveways, and other hazards common in residential settings.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.352; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the maximum speed limit on rural Texas highways?
choices: 70-75 mph depending on the road
65 mph
80 mph
60 mph
questions.explanation: Rural Texas highways can have speed limits up to 70-75 mph depending on the type of road and posted signs. Drivers should always check posted speed limit signs as they vary by location.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: The basic speed law requires you to:
choices: Never drive faster than is safe for current conditions
Always drive at the posted speed limit
Drive at least 5 mph below the speed limit in rain
Match the speed of surrounding traffic
questions.explanation: The basic speed law requires drivers to never exceed a speed that is reasonable and prudent under current conditions, regardless of posted limits. Weather, visibility, and traffic may require slower speeds than posted.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When should you reduce your speed below the posted limit?
choices: In poor weather, heavy traffic, or reduced visibility
Only when a police officer is present
Never, the posted limit is always safe
Only at night
questions.explanation: Drivers must reduce speed below posted limits when conditions such as rain, fog, ice, heavy traffic, or poor visibility make the posted speed unsafe. Safe driving requires adjusting to current conditions.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is a prima facie speed limit?
choices: A speed limit that applies based on road type even when not posted
The minimum speed allowed on highways
A temporary speed limit during construction
A speed limit that only applies during daytime
questions.explanation: Prima facie speed limits are statutory limits that apply to certain types of roads based on their characteristics, even without posted signs. For example, 30 mph in residential areas applies even without signs.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You merge onto an urban highway in Houston with no posted speed limit sign visible. What maximum speed should you assume?
choices: 60 mph — the default for urban highways in Texas
70 mph — the general Texas highway limit
55 mph — the national speed limit standard
65 mph — the default for all Texas highways
questions.explanation: The default speed limit for urban highways (numbered highways within a city's limits) in Texas is 60 mph when no other limit is posted. Rural highways have a higher default of 70 mph. The lower urban limit reflects higher traffic density, more frequent exits, and greater pedestrian activity near urban highways.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.352; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What does driving too slowly on a highway violate?
choices: Minimum speed laws that prohibit impeding traffic flow
No law, you can drive as slowly as you want
Only the basic speed law
School zone regulations
questions.explanation: Texas law prohibits driving so slowly that you impede the normal and reasonable movement of traffic. Minimum speed limits exist on many highways to maintain safe traffic flow.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When are school zone speed limits typically enforced?
choices: When children are present or signals are flashing
24 hours a day, 7 days a week
Only during morning hours
Only on weekdays
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits are enforced when children are present, when crossing guards are on duty, or when school zone signals are flashing. Outside these times, regular speed limits apply.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What should you do when driving through a construction zone?
choices: Reduce speed and obey posted construction zone speed limits
Maintain normal speed if workers are not visible
Increase speed to exit the zone quickly
Only slow down if flaggers are present
questions.explanation: Construction zones require reduced speeds as posted. Even when workers are not visible, narrow lanes, uneven surfaces, and equipment create hazards requiring slower speeds.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: On a highway with a posted speed limit of 65 mph, what is generally considered impeding traffic?
choices: Driving significantly below the posted limit without justification
Driving exactly at the speed limit
Driving 5 mph over the limit
Driving in the right lane
questions.explanation: Driving significantly slower than the posted limit without good reason (weather, mechanical issues) can impede traffic flow and create hazards. Drivers should maintain a reasonable speed or use slower-traffic lanes.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Which factor most affects whether a speed is legally considered 'reasonable and prudent'?
choices: Current road and traffic conditions
The posted speed limit only
The speed of the fastest vehicles
The time of day
questions.explanation: A 'reasonable and prudent' speed depends primarily on current conditions including weather, visibility, traffic density, and road surface. Even speeds below posted limits can be unreasonable if conditions are poor.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: A new driver asks why school zones have such low speed limits compared to the surrounding roads. What is the primary safety reason?
choices: Lower speeds give drivers more time to see and react to children who may dart into the street
Lower speeds reduce noise near school buildings
Lower speeds reduce vehicle emissions in areas with children
Lower speeds prevent damage to school infrastructure
questions.explanation: School zone speed limits are primarily about reaction time and stopping distance. At 20 mph, a car needs about 30 feet to stop. At 40 mph, stopping distance more than quadruples to over 130 feet. Children are small, unpredictable, and may enter the roadway without warning — the lower speed gives drivers a realistic chance to stop in time.
questions.reference: DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What speed limit typically applies in alleys in Texas?
choices: 15 mph
20 mph
25 mph
30 mph
questions.explanation: The prima facie speed limit in alleys is 15 mph unless otherwise posted. This low speed accounts for limited visibility, narrow passages, and frequent pedestrian activity.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When can you legally exceed the posted speed limit?
choices: Never, posted limits are legal maximums under ideal conditions
When passing another vehicle
When keeping up with traffic flow
When running late for an appointment
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits are legal maximums that apply under ideal conditions. Exceeding them is illegal even when passing, matching traffic, or in a hurry. Safe passing must occur within the speed limit.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: A highway has a 70 mph speed limit but heavy fog reduces visibility to 100 feet. What is the legal maximum speed?
choices: Whatever speed is safe for the conditions, likely well below 70 mph
70 mph, the posted limit always applies
60 mph, reduced by 10 mph for fog
55 mph, the standard reduced-visibility limit
questions.explanation: The basic speed law requires driving at a safe speed for conditions regardless of posted limits. With 100-foot visibility, a safe speed would be far below 70 mph to allow adequate stopping distance.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the typical speed limit on numbered highways in rural areas?
choices: 70 mph for most highways
60 mph for all highways
55 mph unless posted higher
75 mph for all rural roads
questions.explanation: Most rural numbered highways in Texas have a 70 mph speed limit, though some may be posted at 75 mph. Always check posted signs as limits vary by specific road and location.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How should you adjust your speed when approaching a curve?
choices: Slow down before entering the curve, not while in it
Maintain speed and brake in the curve if needed
Accelerate through the curve for stability
Speed doesn't matter if you have good tires
questions.explanation: Drivers should reduce speed before entering a curve, not while in it. Braking in a curve can cause loss of traction and control, especially on wet or icy roads.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is driving significantly slower than traffic flow dangerous even if you're at the speed limit?
choices: It creates speed differentials that cause accidents
It's not dangerous, slower is always safer
It only affects traffic flow, not safety
It's only dangerous if you're in the left lane
questions.explanation: Large speed differences between vehicles increase collision risk as faster vehicles must suddenly brake or change lanes. Matching reasonable traffic flow (within legal limits) is often safer than going much slower.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the main reason speed limits are lower at night in some areas?
choices: Reduced visibility limits reaction time and sight distance
To reduce noise for residents
Nighttime speed limits are actually the same
To save fuel with lower speeds
questions.explanation: When posted, night speed limits reflect reduced visibility that decreases the distance you can see hazards, reducing available reaction time. Even with headlights, nighttime sight distance is significantly less than daytime.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the speed limit for a narrow, winding country road if no signs are posted?
choices: Whatever speed is safe for the road conditions
30 mph as the residential default
55 mph as the standard rural limit
45 mph for unpaved roads
questions.explanation: On roads without posted limits, the basic speed law requires driving at a safe speed for conditions. A narrow, winding road requires much slower speeds than straight highways, regardless of default limits.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You notice a speed limit sign showing 20 mph with flashing amber beacons. Where are you most likely driving?
choices: Through an active school zone near a school
In a hospital parking lot
Through a residential neighborhood
In a construction zone on a highway
questions.explanation: A 20 mph speed limit with flashing beacons is the hallmark of an active school zone. The beacons indicate that the reduced speed limit is currently in effect, typically during school arrival and dismissal times. This is the most common location for such a low posted speed in Texas.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.3561; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When is it legal to drive below the minimum speed limit on a highway?
choices: When safety requires it due to weather or vehicle problems
Never, minimum limits must always be obeyed
Only during rush hour
When driving a large truck
questions.explanation: Drivers may go below minimum speed limits when safety requires it, such as in severe weather, mechanical problems, or other hazardous conditions. However, if your vehicle cannot maintain minimum speed, use a different route.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the general speed limit in business or urban districts unless posted otherwise?
choices: 30 mph
35 mph
40 mph
25 mph
questions.explanation: The prima facie speed limit in business and urban districts is 30 mph unless otherwise posted. This accounts for increased pedestrian activity, frequent intersections, and vehicles entering the roadway.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does speed affect your field of vision?
choices: Higher speeds narrow your field of vision to straight ahead
Speed does not affect field of vision
Higher speeds improve peripheral vision
Only extreme speeds above 100 mph affect vision
questions.explanation: As speed increases, your useful field of vision narrows, creating tunnel vision. At high speeds, you focus more on the road ahead and notice less in your periphery, reducing awareness of hazards.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What should you do if other vehicles are exceeding the speed limit?
choices: Drive at a safe, legal speed; don't follow unsafe behavior
Match their speed to avoid being a hazard
Report them immediately to police
Flash your lights to warn them
questions.explanation: Never exceed speed limits just because others do. Maintain a safe, legal speed and let faster vehicles pass. You're responsible for your own safe driving, not matching unsafe behavior.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is speeding particularly dangerous on wet roads even at moderate speeds?
choices: Stopping distance increases dramatically and hydroplaning risk rises
Wet roads are not more dangerous if you maintain speed
Only speeds above 60 mph are dangerous on wet roads
Wet roads only affect visibility, not traction
questions.explanation: Wet roads reduce tire traction, increasing stopping distance significantly. Additionally, higher speeds increase hydroplaning risk where tires lose contact with the road entirely. Reduced speed is essential on wet surfaces.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When entering a highway from an entrance ramp, you should:
choices: Accelerate to match highway traffic speed before merging
Enter slowly and speed up after merging
Stop at the end of the ramp to check traffic
Maintain the posted ramp speed limit
questions.explanation: Entrance ramps are designed for accelerating to highway speeds before merging. Entering at speeds much lower than traffic flow creates dangerous speed differentials and collision risk.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the relationship between speed and crash severity?
choices: Higher speeds exponentially increase injury severity and fatality risk
Speed has minimal effect on crash outcomes
Speed only matters in head-on collisions
Modern safety features eliminate speed-related risks
questions.explanation: Crash severity increases exponentially with speed. A crash at 60 mph releases four times the energy of one at 30 mph, dramatically increasing injury severity and the likelihood of fatalities.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: A friend shows you a rectangular white sign with black text and asks what type of sign it is. The sign reads 'SPEED LIMIT 65.' How would you identify this sign type?
choices: It is a regulatory sign — white rectangle with black text is the standard format for speed limits
It is a warning sign displayed before a curve
It is a guide sign directing you to a highway
It is an advisory sign showing a recommended speed
questions.explanation: Speed limit signs follow a standardized design: white rectangular background with black text reading 'SPEED LIMIT' above the number. This makes them immediately distinguishable from yellow diamond warning signs (advisory speeds) and green guide signs (destinations). The MUTCD mandates this format nationwide.
questions.reference: MUTCD Section 2B.13; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You are driving at 55 mph on a clear, dry road. Using the 3-second following rule, approximately how many feet of space should you maintain behind the car ahead?
choices: About 240 feet — at 55 mph you travel roughly 80 feet per second
About 50 feet — one car length per 10 mph
About 160 feet — three car lengths
About 100 feet — the minimum safe distance at highway speed
questions.explanation: At 55 mph you cover about 80 feet per second (55 × 5280 / 3600 ≈ 80.7 ft/s). Three seconds of travel equals approximately 240 feet. The 3-second rule automatically scales with speed — the faster you drive, the more space you need. This is why time-based following distance is more reliable than counting car lengths.
questions.reference: DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You want to check whether you are maintaining a safe 3-second following distance from the car ahead on the highway. What is the correct technique?
choices: Pick a fixed object; when the car ahead passes it, count 3 seconds — you should not reach it before finishing
Estimate the number of car lengths between you and the vehicle ahead
Check your speedometer and divide by 10 for the number of car lengths needed
If you can read the car's license plate clearly, you are too close
questions.explanation: The standard technique is to pick a stationary reference point (sign, pole, overpass). When the vehicle ahead passes it, count 'one-thousand-one, one-thousand-two, one-thousand-three.' If you reach the reference point before you finish counting, you are following too closely and need to back off. This method works at any speed.
questions.reference: DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When following a large truck or bus, you should maintain:
choices: At least 4 seconds following distance
The standard 3 seconds following distance
At least 2 seconds following distance
Whatever distance allows you to see around it
questions.explanation: Large vehicles require at least 4 seconds following distance because they can block your view ahead, may stop suddenly, and their size makes judging distance more difficult. Extra space provides safer reaction time.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How should you adjust following distance in rain?
choices: Double your following distance to at least 6 seconds
Maintain the standard 3 seconds
Reduce following distance to stay closer
Add 1 second for a total of 4 seconds
questions.explanation: Wet roads require at least double the normal following distance because stopping distance increases significantly. A 6-second gap provides the extra time and space needed to stop safely on wet pavement.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What following distance should you maintain on icy roads?
choices: At least 9 seconds or more
The standard 3 seconds
At least 6 seconds
At least 4 seconds
questions.explanation: Ice dramatically reduces traction, requiring triple or more following distance (9+ seconds). Stopping on ice can take 3-10 times longer than on dry pavement, necessitating much greater space.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is tailgating?
choices: Following too closely behind another vehicle
Driving with the tailgate down
Parking too close to another vehicle
Changing lanes without signaling
questions.explanation: Tailgating means following too closely behind another vehicle, not maintaining a safe following distance. It's dangerous and illegal because it doesn't allow enough time or space to stop if the lead vehicle brakes suddenly.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is a time-based following distance (seconds) better than a distance-based one (feet)?
choices: Time-based distances work at all speeds automatically
Feet are easier to measure than seconds
Time-based distances are shorter
Distance-based measurements are more accurate
questions.explanation: A time-based following distance automatically adjusts for speed. At 30 mph, 3 seconds equals 132 feet; at 60 mph, it equals 264 feet. This ensures adequate space at any speed without complex calculations.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What should you do if someone is tailgating you?
choices: Maintain your speed, change lanes if safe, and let them pass
Brake suddenly to teach them a lesson
Speed up to increase the gap
Tailgate the vehicle in front of you
questions.explanation: When being tailgated, maintain steady speed and move to another lane if possible to let the tailgater pass. Never brake suddenly or speed excessively, as both create additional hazards.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the 'space cushion' concept?
choices: Maintaining safe space on all sides of your vehicle
Only maintaining distance from the vehicle ahead
Extra space only needed in bad weather
Space between your seat and the steering wheel
questions.explanation: A space cushion means maintaining adequate space on all sides of your vehicle—front, rear, and both sides. This provides escape routes and reaction time if hazards develop from any direction.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is following distance particularly important at night?
choices: Reduced visibility limits your ability to see hazards ahead
Roads are more slippery at night
Other drivers are always impaired at night
Speed limits are lower at night
questions.explanation: At night, even with headlights, you cannot see as far ahead as during daylight. Increased following distance compensates for reduced visibility and gives more time to identify and react to hazards.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When following a motorcycle, you should:
choices: Give extra following distance as motorcycles can stop quickly
Follow more closely to be visible in their mirrors
Maintain the standard 3-second distance
Match their exact speed and position
questions.explanation: Motorcycles can stop more quickly than cars, and they're harder to see. Providing extra following distance (4+ seconds) protects both you and the motorcyclist if sudden braking is needed.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What happens to required following distance as your speed increases?
choices: The distance in feet increases proportionally while time stays constant
Both time and distance decrease
Time increases but distance stays the same
Nothing changes if you maintain 3 seconds
questions.explanation: At higher speeds, you travel more feet per second, so a 3-second following distance covers more ground. The time interval stays constant (3 seconds), but the physical distance increases with speed.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does fatigue affect safe following distance?
choices: Increase following distance as reaction time is slower when tired
Following distance doesn't need adjustment for fatigue
Decrease distance to stay more alert
Only adjust at night when fatigued
questions.explanation: Fatigue slows reaction time significantly. Increasing following distance compensates for the delayed response, providing extra time and space to recognize hazards and react safely despite reduced alertness.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: In heavy traffic moving at 20 mph, what following distance should you maintain?
choices: At least 3 seconds, the minimum regardless of speed
1 second is sufficient at low speeds
Following distance doesn't matter in slow traffic
As close as possible to keep traffic moving
questions.explanation: The 3-second rule applies at all speeds, even slow traffic. Low speeds don't eliminate the need for reaction time and stopping distance. Adequate space prevents rear-end collisions if traffic stops suddenly.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is it dangerous to follow closely even if you're confident in your reaction time?
choices: The vehicle ahead might stop instantly due to a collision, giving you no warning
Confident drivers never have accidents
Close following actually improves aerodynamics
Modern brakes make following distance irrelevant
questions.explanation: If the vehicle ahead hits something, it stops almost instantly with no brake lights or warning. No matter how quick your reactions, you need physical distance to stop. Human reaction time cannot overcome physics.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the primary benefit of maintaining proper following distance?
choices: It provides adequate time and space to react to sudden stops
It reduces fuel consumption
It prevents other vehicles from changing lanes ahead of you
It allows you to drive faster
questions.explanation: Proper following distance's main benefit is providing sufficient time to perceive a hazard, react, and stop before hitting the vehicle ahead. This reaction and stopping space is critical for avoiding rear-end collisions.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How should following distance change in fog?
choices: Increase significantly because you cannot see ahead clearly
Decrease so you can follow the vehicle's taillights
Maintain normal distance but use hazard lights
Following distance is irrelevant in fog
questions.explanation: Fog severely reduces visibility of hazards ahead. Increased following distance gives more time to react to vehicles stopped or slowing ahead that you cannot see until the last moment. Never follow taillights closely in fog.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What should you do when vehicles keep merging into your following space?
choices: Slow down to re-establish a safe following distance
Maintain your speed and accept reduced space
Speed up to close the gap and prevent merging
Change to a slower lane
questions.explanation: When vehicles merge into your space cushion, ease off the accelerator to gradually re-establish safe following distance. Never speed up or tailgate to prevent lane changes, as this creates hazards.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is the '1 car length per 10 mph' rule considered inadequate?
choices: It doesn't account for reaction time, only braking distance
It provides too much following distance
Car lengths vary too much between vehicles
It's actually the most accurate method
questions.explanation: The 'car length per 10 mph' rule only estimates braking distance but ignores reaction time distance. Additionally, judging car lengths while driving is difficult. Time-based rules (3-second rule) account for both reaction and braking.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When should you increase following distance beyond the 3-second minimum?
choices: In bad weather, heavy traffic, or when following large vehicles
Only when visibility is reduced
Never, 3 seconds is always sufficient
Only on highways
questions.explanation: Increase following distance beyond 3 seconds in adverse conditions: bad weather, poor visibility, heavy traffic, when fatigued, when following motorcycles or large vehicles, or when being tailgated. Multiple factors often require extra space.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You are following a large SUV closely on the highway at 65 mph. The SUV suddenly brakes hard for debris in the road. Why is your position especially dangerous?
choices: You may not have enough distance to stop before hitting the SUV or the debris
The SUV's brake lights may not be bright enough to see
Your fuel efficiency decreases significantly when following closely
The SUV's exhaust may cloud your windshield
questions.explanation: Tailgating eliminates your safety margin. At 65 mph, you travel nearly 100 feet per second. Average reaction time is about 1.5 seconds (150 feet at that speed), and braking distance adds another 200+ feet. Following too closely means you have less time and distance to react than physically required to stop, making a rear-end collision almost inevitable if the vehicle ahead brakes hard.
questions.reference: DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does vehicle weight affect the following distance you should maintain?
choices: Heavier vehicles need more following distance because they take longer to stop
Weight doesn't affect following distance
Lighter vehicles need more following distance
Only commercial vehicles need to consider weight
questions.explanation: Heavier vehicles have more momentum and require greater distance to stop. If driving a heavy vehicle, truck, or towing a trailer, increase your following distance beyond the standard minimum to account for increased stopping distance.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the correct following distance when driving downhill?
choices: Increase following distance as gravity makes stopping more difficult
Decrease distance since you're going slower downhill
Maintain the standard 3 seconds
Downhill grades don't affect following distance
questions.explanation: Downhill grades increase stopping distance because gravity pulls your vehicle forward while braking. Increase following distance on downhill sections to compensate for this additional momentum and longer stopping distances.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How can you tell if you're maintaining a safe following distance?
choices: You can stop comfortably without hard braking if the vehicle ahead stops
You can see the rear tires of the vehicle ahead
Other drivers don't merge into your space
Your speedometer matches the vehicle ahead
questions.explanation: A safe following distance allows you to stop completely without hard braking if the vehicle ahead stops suddenly. If you must brake hard or swerve to avoid a collision, your following distance is too short.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why should you avoid 'drafting' or following large trucks closely on highways?
choices: You cannot see ahead, stopping distance is insufficient, and debris from the truck can hit you
It's actually safer because the truck blocks wind
Trucks don't mind being followed closely
It improves your fuel economy significantly
questions.explanation: Following trucks closely ('drafting') is extremely dangerous. You cannot see hazards ahead, don't have adequate stopping distance if the truck brakes, and tire debris or cargo can strike your vehicle with no warning.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Total stopping distance consists of which two components?
choices: Reaction distance and braking distance
Thinking time and stopping time
Speed distance and brake distance
Perception time and skid distance
questions.explanation: Total stopping distance equals reaction distance (distance traveled while you recognize danger and move foot to brake) plus braking distance (distance traveled while braking to a stop).
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is typical reaction time for an alert driver?
choices: 0.75 to 1.5 seconds
0.25 seconds
3 seconds
5 seconds
questions.explanation: Most alert drivers have a reaction time of 0.75 to 1.5 seconds from seeing a hazard to beginning braking. During this time, the vehicle continues at the same speed, covering significant distance.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does doubling your speed affect braking distance?
choices: Braking distance quadruples (increases by 4 times)
Braking distance doubles
Braking distance stays the same
Braking distance triples
questions.explanation: Braking distance increases exponentially with speed. Doubling speed from 30 to 60 mph quadruples braking distance because kinetic energy increases by the square of velocity. This is why speed is so critical to safety.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Which factor has the greatest effect on stopping distance?
choices: Vehicle speed
Tire brand
Radio volume
Number of passengers
questions.explanation: Speed is the single most important factor affecting stopping distance. Higher speeds exponentially increase both reaction distance and braking distance, making speed control critical for safety.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How do wet roads affect stopping distance?
choices: Stopping distance can double or more on wet roads
Stopping distance decreases slightly on wet roads
Wet roads don't affect stopping distance
Stopping distance increases by 10% on wet roads
questions.explanation: Wet roads significantly reduce tire traction, potentially doubling stopping distance or more compared to dry pavement. This is why reducing speed and increasing following distance in rain is critical.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is brake fade and when does it occur?
choices: Reduced braking power from overheated brakes, common on long downhill grades
The normal wearing down of brake pads over time
A type of brake fluid
Brake failure from cold temperatures
questions.explanation: Brake fade occurs when brakes overheat from excessive use, particularly on long downhill grades. Overheated brakes lose effectiveness, dramatically increasing stopping distance. Use lower gears to slow on long hills rather than continuous braking.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does driving uphill versus downhill affect stopping distance?
choices: Stopping distance is shorter uphill and longer downhill
Stopping distance is longer uphill and shorter downhill
Grade has no effect on stopping distance
Stopping distance is the same in both directions
questions.explanation: Gravity helps slow your vehicle when going uphill, reducing stopping distance. When going downhill, gravity pulls the vehicle forward, working against your brakes and increasing stopping distance significantly.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What happens to reaction distance as speed increases?
choices: Reaction distance increases proportionally with speed
Reaction distance decreases with speed
Reaction distance stays constant regardless of speed
Reaction distance doubles when speed doubles
questions.explanation: Reaction distance increases directly with speed. If reaction time is 1.5 seconds, at 30 mph you travel 66 feet during reaction time, but at 60 mph you travel 132 feet before even starting to brake.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does tire tread depth affect stopping distance?
choices: Worn tires with shallow tread increase stopping distance, especially on wet roads
Tread depth has no effect on stopping
Shallow tread actually decreases stopping distance
Tread depth only matters for off-road driving
questions.explanation: Adequate tread depth is essential for traction, especially on wet roads where treads channel water away. Worn tires with shallow tread increase stopping distance and hydroplaning risk. Check tread depth regularly.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why is stopping distance on ice up to 10 times greater than on dry pavement?
choices: Ice provides almost no friction between tires and road surface
Ice makes tires harder and less flexible
Ice damages brake systems
Ice is heavier than dry pavement
questions.explanation: Ice creates an extremely low-friction surface between tires and road. With minimal friction, tires cannot grip effectively regardless of braking pressure, causing vehicles to slide and dramatically increasing stopping distance.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How should you use brakes when driving with anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
choices: Apply firm, steady pressure without pumping
Pump the brakes rapidly
Press and release repeatedly
Use parking brake first
questions.explanation: With ABS, apply firm, steady pressure to the brake pedal. The system automatically pumps the brakes to prevent wheel lockup. Never pump ABS brakes manually as this reduces their effectiveness.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the main advantage of anti-lock brakes (ABS)?
choices: They allow you to steer while braking hard
They reduce stopping distance on all surfaces
They eliminate the need for brake maintenance
They work better than regular brakes on ice
questions.explanation: ABS's main advantage is maintaining steering control during hard braking by preventing wheel lockup. While they may slightly reduce stopping distance on some surfaces, maintaining steering control to avoid hazards is their primary benefit.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does vehicle weight affect stopping distance?
choices: Heavier vehicles have more momentum and require greater distance to stop
Weight has no effect on stopping distance
Heavier vehicles stop more quickly due to better traction
Only weight above 10,000 pounds affects stopping
questions.explanation: Heavier vehicles have more momentum (mass times velocity) and require more force and distance to stop. A loaded truck takes much longer to stop than an empty car, even at the same speed.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What should you do to avoid brake fade on a long downhill grade?
choices: Use a lower gear and engine braking instead of constant braking
Ride the brakes continuously
Shift to neutral and coast
Accelerate to get down the hill faster
questions.explanation: Use lower gears and engine braking on long downhill grades to avoid overheating brakes. Engine braking slows the vehicle without using brakes, preventing brake fade and maintaining full braking ability for emergencies.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: At 55 mph, approximately how many feet does a vehicle travel during a 1.5 second reaction time?
choices: About 121 feet
About 50 feet
About 200 feet
About 80 feet
questions.explanation: At 55 mph, a vehicle travels about 81 feet per second (55 mph ÷ 60 min × 5,280 ft ÷ 60 sec). In 1.5 seconds of reaction time, the vehicle travels approximately 121 feet before braking even begins.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You are driving on a winding mountain road at dusk and your headlights illuminate about 300 feet ahead. The posted speed limit is 45 mph. At what speed should you actually be traveling?
choices: A speed that allows you to stop within 300 feet — likely below the 45 mph posted limit
45 mph since that is the posted speed limit
35 mph because dusk automatically reduces all speed limits by 10 mph
Any speed as long as your headlights are on
questions.explanation: You must always be able to stop within the distance you can see ahead — your 'sight distance.' If your headlights illuminate only 300 feet, you must travel at a speed that allows you to stop within that distance. At 45 mph on a winding road, stopping distance may exceed 300 feet, requiring you to slow down even though the posted limit is higher.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.351; DL-7 Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How much does stopping distance typically increase when a vehicle is towing a trailer?
choices: Stopping distance can increase by 20-40% or more
Trailers don't affect stopping distance
Stopping distance decreases when towing
Stopping distance increases by only 5%
questions.explanation: Towing a trailer significantly increases vehicle weight and momentum, increasing stopping distance by 20-40% or more depending on trailer weight. Always increase following distance when towing.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is 'perception time' in the context of stopping distance?
choices: The time it takes to recognize a hazard exists
The time it takes to apply the brakes
The time your brakes take to engage
The time between seeing something and deciding what it is
questions.explanation: Perception time is the moment you first see a hazard until you recognize it as a danger. This is part of overall reaction time and varies based on alertness, visibility, and hazard obviousness.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why can't you simply memorize one stopping distance that applies to all situations?
choices: Stopping distance varies with speed, road conditions, vehicle weight, and brakes
Stopping distance is always the same
Only speed affects stopping distance
Memorizing one distance is actually recommended
questions.explanation: Stopping distance varies dramatically based on multiple factors: speed, road surface condition, tire condition, brake condition, vehicle weight, grade, and weather. Safe driving requires adjusting for current conditions, not memorizing one distance.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: How does tire pressure affect stopping distance?
choices: Both under-inflation and over-inflation increase stopping distance
Only over-inflation affects stopping distance
Tire pressure has no effect on stopping
Under-inflation decreases stopping distance
questions.explanation: Improper tire pressure, whether too high or too low, reduces the tire's contact patch with the road, decreasing traction and increasing stopping distance. Maintain manufacturer-recommended tire pressure for optimal braking.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When passing another vehicle, how much clear distance ahead do you typically need?
choices: At least 1/3 to 1/2 mile of clear visibility
100 feet of clear space
500 feet of clear space
Whatever distance you can see
questions.explanation: Safe passing requires at least 1/3 to 1/2 mile of clear visibility ahead to ensure you can complete the pass and return to your lane safely before meeting oncoming traffic.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When is it safe to return to the right lane after passing?
choices: When you can see the passed vehicle in your rearview mirror
As soon as you're alongside the vehicle
After you're 10 feet ahead
When your front bumper is ahead of theirs
questions.explanation: Return to the right lane only when you can see the entire passed vehicle in your rearview mirror. This ensures adequate clearance and avoids cutting off the other driver.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: What is the minimum clearance required when passing a bicycle in Texas?
choices: 3 feet
1 foot
6 feet
5 feet
questions.explanation: Texas law requires drivers to maintain at least 3 feet of clearance when passing a bicycle. This distance protects cyclists from side-swipe collisions and air turbulence from passing vehicles.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: When is passing on the right permitted?
choices: On multi-lane roads or when a vehicle ahead is turning left
Anytime on any road
Never under any circumstances
Only on highways with 3 or more lanes
questions.explanation: Passing on the right is legal only in specific situations: on roads with multiple lanes going the same direction, or when the vehicle ahead is turning left. Never pass on the right using the shoulder or off-road areas.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: Why should you not pass near intersections, curves, or hills?
choices: You cannot see far enough ahead to ensure oncoming traffic won't reach you
It's not dangerous, just illegal
Other vehicles might turn into your path or appear suddenly
Passing is slow in these areas
questions.explanation: Intersections, curves, and hills limit visibility of oncoming traffic. Without adequate sight distance, you cannot determine if sufficient space exists to pass safely. Unexpected vehicles may also enter from side roads at intersections.
questions.reference: DL-7: Speed Limits and Safe Distances

questions.text: You are approaching an intersection at 35 mph when the light turns red. You are past the point where you can safely stop. What should you do?
choices: Stop at the stop line — you must not enter the intersection on a red light
Accelerate through the intersection before cross traffic starts
Slow down and proceed through cautiously
Stop in the middle of the intersection and wait for green
questions.explanation: A solid red light requires a complete stop before the stop line or crosswalk. If you can still stop safely before entering the intersection, you must do so. Running a red light — even by a fraction of a second — is illegal and one of the leading causes of severe intersection crashes. If you truly cannot stop, you should have been driving at a speed that allowed you to stop when the light changed.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: The light turns green but you can see that the intersection ahead is gridlocked with vehicles from the cross street. What should you do?
choices: Wait behind the stop line until there is room to clear the intersection completely
Enter the intersection since you have a green light
Proceed into the intersection and wait for the gridlock to clear
Honk your horn and enter the intersection
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, you must not enter an intersection unless you can clear it completely. Entering a gridlocked intersection means you will block the cross street when the light changes, creating worse congestion and potentially trapping emergency vehicles. This violation is commonly called 'blocking the box.'
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §545.302; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: What does a solid yellow traffic light indicate?
choices: The light is about to turn red; prepare to stop
Speed up to get through the intersection
Slow down but continue through
Stop immediately regardless of position
questions.explanation: A solid yellow light warns that the signal is about to turn red. You should stop if you can do so safely, not speed up to beat the red light.

questions.text: At a red light, when are you permitted to turn right in Texas?
choices: After coming to a complete stop and yielding to traffic and pedestrians, unless a sign prohibits it
Whenever there is no oncoming traffic
Only when a green arrow appears
Never, right turns on red are illegal in Texas
questions.explanation: In Texas, you may turn right on red after stopping completely and yielding to all traffic and pedestrians, unless a sign specifically prohibits the turn.

questions.text: You are at a red light in the left lane. Can you turn left onto a one-way street in Texas?
choices: Yes, after stopping and yielding to traffic and pedestrians, if no sign prohibits it
No, left turns on red are never permitted
Yes, but only from a one-way street onto another one-way street
Yes, without stopping if the intersection is clear
questions.explanation: In Texas, you may turn left on red only when turning from a one-way street onto another one-way street, after stopping completely and yielding to all traffic.

questions.text: What should you do if you are already in an intersection when the light turns yellow?
choices: Continue through the intersection safely
Stop immediately in the intersection
Back up to the stop line
Speed up to clear the intersection quickly
questions.explanation: If you are already in the intersection when the light turns yellow, you should continue through safely. Stopping in the intersection creates a hazard.

questions.text: At a red light, you want to turn right, but a pedestrian is crossing the street you're turning onto. What must you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to completely cross before turning
Turn slowly behind the pedestrian
Honk to warn the pedestrian and proceed
Turn in front of the pedestrian if moving slowly
questions.explanation: You must yield to all pedestrians in the crosswalk before making a right turn on red. Pedestrians always have the right of way in crosswalks.

questions.text: You are 100 feet from an intersection traveling at 40 mph when the light turns yellow. You estimate you can either stop safely or proceed through before it turns red. What should you generally do?
choices: Stop safely — the yellow light warns that the red phase is about to begin
Accelerate to clear the intersection before the light turns red
Maintain your speed and coast through the intersection
Flash your headlights to warn cross traffic you are coming through
questions.explanation: A yellow light means the signal is about to turn red and you should prepare to stop. If you can safely stop before the intersection, you should do so. The yellow phase is designed to give drivers enough time to either stop or clear the intersection — but when in doubt, stopping is the safer choice. Accelerating through increases the risk of running the red.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: If a traffic signal displays both red and yellow lights at the same time, what does this indicate?
choices: The signal is malfunctioning; treat it as a stop sign
Proceed with extreme caution
The light is about to turn green
You may turn right only
questions.explanation: When a traffic signal displays conflicting lights or appears to be malfunctioning, you must treat the intersection as if it has a stop sign at every approach.

questions.text: When approaching a green light, why should you still scan the intersection before entering?
choices: Other drivers may run their red light or pedestrians may be crossing
Green lights are only advisory
You must always stop at green lights first
Green lights mean yield to all traffic
questions.explanation: Even with a green light, you must ensure the intersection is clear because other drivers may run the red light or pedestrians may still be in the crosswalk.

questions.text: You arrive at a red light behind several cars. When the light turns green, when should you proceed?
choices: When the vehicle ahead of you has moved and it's safe to proceed
Immediately when the light turns green
After counting to three
When you hear other cars honking
questions.explanation: You should proceed when the vehicle in front of you has moved and you can do so safely, maintaining appropriate following distance.

questions.text: Can you enter an intersection on a green light if traffic ahead is backed up and you cannot completely clear the intersection?
choices: No, you must wait until you can completely clear the intersection
Yes, as long as the light is green
Yes, if you enter before the light turns yellow
Yes, but only if you're turning
questions.explanation: You must not enter an intersection, even on a green light, if traffic conditions prevent you from clearing it completely. This prevents blocking the intersection or gridlock.

questions.text: What does a solid red traffic signal mean for pedestrians?
choices: Do not begin crossing; wait for the walk signal
Cross quickly before traffic starts
Cross only if no vehicles are present
You have the right of way to cross
questions.explanation: When the traffic signal is red for vehicles in your direction, pedestrians should wait for their walk signal rather than assuming it's safe to cross.

questions.text: During heavy traffic, you enter an intersection legally on a yellow light but cannot clear it before the light turns red. Traffic from other directions begins to move. What should you do?
choices: Continue clearing the intersection safely; you have the right of way
Stop in the middle of the intersection
Reverse back to your stop line
Turn to exit through a different street
questions.explanation: Once you have legally entered an intersection, you must clear it even if the light turns red. Other traffic must yield to vehicles already in the intersection.

questions.text: What should you do if a traffic signal's green light has been on for a while as you approach?
choices: Be prepared to stop as the light may change soon
Speed up to make sure you get through
Continue at the same speed
Slow down to 5 mph
questions.explanation: A stale green light that has been on for some time may change soon, so you should be prepared to stop safely if needed.

questions.text: You approach an intersection with a red light. There is a marked stop line, a crosswalk beyond it, and then the intersection. Where exactly must you stop?
choices: At the stop line, before the crosswalk
In the crosswalk, as close to the intersection as possible
Just past the crosswalk at the edge of the intersection
Anywhere you can see the traffic signal clearly
questions.explanation: You must stop at the marked stop line. If there is no stop line, stop before the crosswalk. If there is neither, stop before entering the intersection. Stopping in the crosswalk blocks pedestrians and forces them into traffic lanes. Stopping past the crosswalk puts your vehicle in the path of cross traffic.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: If you accidentally run a red light and are already in the intersection, what should you do?
choices: Continue through the intersection quickly and safely
Stop immediately in the intersection
Back up to the stop line
Turn onto a side street
questions.explanation: If you're already in the intersection, stopping creates a greater hazard. You should clear the intersection quickly and safely, then drive more carefully.

questions.text: You are approaching a green light but notice the crosswalk is full of pedestrians still crossing. What should you do?
choices: Wait for all pedestrians to clear the crosswalk before proceeding
Proceed slowly through the pedestrians
Honk to clear the crosswalk
Drive around the pedestrians
questions.explanation: You must always yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk, even if you have a green light. Wait until they have completely crossed.

questions.text: What is the minimum duration you should expect for a yellow light at a typical intersection?
choices: 3 to 6 seconds depending on the speed limit
Always exactly 3 seconds
10 seconds or more
1 to 2 seconds
questions.explanation: Yellow light duration typically ranges from 3 to 6 seconds based on the approach speed and intersection design, giving drivers adequate time to stop safely.

questions.text: You stop at a red light on a steep downhill grade. When the light turns green, the vehicle ahead of you starts to roll backward. What should you do?
choices: Stay back and honk your horn to alert the driver
Move forward to push their vehicle
Quickly change lanes to avoid them
Assume they will stop rolling
questions.explanation: Maintain a safe following distance and alert the driver with your horn. Never move forward into a vehicle, even when you have a green light.

questions.text: You are waiting to turn left at an intersection. The signal changes to a green left-turn arrow. A pedestrian is jogging through the crosswalk. What should you do?
choices: Wait for the pedestrian to clear your path, then turn — the green arrow gives you a protected turn but pedestrians still have priority
Turn immediately — the green arrow means all conflicting traffic and pedestrians are stopped
Honk to alert the pedestrian and proceed with your turn
Ignore the arrow and wait for a solid green light instead
questions.explanation: A green arrow gives you a protected turn phase — meaning oncoming traffic has a red light. However, you must still yield to any pedestrians in the crosswalk. Pedestrians may have entered the crosswalk during the previous phase or may be slow to clear. Safety always takes priority over signal phase.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: You see a green left arrow along with a red circular signal. What should you do?
choices: You may turn left only; straight and right movements are prohibited
You may proceed straight or turn left
You must stop completely
You may proceed in any direction
questions.explanation: A green arrow with a red circular signal means only movements in the direction of the arrow are permitted; all other movements must stop.

questions.text: What does a yellow arrow signal indicate?
choices: The protected turn is ending; prepare to stop or yield
You may proceed with the turn
Turn only if the intersection is clear
The signal is malfunctioning
questions.explanation: A yellow arrow warns that the protected turn phase is ending. You should prepare to stop, or complete your turn if already committed.

questions.text: You are at an intersection wanting to turn left. The signal shows a red left-turn arrow while the main signal is green. May you turn left?
choices: No — a red arrow prohibits turning in that direction until the arrow changes
Yes — you may turn left after yielding to oncoming traffic since the main light is green
Yes — treat the red arrow like a regular red light and turn after stopping
Only if there is no oncoming traffic visible
questions.explanation: A red arrow specifically prohibits movement in the direction of the arrow. Unlike a solid red light (which permits right turns on red in most cases), a red arrow means you must not turn in that direction at all — even after stopping. You must wait until the red arrow is replaced by a green arrow or a solid green light.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: You are in a left turn lane with a green circular signal but no green arrow. What must you do?
choices: Yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians before turning
Proceed with your turn immediately
Wait for a green arrow before turning
You cannot turn left; the signal prohibits it
questions.explanation: A green circular signal without an arrow is a permissive turn. You may turn left but must yield to oncoming traffic and pedestrians.

questions.text: At an intersection, you have a green arrow to turn left. Oncoming traffic has what signal?
choices: A red signal preventing them from entering the intersection
A green signal allowing them to proceed
A yellow caution signal
A flashing red signal
questions.explanation: When you have a green arrow, it is a protected turn meaning oncoming traffic has a red signal and must stop.

questions.text: The signal changes from a green arrow to a green circular signal while you're waiting to turn left. What has changed?
choices: You must now yield to oncoming traffic when turning
You no longer can turn left
You have more right of way than before
Nothing; both signals mean the same thing
questions.explanation: Changing from a green arrow to a green circular signal means your turn is no longer protected. You must now yield to oncoming traffic.

questions.text: Can you make a right turn when you see a red arrow pointing right?
choices: No, you must wait for a green signal or arrow
Yes, after stopping and yielding
Yes, if no traffic is coming
Yes, red arrows are only advisory
questions.explanation: A red arrow specifically prohibits movement in that direction. You cannot turn right on a red arrow, even after stopping.

questions.text: You are turning left on a green arrow. A pedestrian enters the crosswalk against their signal. What should you do?
choices: Stop and yield to the pedestrian even though you have the right of way
Continue; you have the green arrow
Honk and proceed slowly
Swerve around the pedestrian
questions.explanation: Even with a protected green arrow, you must always yield to pedestrians in the roadway to avoid a collision, regardless of signal status.

questions.text: What is the difference between a green arrow and a green circular signal for turning?
choices: A green arrow is protected; a green circular signal requires yielding to oncoming traffic
They mean the same thing
A green arrow requires stopping first
A green circular signal gives more right of way
questions.explanation: A green arrow provides a protected turn with right of way, while a green circular signal is a permissive turn requiring you to yield to oncoming traffic.

questions.text: You have a green left arrow. Halfway through your turn, the arrow turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn safely and clear the intersection
Stop in the middle of your turn
Speed up dramatically
Reverse back to the stop line
questions.explanation: If you've already started your turn legally, you should complete it safely and clear the intersection even if the signal changes.

questions.text: At a complex intersection, you see a green circular signal and a separate red arrow pointing left. What can you do?
choices: Go straight or turn right, but not left
Turn in any direction
Only go straight
Only turn left
questions.explanation: The green circular signal permits straight and right movements, but the red left arrow specifically prohibits left turns.

questions.text: You are waiting to turn left on a green circular signal. Oncoming traffic is heavy. The light turns yellow. What should you do?
choices: Complete your turn when oncoming traffic stops for their yellow light
Wait at the stop line; do not enter the intersection
Turn in front of oncoming traffic quickly
Abandon the turn and go straight
questions.explanation: If you're already in the intersection waiting to turn, you should complete your turn safely when oncoming traffic yields for the yellow light.

questions.text: When turning right on a green circular signal, what must you watch for?
choices: Pedestrians crossing and vehicles turning left from the opposite direction
Only vehicles behind you
Only the traffic signal
Nothing; you have complete right of way
questions.explanation: Even on a green signal, you must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk and watch for vehicles from the opposite direction making permissive left turns.

questions.text: What does it mean if you see a green right arrow?
choices: You have a protected right turn with no conflicting traffic
You must turn right; going straight is prohibited
You may turn right after yielding
The signal is for bikes only
questions.explanation: A green right arrow indicates a protected right turn phase where pedestrian and conflicting traffic are stopped.

questions.text: You're at a T-intersection where you must turn either left or right. You have a red signal but no arrows. Can you turn after stopping?
choices: You may turn right on red after stopping and yielding, unless prohibited by a sign
You cannot turn in either direction on red
You may turn in either direction
You may only turn left
questions.explanation: At a T-intersection with a red signal, standard right-turn-on-red rules apply unless posted otherwise, but left turns on red are not permitted unless turning from one-way to one-way.

questions.text: While waiting to turn left with a green circular signal, you should position your vehicle how?
choices: In the intersection with wheels straight, not turned
Before the stop line with wheels turned left
In the intersection with wheels turned left
Partially in the intersection
questions.explanation: You should position your vehicle in the intersection with wheels straight so that if you're rear-ended, you won't be pushed into oncoming traffic.

questions.text: A traffic signal shows a yellow arrow for your left turn, but you haven't entered the intersection yet. What should you do?
choices: Stop if you can do so safely; the protected turn is ending
Enter the intersection quickly to make the turn
Proceed slowly with caution
Treat it as a green arrow
questions.explanation: A yellow arrow means the protected turn phase is ending. If you haven't entered the intersection, you should stop if you can safely do so.

questions.text: Why might an intersection use a red arrow instead of just a red circular signal?
choices: To specifically prohibit turns while other movements might be allowed
To indicate a longer red phase
To warn of a dangerous intersection
Red arrows and red circles mean exactly the same thing
questions.explanation: Red arrows are used to specifically prohibit certain movements while other directions might have different signal phases.

questions.text: You are in a left-turn lane at an intersection. The signal shows a green arrow pointing left, while the opposing traffic has a red light. What does this combination tell you?
choices: You have a protected left turn — oncoming traffic is stopped, so you may turn without yielding to it
You may turn left but must still yield to oncoming traffic
You should go straight, not left, despite being in the turn lane
The green arrow is for pedestrians, not vehicles
questions.explanation: A green left-turn arrow is a protected phase. It means oncoming traffic has a red signal and should be stopped, so you may proceed with your left turn without needing to yield to oncoming vehicles. However, always scan the intersection before turning — a driver may have run their red light.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: Late at night you approach an intersection where the traffic signal is flashing red in all directions. How should you treat this signal?
choices: Treat it exactly like a stop sign — stop completely, then proceed when safe
Slow down and proceed with caution without stopping
The signal is malfunctioning — proceed at normal speed
Stop and wait for the signal to return to its normal cycle
questions.explanation: A flashing red signal functions as a stop sign. You must come to a complete stop, yield to any vehicles or pedestrians with the right-of-way, and proceed only when safe. If all directions are flashing red, treat the intersection like a four-way stop — yield to the vehicle that arrived first, or to the vehicle on your right if you arrive simultaneously.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: You approach an intersection where the signal is flashing yellow. There is moderate cross traffic. What should you do?
choices: Slow down, watch for cross traffic and pedestrians, and proceed with caution
Come to a complete stop before entering the intersection
Speed up to clear the intersection before it changes
Yield only to vehicles on your right
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow signal means proceed with caution — you do not have to stop unless cross traffic or pedestrians require it. However, you must slow down and be alert because cross traffic may have a flashing red (stop) signal and might not stop. Treat the intersection with extra vigilance, especially at night.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §544.007; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: You approach an intersection with a flashing red signal while cross traffic has a flashing yellow signal. What should you do?
choices: Stop completely, then proceed when safe after yielding to cross traffic
Proceed with caution at the same time as cross traffic
Stop and wait for the signal to turn green
Proceed without stopping since you see the yellow
questions.explanation: A flashing red requires you to stop and yield to all traffic, including vehicles with the flashing yellow who have the right of way.

questions.text: When are you most likely to encounter flashing traffic signals?
choices: Late at night or during low traffic periods, or when signals are malfunctioning
During rush hour
Only during emergency situations
During school hours
questions.explanation: Flashing signals are commonly used during late night hours when full signal cycles aren't needed, or when a signal malfunctions.

questions.text: At an intersection, you have a flashing yellow signal. What right of way do you have?
choices: Proceed with caution but yield to any vehicles already in the intersection
You have complete right of way over all other traffic
You must stop and wait for other vehicles
You must yield to all traffic entering from any direction
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow gives you the right to proceed with caution, but you must still yield to vehicles already lawfully in the intersection.

questions.text: If all signals at an intersection are flashing red in all directions, how should you proceed?
choices: Treat the intersection as a four-way stop
Proceed with caution without stopping
The first to arrive has right of way without stopping
Wait for police to direct traffic
questions.explanation: When all approaches have flashing red signals, the intersection functions as an all-way stop, with normal stop sign rules applying.

questions.text: You approach an intersection where the signal is completely dark with no lights showing. How should you proceed?
choices: Treat it as a four-way stop and stop before entering
Proceed normally as if it were green
Slow down but don't stop unless you see traffic
Only the main road has right of way
questions.explanation: A completely dark or non-functioning signal should be treated as an all-way stop sign, requiring all traffic to stop before proceeding.

questions.text: What is the key difference between a flashing yellow and a solid yellow signal?
choices: Flashing yellow means proceed with caution; solid yellow means prepare to stop
They mean the same thing
Flashing yellow means stop; solid yellow means go
Flashing yellow is more urgent than solid yellow
questions.explanation: A flashing yellow is a warning to proceed cautiously, while a solid yellow indicates the signal is changing and you should prepare to stop.

questions.text: At an intersection with a flashing red signal, two vehicles from different directions arrive at exactly the same time. Who has the right of way?
choices: The vehicle on the right
The vehicle on the left
The larger vehicle
The vehicle that flashes its headlights first
questions.explanation: When two vehicles arrive simultaneously at a flashing red (treated as a stop sign), the vehicle on the right has the right of way.

questions.text: During a power outage, traffic signals are completely out. You arrive at a busy intersection at the same time as several other vehicles. What governs right-of-way?
choices: Standard four-way stop rules and basic right-of-way principles
The largest vehicle goes first
Whoever proceeds first has the right of way
Everyone should wait for police
questions.explanation: Non-functioning signals create a four-way stop situation. Right of way follows normal stop sign rules: first to arrive, or vehicle on right if simultaneous.

questions.text: You are a pedestrian waiting to cross at an intersection. The pedestrian signal changes from a raised hand to a walking person symbol. What does this mean?
choices: You may begin crossing the street in the direction of the signal
You should finish crossing only if you are already in the street
You should wait for the next signal cycle to be safe
You may cross only if the vehicle signal is also green
questions.explanation: The walking person (WALK) signal means pedestrians may begin crossing the street in the indicated direction. It corresponds to a traffic phase that protects you from conflicting vehicle movements. Once the signal changes to a flashing raised hand, you should not start crossing but may finish if you are already in the street.
questions.reference: Texas Transportation Code §552.002; DL-7 Traffic Signals

questions.text: What does a steady DON'T WALK or raised hand signal mean?
choices: Do not start crossing the street
Stop immediately wherever you are
Cross quickly
The signal is for vehicles only
questions.explanation: A steady DON'T WALK or raised hand signal means pedestrians should not begin crossing, though those already crossing should complete their crossing.

questions.text: What does a flashing DON'T WALK signal mean?
choices: Do not start crossing; finish crossing if already in the street
Start crossing quickly
Stop in the middle of the street
The pedestrian signal is broken
questions.explanation: A flashing DON'T WALK means do not start crossing. Pedestrians already in the crosswalk should continue and finish crossing safely.

questions.text: You are a pedestrian and the WALK signal turns to a flashing DON'T WALK when you are halfway across a wide street. What should you do?
choices: Continue crossing to the other side or to a safety island
Run back to where you started
Stop and wait in the middle of the street
Run across quickly
questions.explanation: If the signal changes while you're crossing, continue to the other side or a pedestrian safety island. Do not run or turn back.

questions.text: What does a pedestrian countdown timer indicate?
choices: The number of seconds remaining to finish crossing before the DON'T WALK phase
The number of seconds until WALK signal appears
The speed you should walk
The number of pedestrians allowed to cross
questions.explanation: A countdown timer shows how many seconds pedestrians have to complete their crossing before the don't walk phase ends and traffic may begin.

questions.text: As a driver with a green light, can you proceed through the crosswalk if the pedestrian signal shows DON'T WALK but a pedestrian is still crossing?
choices: No, you must yield to any pedestrian in the crosswalk regardless of signal
Yes, the pedestrian is crossing illegally
Yes, if you honk first
Yes, but proceed very slowly
questions.explanation: Drivers must always yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk, regardless of what the pedestrian signal shows or whose signal shows green.

questions.text: A pedestrian countdown timer shows 3 seconds remaining as you approach the crosswalk. Should you start crossing?
choices: No, do not start crossing if you cannot make it across safely
Yes, you have 3 seconds to cross
Yes, run across quickly
Yes, traffic will wait for you
questions.explanation: If the countdown shows insufficient time to safely cross, do not enter the crosswalk. Wait for the next WALK signal.

questions.text: What should drivers do when they see a pedestrian signal showing WALK for a crosswalk they want to turn through?
choices: Wait for pedestrians to cross; they have the right of way
Turn slowly behind the pedestrians
Honk to warn pedestrians
Proceed; the WALK signal is not for drivers
questions.explanation: When the pedestrian signal shows WALK, pedestrians have the right of way in that crosswalk and drivers must yield before turning.

questions.text: At an intersection with pedestrian signals, you have a green left arrow. What should the pedestrian signal show?
choices: DON'T WALK, preventing pedestrians from crossing into your path
WALK, giving pedestrians the right of way
Flashing DON'T WALK
No signal
questions.explanation: A green arrow for vehicles is a protected turn, meaning pedestrian signals should show DON'T WALK to prevent conflicts.

questions.text: A pedestrian signal shows WALK but the traffic signal for vehicles shows green in the same direction. A driver wants to turn right. Who has the legal right of way?
choices: The pedestrian; drivers must yield when turning
The driver with the green light
Whoever reaches the crosswalk first
Neither; it's a signal malfunction
questions.explanation: Even though drivers have a green light, they must yield to pedestrians in the crosswalk who have a WALK signal when making turns.
